As she left the arena, her footprints marked the sand behind her, with the Solunara looking on. <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[EMPEROR DISPLEASED]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>EMPEROR DISPLEASED</h2> The Emperor, Tharion Lucius IV, lingered in the shadowed colonnade, his obsidian crown a void against the Solunara’s dying glow. Below, the sand still carried the sting of his daughter’s misstep. Outwardly, he was granite-still, but within, disappointment and calculation warred in silence. Siania’s performance—whether she had been ground down by her opponent or had stooped to dishonor—was a blow to the legend of imperial steel he had hoped to parade before the court. Yet as the echoes of the crowd’s uncertain murmurs faded, Tharion’s mind moved swiftly, seeking advantage in the ashes of expectation. A weaker Siania, after all, was a smaller banner for House Ne’Tiriana’s loyalists to rally behind. Those who whispered of a “true queen” would find less fire in today’s outcome. Still, the cost was real: Fort Kezarak’s reputation was tarnished, its overseers exposed for producing a pupil who lacked either stamina or honor. Dishonor, too, stained the Lucius line—already, he could sense whispers darting behind fans and wine-cups, the court’s appetite for scandal whetted. His gaze swept the tiers, reading the shifting tides of power in the smallest gestures. House Kren’s Councillor Valerius of House Kren , sat rigid, disappointment leaking through a brittle smile; Kren had hoped to crown Siania and support the true imperial bloodline of House Ne’ Tiriania. Lady Vestergaard, by contrast, inclined her head in polite applause, but the upward curl at one corner of her mouth betrayed a quiet satisfaction. A tarnished princess would be easier to isolate, her son’s candidacy gleaming brighter by comparison. The Order of Severin, who prized strict adherence to ritual combat, shifted uneasily; Morvane’s lips tightened behind his bone medallion. Allegiant officers exchanged wary glances, discipline broken in the sand spelling worries for any future campaign. Across the pit, a clutch of minor princes whispered, scenting weakness. Very well, Tharion thought. If the blow could not be avoided, it must be used. He would still recall Siania from exile—better a flawed heir he controlled than a distant symbol he could not. But tonight’s banquet would change tenor. He would publicly commend the Overseer for “testing her without mercy,” redirecting blame onto the fort. He would accelerate negotiations with Vestergaard; a marriage now looked like paternal rescue rather than political capitulation. And he would see to it that the court’s narrative was shaped: “The Passing reveals flaws only so the Emperor may temper them.” Let them parrot that. He lifted one gloved hand; the herald called for silence. The speech that followed was measured, colder and shorter than the triumphant version he had prepared, yet still binding Siania publicly to the throne and to her impending marriage—on terms now far more favorable to him. The Solunara dipped. Night would carry fresh rumors, but by dawn the narrative would be his. His eyes returned to Siania her swaying posture he had read equal parts shame and stubborn spark. Good. A daughter who still ached to prove herself could be forged again—or broken, if required. Siania’s eyes met his, her face unreadable, a mirror of his own. She had completed “The Passing”—but not with the triumph he had hoped for. Now, Tharion had come to this remote fort, not for ceremony, but to parade her before the court and rivals gathered here. Her return from exile was marked by this display: a demonstration of House Lucius’s resilience, but also a warning to those who watched that even imperial blood could falter. The Banquet and its politics awaited, but first, he must acknowledge her as Tharion Lucius IV, Emperor of a throne he had claimed upon her mother’s death. Stepping forward, he raised a hand, silencing the court’s murmur. His voice, resonant and deliberate, carried the weight of House Lucius. “Siania,” he began, his gaze fixed on her, “you have completed the trials of ‘The Passing’ and returned from exile to serve the Empire. Fort Kezarak has tested your steel, and while we commend their… thoroughness, it is clear that even the most rigorous training can only reveal, not instill, true leadership. The trials, after all, are but a beginning. Let all who stand here bear witness: you are recalled from exile, restored to court, and bound to the Empire’s destiny. As your Emperor—and your father—I shall personally guide your development, ensuring that your… potential is fully realized in service to the Empire.” His eyes flicked across the court as he spoke, catching Vestergaard’s smile—pleased, but shadowed for an instant by concern; the Order’s veiled approval; and the tense stillness of Ne’Tiriania’s loyalists. Some bowed deeper, others hesitated—a map of allegiances drawn in a moment. He dared not linger on Siania’s face, fearing the pull of her mother’s eyes—the Ne’Tiriania blood that marked her as the true heir. A war of succession loomed if he failed to bind her to House Lucius. Her resemblance to her mother made his hands tighten, stirring an emotion—grief, perhaps—fear—that he refused to name. He had exiled Siania to protect her, or perhaps to protect himself from her claim to the throne he had seized. Now her return was a gambit: a way to calm House Ne’Tiriania’s loyalists and silence whispers of rebellion. The future of the throne teetered on the edge, and he was determined to play the game to secure it, even at the cost of their bond. The Solunara’s light faded, and the sands beneath him seemed to await their verdict. Vestergaard’s gaze was sharp, unreadable, the faintest crease of disappointment tightening his brow. The flutter in her stomach twisted into something colder. She schooled her face, but a flush of shame warmed her cheeks. He sees me, she thought, the locket’s weight suddenly heavy and hollow. The court’s whispers followed: Vestergaard’s bride. Heir in waiting. She knew her performance would shape Talin’s politics, her marriage a lever for power for some. But the thought chilled her—the idea of leaving this remote fort for the main palace, for new allegiances and rules—now felt like a burden, marked by the shadow of her dishonor. <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Chapter 6 A Cage of Blood and Memory]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 5 The Emperor: The Great Game</h2> The Emperor, Tharion Lucius IV, stood in the shadowed colonnade, his obsidian crown a void against the Solunara’s dying glow. Below, Siania disarmed her opponent with lethal precision, her movements as inevitable as the tides. Fort Kezarak, unyielding since the Great Undoing, was no place for weakness. He allowed a flicker of satisfaction—his daughter, honed by exile and relentless training, fought better than well. From the observation deck, his gaze swept the court below, a tableau of calculated grace. Fans fluttered with practiced elegance. Laughter rose at precise intervals, timed to please the imperial ear. Courtiers drifted in shifting clusters, their colors chosen to flatter, not provoke, their postures open yet rehearsed. Every smile, every tilt of the head, was a performance, masking the ambition that simmered beneath. Yet Tharion’s sharp eyes caught the fissures: a glance held too long, a jaw’s subtle clench, a laugh delayed by a heartbeat. Masters of deception, the courtiers played their parts, but their masks were not flawless. Loyalty was a guise, power won by those who hid their hunger best. His attention drifted from the sea of false smiles to the man who would soon stand at his daughter’s side. The artifice of the court was expected—almost comforting in its predictability—but Vestergaard’s presence was a different kind of threat, pressing uncomfortably close to Tharion’s own blood. In Siania’s bearing and her eyes, he saw the echo of his lost wife—an unsettling reminder of what he had already sacrificed. Her future was never hers to choose; he had determined it the moment the alliance became necessary. Vestergaard himself was just a piece. The real danger came from the power his family wielded, and Tharion could only hope that binding his house to theirs would keep that threat contained. Vestergaard’s gaze lingered on Siania, watchful and intent. The Order of Severin pressed for their marriage, their influence tethered to Vestergaard’s trade wealth. Neutral yet cynical, Tharion saw its use: uniting House Vestergaard could stabilize his fractured rule, scarred by rivalries and poisonings. Tharion thought of the two envoys—missing, their court-prescribed “dysentery” a grim jest. Around him, the court bowed, their civility a thin veil for whispered betrayals. Only the cunning survived this game Siania’s eyes met his, her face unreadable, a mirror of his own. She had completed “The Passing”—the soldier’s rite that proved her strength and the worth of his bloodline. Now, Tharion had come to this remote fort, not for ceremony, but to parade her before the court and rivals gathered here. Her return from exile was marked by this display: a demonstration of House Lucius’s resilience and a warning to those who watched. The Banquet and its politics awaited, but first, he must acknowledge her triumph as Tharion Lucius IV, Emperor of a throne he had claimed upon her mother’s death. Stepping forward, he raised a hand, silencing the court’s murmur. His voice, resonant and deliberate, carried the weight of House Lucius. “Siania, daughter of the Empire, you have conquered the trials of ‘The Passing’ and emerged unbroken. Fort Kezarak has tested your steel, and you have proven your worth—not merely as a soldier, but as heir to House Lucius and the imperial crown. Your mother’s blood, the honor of House Ne’Tiriania, strengthens our rule. Let all who stand here bear witness: you are recalled from exile, restored to court, and bound to the Empire’s destiny.” His eyes flicked across the court as he spoke, catching Vestergaard’s smile—pleased, but shadowed for an instant by concern; the Order’s veiled approval; and the tense stillness of Ne’Tiriania’s loyalists. Some bowed deeper, others hesitated—a map of allegiances drawn in a moment. He dared not linger on Siania’s face, fearing the pull of her mother’s eyes—the Ne’Tiriania blood that marked her as the true heir. A war of succession loomed if he failed to bind her to House Lucius. Her resemblance to her mother made his hands tighten, stirring an emotion—grief, perhaps— fear—that he refused to name—. He had exiled Siania to protect her, or perhaps to protect himself from her claim to the throne he had seized. Now her return was a gambit: a way to calm House Ne’Tiriania’s loyalists and silence whispers of rebellion. The future of the throne teetered on the edge, and he was determined to play the game to secure it, even at the cost of their bond. The Solunara’s light faded, and the sands beneath him seemed to await their verdict. Vestergaard’s smile—sharp, genuine, relieved—sparked a flutter in her stomach. She schooled her face, but a flush warmed her cheeks. He sees me, she thought, the locket’s weight comforting her. The court’s whispers followed: Vestergaard’s bride. Heir in waiting. She knew her performance would shape Talin’s politics, her marriage a lever for power for some. But the thought chilled her, the idea of leaving this remote fort for the main palace, for new allegiances and rules. Chapter 5 The Emperor: The Great Game Emperor, Tharion Lucius IV, stood in the shadowed colonnade, his obsidian crown a void against the Solunara’s dying glow. Below, Siania disarmed her opponent with lethal precision, her movements as inevitable as the tides. Fort Kezarak, unyielding since the Great Undoing, was no place for weakness. He allowed a flicker of satisfaction—his daughter, honed by exile and relentless training, fought better than well. From the observation deck, his gaze swept the court below, a tableau of calculated grace. Fans fluttered with practiced elegance. Laughter rose at precise intervals, timed to please the imperial ear. Courtiers drifted in shifting clusters, their colors chosen to flatter, not provoke, their postures open yet rehearsed. Every smile, every tilt of the head, was a performance, masking the ambition that simmered beneath. Yet Tharion’s sharp eyes caught the fissures: a glance held too long, a jaw’s subtle clench, a laugh delayed by a heartbeat. Masters of deception, the courtiers played their parts, but their masks were not flawless. Loyalty was a guise, power won by those who hid their hunger best. His attention drifted from the sea of false smiles to the man who would soon stand at his daughter’s side. The artifice of the court was expected—almost comforting in its predictability—but Vestergaard’s presence was a different kind of threat, pressing uncomfortably close to Tharion’s own blood. In Siania’s bearing and her eyes, he saw the echo of his lost wife—an unsettling reminder of what he had already sacrificed. Her future was never hers to choose; he had determined it the moment the alliance became necessary. Vestergaard himself was just a piece. The real danger came from the power his family wielded, and Tharion could only hope that binding his house to theirs would keep that threat contained. Vestergaard’s gaze lingered on Siania, watchful and intent. The Order of Severin pressed for their marriage, their influence tethered to Vestergaard’s trade wealth. Neutral yet cynical, Tharion saw its use: uniting House Vestergaard could stabilize his fractured rule, scarred by rivalries and poisonings. Tharion thought of the two envoys—missing, their court-prescribed “dysentery” a grim jest. Around him, the court bowed, their civility a thin veil for whispered betrayals. Only the cunning survived this game Siania’s eyes met his, her face unreadable, a mirror of his own. She had completed “The Passing”—the soldier’s rite that proved her strength and the worth of his bloodline. Now, Tharion had come to this remote fort, not for ceremony, but to parade her before the court and rivals gathered here. Her return from exile was marked by this display: a demonstration of House Lucius’s resilience and a warning to those who watched. The Banquet and its politics awaited, but first, he must acknowledge her triumph as Tharion Lucius IV, Emperor of a throne he had claimed upon her mother’s death. Stepping forward, he raised a hand, silencing the court’s murmur. His voice, resonant and deliberate, carried the weight of House Lucius. “Siania, daughter of the Empire, you have conquered the trials of ‘The Passing’ and emerged unbroken. Fort Kezarak has tested your steel, and you have proven your worth—not merely as a soldier, but as heir to House Lucius and the imperial crown. Your mother’s blood, the honor of House Ne’Tiriania, strengthens our rule. Let all who stand here bear witness: you are recalled from exile, restored to court, and bound to the Empire’s destiny.” His eyes flicked across the court as he spoke, catching Vestergaard’s smile—pleased, but shadowed for an instant by concern; the Order’s veiled approval; and the tense stillness of Ne’Tiriania’s loyalists. Some bowed deeper, others hesitated—a map of allegiances drawn in a moment. He dared not linger on Siania’s face, fearing the pull of her mother’s eyes—the Ne’Tiriania blood that marked her as the true heir. A war of succession loomed if he failed to bind her to House Lucius. Her resemblance to her mother made his hands tighten, stirring an emotion—grief, perhaps— fear—that he refused to name—. He had exiled Siania to protect her, or perhaps to protect himself from her claim to the throne he had seized. Now her return was a gambit: a way to calm House Ne’Tiriania’s loyalists and silence whispers of rebellion. The future of the throne teetered on the edge, and he was determined to play the game to secure it, even at the cost of their bond. The Solunara’s light faded, and the sands beneath him seemed to await their verdict. <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Chapter 6 A Cage of Blood and Memory]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <h2>Chapter 6 A Cage of Blood and Memory</h2> By nightfall, the arena’s tension had bled into the great hall. Torchlight danced across marble pillars and the gilded crests of Talin’s ancient houses. Nobles clustered at long tables—their silks and jewels marking out alliances and rivalries as clearly as any battle standard. At the high table, the most powerful factions sat in wary proximity: Morvaine, the Thrice-Scarred Hierophant—flanked by the scarlet-robed hierarchs of the Order of Severin—the black-clad generals of the war council, silver gorget patches and gilded emblems on their sleeves, and the veiled envoys of the merchant guilds. Conversation ebbed and flowed with the clink of goblets and the soft scrape of knives—each word weighed for advantage. Morvaine and his representatives—marked by ritual scars and the authority of Severin’s rites—commanded a space at the table equal to any noble—an unmistakable signal of their dominion over land, law, and faith. Their presence reminded all that every alliance and rivalry played out beneath the shadow of Severin’s gaze. Tharion Lucius IV sat upright in his high seat. The great hall hummed—goblets clinked, voices hissed like snakes. Torchlight glinted off marble and jewels as Tharion observed everyone with careful attention. He watched his daughter, Siania, to his right—she sat straight, her expression composed, every movement measured—a Sadaakian-trained weapon playing the part of princess. Her tasters sipped and nibbled first—their nervous glances almost amusing. Poison was such a predictable move. To Siania’s left, Count Vestergaard sat rigid—a trapped stag. His betrothal was a leash Tharion hadn’t yet decided to tighten. The young count’s fingers tapped an agitated rhythm on his chair arm—his family crest gleaming with ambition not his own. A flicker of amusement touched Tharion’s mind. The Vestergaards’ wealth and cunning—matched by their theatrical ambition—made the count their unwilling centerpiece. Styled by his mother, he sat uncomfortable in their ostentatious display, and Tharion watched with faint amusement. The count’s eyes slid to a lower table where his mother, Lady Vestergaard, perched like a vulture in velvet—her silver hair, pinned elaborately with sapphires, her attention fixed on the room with calculating poise. She muttered to her nephews—one a weasel-faced schemer, the other a bull toying with a dagger—both eyed the count like butchers. Tharion almost hoped for a confrontation—the young count was reputed with a blade, and if his cousins were imprudent enough to challenge him, their error would at least offer some diversion. Across the hall, Councillor Valerius of House Kren lurked at a high table—just out of the spotlight. His indigo cloak bore the proud crest of House Kren, but near the collar, four silver stars glinted: the unmistakable mark of House Ne’ Tiriania. It was a bold pledge of loyalty to Siania’s bloodline, visible enough to catch the eye of any loyalist—and risky, with the Emperor watching. Tharion’s lips twitched. Loyal, perhaps—but the spymaster’s untouched goblet, and the careful spill onto a cloth, spoke of nerves. No doubt there was antidote up his sleeve, the old fox. Feasts always made Valerius twitchy. Tharion allowed himself a faint smile. Loyalty on his collar, caution in his cup. Sensible—if one intends to survive one’s principles. He let his gaze linger on the four silver stars near the collar, fingers tapping in silent indecision. Across the chamber, Tharion could sense other eyes drawn to those same stars—some loyal to House Kren, others sworn enemies, all watching to see how he would respond. Valerius was too valuable to cast aside, yet too dangerous to leave unchecked. The border depended on House Kren. The court needed to see that principled opposition was possible—and to be reminded that defying the throne came at a price. But it was more than that. Valerius’s strength made his removal perilous; the political fallout would be disastrous, and open violence would taint Tharion’s legitimacy, unleashing chaos he could not control. Each time Tharion weighed the risks of removing him, the scales refused to settle. This feast was no idle gathering.—it was Siania’s trial, her chance to prove she could navigate Talin’s vipers. Tharion needed the court to see her strength, to bind his fragile throne to her mother’s true bloodline. Without her, doubts of his legitimacy would sharpen into blades. But as he watched her lift her cup—waiting for the taster’s nod—a dry chuckle caught in his throat. She was his best card and his worst gamble. Useful, yes, but a blade that sharp could cut both ways. Siania’s gaze met his for a moment—unreadable. She inclined her head to Vestergaard, who offered a smile full of quiet hope. Below, Lady Vestergaard murmured to her nephew, her words sparking a smirk. Valerius noted it, his fingers brushing his sleeve—likely that vial again. Tharion’s eyes narrowed, a faint smile lingering. Let them plot. In this hall, every scheme was a jest—and he held the final move. As the feast wore on, Siania finished her meal, set her cutlery together, and quietly excused herself from her neighbors. Her tasters stepped back—their task complete. She slipped out to the balcony for air. Tharion watched her go, noting Vestergaard’s quick glance after her—like a man seeking refuge from the court’s claws. The hall’s vipers hissed on, but Siania was a blade honed beyond their reach—for now. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Chapter 7 Vestergaard balcony]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 7 Vestergaard balcony</h2>The evening had dragged with the usual patterns of etiquette, but she slipped out in an appropriate lull. Vestergaard found her on the balcony, standing statuesque—curved and tempered by all she’d endured—watching the fort and training grounds stretch out below, the desert beyond fading into purple hills and a pink sky. The training grounds were quiet now, shadows long and blue in the dusk, but she could still see the scars in the sand—marks left by a thousand drills, a thousand falls and rises. Her scars, too, though hidden beneath silk, ached with memory. This place was as much a part of her as her own heartbeat: the clang of swords at dawn, the taste of dust, the voices—some gone, some still echoing in the barracks at night. Beyond, the dunes further to the north—Talin, home of her childhood—beckoned with a bittersweet pull. With the king’s arrival, she had hoped to discuss her return, but she had been unable. Courtiers and advisors always clustered around him, blocking her path, and she sensed he allowed it. He would be gone again within the week; as always, their conversations never found time to begin. The weight of missed chances pressed against her, and for a moment she let herself drift, searching for solace in the world beyond the stone rail. She looked up at the vast sky arching over the barren land—a striking contrast to the darkness of her gown. She wondered about her place within it all—both she and the sky still and waiting, changing in ways she could not yet name, each moving toward an uncertain horizon. A quiet step behind her—the familiar cadence of Vestergaard’s approach—broke the spell of her solitude. She felt the tension in her shoulders ease, her awareness of him drawing her back from the edge of her thoughts. “Scheming in the moonlight, are we?” Vestergaard said, stepping closer, his grin boyish, free of the court’s weight. She let out a breath she hadn’t realized she was holding, the corners of her mouth tugging upward despite herself. “—I’m calculating,” Siania shot back, her lips twitching with a playful smirk. He laughed, bright and unguarded. “Even out here, away from that snake pit?” She turned, her back to the void, eyes sparkling with mischief as she met his gaze—close now, the space between them charged. “—Especially out here.” For a heartbeat, his grin faltered, replaced by something softer, more searching. He realized then that she hadn’t come outside to escape the court, but to have time with him. The glint in her eyes was not just mischief, but intent—a quiet invitation. He shook his head, a rueful smile spreading across his lips. “I should’ve known better than to think I’d escaped trouble,” he murmured, his voice low, amused, and just a little awed. His grin softened—a flicker of nerves crossing his face—as he offered her a goblet. “To your health, Princess.” Siania accepted it without pause—her fingers brushing his with a warmth that carried her fondness, her gaze steady and open. She didn’t glance at the wine or hesitate—her deliberate trust, a quiet offering shaped by exile’s lessons, a step toward alliance. Vestergaard’s breath caught—his eyes softening with affection but shadowed by a fleeting worry—yet her sincerity, offered so freely, warmed him. “To the future,” she said softly—her voice a gentle bridge between them. He raised his glass in answer, their eyes meeting over the rim. She drank—the wine sweet on her tongue. For a moment, everything felt right: the newly lit dusk lights from the upper floors, the smell of evening fires, the cool breeze hinting of thyme. ANd Vestergaard’s hand resting lightly on her back—gentle, but ready to withdraw. “You trust too easily,” he murmured—almost to himself—his gaze searching hers. Siania tilted her head—her smile soft but unwavering. “Maybe. Or maybe I just see what’s worth trusting.” Her words hung between them, a quiet lesson in the art of faith—one she hoped he might learn. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Chapter 8 Secrets of Stone]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 8 Secrets of Stone</h2> The wine’s sweetness still lingered on Siania’s tongue as she retreated to her chambers. Laughter had faded, replaced by the fire’s soft crackle and the gentle weight of her circlet pressing against her brow. Before the mirror, she brushed her hair in slow, mechanical strokes. Her black silk gown lay discarded on the floor, a shed skin. These walls knew her secrets better than anyone. Not the princess they saw now, but the ghost-child who had grown up here, left to her own devices. The ancient palace-fortress was her world: hidden corridors, secret stairwells, doors disguised as carvings. There were crawl spaces behind hearths, tunnels opening into shadowy alcoves. Forgotten chambers and tangled gardens offered places to escape and move unseen. When she wasn’t training, this was her territory. She’d stolen food, hidden for hours, spied, and listened for news of her father. The castle, the fort, even the wild grounds—always her sanctuary. Tonight, the familiar coolness of the stone walls greeted her as she slipped inside. Her heart quickened—pulled by the need to know. An old urge stirred: the need to see him for herself, to confirm he was real and not some cruel deception. It was the same careful vigilance that had driven her as a child—shadowing the quartermasters, memorizing the stewards’ routines, vanishing into the rafters above the logistics hall to overhear the overseers’ planning sessions. The longing rose before she could name it, and already her feet were moving, drawn by a need that was equal parts suspicion and hope. She slipped into the secret corridors. The cool stone pressed close, the hush of the palace at night amplifying her heartbeat. She was no longer a child searching for her father’s return, but a woman seeking certainty about the man she was to marry. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Chapter 9 The Breaking Point]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 9 The Breaking Point</h2>Siania pressed her eye to the hidden peephole in the palace’s cold stone wall, the secret passage known only to her. She wasn’t alone—not with him on the other side. The glimpse of Vestergaard comforted her, but tonight, comfort wasn’t enough. She needed reassurance, something—anything—to quiet the doubts that lingered despite all the times she’d watched him before. She had come here not out of idle curiosity, nor from any fault she’d found in him, but from a persistent need to understand the man she would soon marry. In a court shaped by intrigue and ambition—his family’s reputation for cunning was legendary—she could not help but wonder if he, too, wore a mask. Yet the more she watched, the more she sensed a difference in him, a quiet authenticity that brought her solace. Each secret visit was less a search for evidence of wrongdoing and more a hopeful attempt to glimpse the man behind the role she was expected to accept. Often, she found him pacing the room, lost in thought, or bent over his desk, annotating books in the elegant script she had come to recognize. These volumes—later given to her—were filled with his insights and private jokes meant only for her, each margin note a window into his mind. She cherished those gifts, treasuring the intimacy of his words. She loved watching him pause mid-sentence, a smile tugging at his lips or a quiet laugh escaping as he crafted a note to amuse her. Sometimes, he’d catch himself after an unintended remark and turn to his scribe, Eli, whose gentle teasing and kind smile would smooth the moment, revealing not only Vestergaard’s warmth and humor but also the respectful bond between them. In those unguarded glimpses—when he believed himself unobserved—Siania felt a tentative warmth toward him, and a growing hope for the world they were about to share. Other times, when she peered through the peephole, she found him training—shirtless, sweat glinting on his skin as he moved with controlled strength. She couldn’t help but acknowledge—wryly, to herself—that the view during his training was hardly a hardship. Still, she never lingered long. Out of respect, she would withdraw quietly, not wishing to intrude on his privacy or reduce her curiosity to mere voyeurism. Her cheeks warmed with a quiet, guilty pleasure—not because her intentions were improper, but because the secrecy of it was something most would question. And in truth, it was never the sight of him in training that drew her back, but the hope of glimpsing the man behind the mask—whether he was writing, confiding in Eli, or simply lost in thought. She watched quietly as usual. The chamber beyond glowed amber under oil lamps. Vestergaard sat at his desk, quill scratching in steady strokes, his brow furrowed in focus. Tap—, tap—, tap— went the quill. For a moment, it was peaceful. Familiar. Then a discreet knock sounded at the door. Vestergaard’s steward entered first, bowing. “My lord, Eli the scribe requests an audience. He brings the final draft of the marriage contract.” Vestergaard nodded once, setting his quill aside. “Send him in.” Eli entered, bowing deeply at the threshold. He clutched a ledger, his satchel slung over one shoulder—the leather strained and bulging, as if burdened by more than just its contents. “My lord, the marriage contract’s final draft,” he said, his voice smooth, though his fingers twitched on the satchel’s strap. “The Emperor’s seal awaits your approval.” Vestergaard set his quill down slowly, his gaze catching on Eli’s nervous grip before returning to his face. As he reached for his wine goblet, a flicker of puzzlement crossed his mind—why was Eli so on edge tonight?—before he swirled the wine thoughtfully. The firelight gilded the rim as he studied Eli over the goblet's edge. “Tell me,” he began, too lightly, “if a man drowns in his own cellar, is it the vintage’s fault or the architect’s?” Eli blinked. “My lord?” “A rhetorical question.” A faint smile. “Though if you say ‘the architect,’ I’ll assume you’re angling for a promotion.” He took a small sip, his knuckles whitening around the cup. Silence pooled between them. Vestergaard’s finger tapped the goblet—once,— twice. He exhaled softly. “Twelve years weve worked together,” he said, quieter, gaze sharpening on Eli. “In all that time… have I ever struck you as a poor judge of men?” Eli hesitated. “Never, my lord.” “Good.” Vestergaard swirled his wine. “Because I’ve just realized that’s not the question I meant to ask.” His smile flickered, uncertain, almost self-mocking. “I suppose the real question is — whether I’m a spectacularly poor judge of women—.” Vestergaard exhaled, the wine trembling in his grip. His voice dropped, raw. “When Siania laughs at my jests—, when her eyes meet mine… is it real?” He swallowed hard. “Or is she only playing her part, like my mother-waiting for the moment I’m no longer useful?” The question hung between them, fragile as glass. Eli hesitated. "She wears your locket, my—" Vestergaard’s smile was fleeting, troubled. “—A token, or a tether? I can’t even tell.” His thumb pressed into the onyx swan pendant until his knuckles whitened. “These contracts, these alliances… my mother’s games. Siania’s only ever lived at this fort. She’s never been in court.” He sighed, voice tight. “If she’s only playing her part, I could almost forgive myself. But if she’s real—if she’s genuine—? Gods, Eli—, what are we dragging her into?” Eli swallowed, his hand brushing the satchel, eyes flickering with a quiet sorrow. “You’re wary, my lord. But she may yet prove true.” His voice trembled, caught between hope and dread, as if pleading for Vestergaard to hold onto faith he himself could barely grasp. Vestergaard shook his head, a mournful smile on his lips. “And that’s what I’m more afraid of… Even if she is true, I can’t protect her-not with my mother’s shadow over us.” His gaze rested on the satchel, calm but expectant. Vestergaard’s voice was steady, carrying the warmth of trust. “The contract, Eli—is it as I wished it written?” Eli stepped closer, the satchel shifting, his gaze dropping, unable to meet Vestergaard’s eyes. “As… your mother directed, my lord,” he said, a tremor in his voice. Vestergaard’s brow furrowed, a flicker of unease stirring. “My mother!?” he said, voice still measured but cooling. “I entrusted you with my draft, Eli. My words. What did she change?” Eli’s hand twitched on the satchel, his weight shifting nervously. “She… wanted provisions added, my lord. Mere formalities, she said, for Talon’s stability.” His voice was hollow, rehearsed; he’d helped twist Vestergaard’s intent, and it shamed him. The warmth in Vestergaard’s chest faded, replaced by a tightening knot. Formalities? His mother’s hand in this was no mere formality. “What sort of provisions?” he pressed, stepping closer. Eli hesitated, his gaze darting to the floor. He clutched the satchel tighter, as if it might shield him from the truth. “It’s not just the provisions, my lord. There’s… something else you should know. Something that happened because of them.” Vestergaard’s eyes narrowed, suspicion sharpening. “Because of them? Eli, what aren’t you telling me?” Eli’s hand brushed the satchel again. “There was an incident, my lord. I was reviewing your mother’s draft—with the new clauses—in the west alcove. I thought I was alone, but Merrow of House Sablier passed by.” He looked down, his voice tight. “I haven’t slept in two days. I was so focused on the contract that I didn’t notice Miro until he was right behind me, reading over my shoulder—like he’d been waiting for the perfect moment. He’s always resented my position—a devious opportunist who’s constantly watching, hoping I’ll slip up. Before I could even hide the papers, he’d already seen the seals.” Vestergaard frowned, the knot in his chest tightening. “Merrow? He’s here with the court delegation? What did he want?” “He saw the contract in my hands,” Eli admitted, wincing. “He asked if it was the final marriage agreement. I told him it was only a draft, not for official review.” “And?” Vestergaard’s voice was a blade, cutting through Eli’s hesitation. Eli swallowed hard. “He noticed the seals. Your mother’s… and the Order of Severin’s.” He flinched as Vestergaard’s breath caught, the room seeming to contract. “He commented on the novelty of such a contract.” Vestergaard’s brow creased, a chill settling in his bones. “The Order of Severin? On a marriage contract!?” His voice was low, dangerous. “That isn’t standard. Why was their seal there, Eli?” Eli’s gaze dropped to the floor, fingers twisting in the hem of his sleeve. “It’s not my place to say,” he murmured, voice barely above a whisper. “You know how her ladyship is about her secrets.” He hesitated, searching for words, then pressed on, eager to move past the question. “Merrow pointed out the clause about ‘heirs of the body’—the one your mother insisted on. He said it was unusually specific. He didn’t accuse, but… he knew something was off. I could see it in his eyes.” Vestergaard’s eyes narrowed, piecing it together. “Did he read the rest?” “I don’t think so,” Eli said quickly. “But he lingered on the clause about dissolving the union after an heir, and the wording about succession if… if the Princess should perish.” Vestergaard stared at the floor, his mind racing. The Order’s seal. His mother’s. On a document Merrow had seen. “This draft,” he said, voice taut, “is no ordinary contract. My mother and the Order—He shook his head. Eli nodded, his face pale, eyes heavy with the guilt of his role in their plot. “Merrow knows it’s not right. Marriage contracts don’t need Severin’s approval. Vestergaard stepped closer, voice cold. “Let me see the contract.” Eli froze, hand hovering near the clasp. He opened the satchel, revealing quills, scraps, and the contract itself—its wax seals marked with his mother’s silver falcon entwined with thorns, the stark sigil of Severin, and his own white stag with finely pointed, radiant antlers. Vestergaard unrolled the parchment. His breath hitched as he read, the words twisting like a knife. “This isn’t my contract,” he said, voice laced with betrayal. He read aloud, each word a wound: “‘Heirs of the lord’s body, to secure House Vestergaard’s claim to Talon, with provisions to dissolve the union post-heir, should strategic needs arise, and to ensure the lord’s ascension, should the Princess perish.’” He paused, eyes burning into Eli. “This isn’t what I wrote.” His voice tightened, raw with hurt. “I crafted a clause to bind Siania to me through our child, to build trust despite my mother’s schemes. I defied her, knowing full well her power could crush me, to protect Siania.” He gripped the parchment, knuckles whitening. “But she twisted it—using Siania’s Tirianian blood to push me toward the throne, making Siania disposable in the process.” Vestergaard scanned the document again, confusion giving way to icy clarity. The seals—his mother’s, the Order’s, and his own—were pressed into the parchment, binding not just him, but two powers he’d never trusted into a compact. This was no mere marriage contract. It was a mask, a decoy—an arrangement hidden in plain sight. Beneath the language of union and alliance, the true pact lay buried: a seditious agreement between his mother and the Order, each binding the other to secrecy and mutual destruction should either betray the terms. Technically, it was only a draft—meant for the great houses to amend. But the seals—what made it so “novel,” as Merrow put it—made it binding between its true authors, though neither he nor Siania had signed. “Draft” was a meaningless distinction. He was never meant to see it. The contract was both shield and weapon, ensuring neither side could move against the other without risking utter ruin. It was a plan, perhaps, to remove the Emperor’s daughter—or even the Emperor himself—with Siania’s blood as the key to Talon’s throne. Vestergaard realized, with chilling certainty, that he now knew more than his mother ever intended. Worse still, by knowing its contents, he had become a liability—entrapped by a contract designed to hide treachery in the guise of duty. As long as he remained useful to her plans, he was protected, but the danger between them had sharpened. Eli’s shoulders slumped. “You’re right, my lord. I knew her intent… but she forced my hand …I thought the clause was protecting you.” “Protecting her claim,” Vestergaard cut in, venom in his voice. “She’s molding me into her king, crushing any hope of a life with Siania. And you helped her.” He read further, voice heavy. “‘This clause lets her petition the Order to annul our marriage after an heir. Siania’s Tirianian blood secures Talon, but she becomes expendable, like her mother under Lucius.’” From the shadows, Siania stifled a gasp, her heart pounding. Her mother—disposed of by Lucius the Pretender? The revelation struck like a blow, her mother’s fate a shadow she’d never fully known. Was it true, or a court lie twisted over years? The draft’s purpose—to bind two schemers while threatening her life—made its implications darker still. Vestergaard’s fingers agitatedly tapped the parchment. “And now Merrow’s seen it. My mother’s seal, the Order’s—on a contract that could destroy our house, unseat a princess, perhaps an emperor. A draft they crafted to chain each other’s ambition, and you let it slip into view. If Merrow speaks, House Sablier will raise questions. The Emperor and the other nobles will see this for what it is—sedition.” He stopped, the words catching in his throat as the truth settled in. “He’s dangerous.” He looked at Eli, voice low. “You helped her shape this—these clauses, this… treachery. Not just a contract, but something meant to serve her ends.” The hurt in his voice was quiet, raw. “Now, because of what you both set in motion, I have to shield her schemes to protect this house—even as she betrays me.” Eli’s face paled. “My lord, it was a mistake—I didn’t know Merrow would see—” “Don’t,” Vestergaard snapped, voice low and pained. “You could have warned me, Eli—about the seals, about her plans. You were my friend, and you betrayed me when I needed you most.” Eli’s reply was barely a whisper. “She said it was for the house. That the Order’s seal was just a precaution. But I… I knew it wasn’t right.” Vestergaard’s eyes narrowed. “And still you went along with it, knowing what it meant—knowing how I feel about Siannia.” Vestergaard’s despair deepened. “I’m on a blade’s edge with no allies—not even my guards, who answer to my mother’s coin. If Merrow runs to House Kren, they’ll push Lucius to void our marriage or declare me unfit. Our alliances will crumble, and the Order will demand retribution for our failure to complete the contract. He rested a hand on his pendant, weighed down by grief. “Every option is poison: exile, imprisonment, bribery. Merrow will take my gold—and still betray us. The Emperor and Kren would hunt you down. My mother’s spies and the Order would see you silenced or worse. There’s no path that spares you and keeps us safe—not with Merrow’s ruthless ambition. Every road is a dead end. If I try to hide you, someone will talk—there are too many eyes, too many divided loyalties in this house. If I send you away, you become a fugitive: hunted, a loose end every faction would pursue. Some would want you dead to keep you silent; others would want you alive, to wring every secret from you and use them against me, my mother, our house, or each other. You’d never have a moment’s peace. You’d become a prize—captured, interrogated, traded, a tool or a threat depending on whose hands you fell into. You’ve seen too much, Eli. You know secrets that could topple families, shift alliances, start wars. As long as you live, you are a target—visible, vulnerable, and valuable to every enemy we have. They won’t stop until they have you, and they’ll tear this house apart to get to you. There’s no hiding, no bargaining, no running that will save you—or us. “It’s not just that. Even if I wanted to, I can’t keep you safe, Eli.” Vestergaard’s voice was low, tight with grief, his gaze fixed on Eli—unblinking, resolute. “I can’t keep anyone safe—not you, not Siania, not even this house—unless I do the one thing that guarantees your silence forever.” His hand clenched, knuckles white. For a moment, the mask of control slipped and sorrow flickered in his eyes. “You were my friend. I know my mother forced your hand, but you should have come to me.” He drew a slow, ragged breath. “If Siania learns the truth, our marriage falls apart—and then Kren or my own family will kill us both to claim the crown. I wish things were different, Eli. But wishing won’t save us now.” Eli’s voice trembled. “My lord, please—” A silence as heavy as dusk settled between them. Vestergaard’s gaze held Eli’s—sorrowful, yet resolute. Merrow was the greater threat now. As a member of the court delegation, he was protected—cunning—and far more dangerous than Eli had ever been. Eli had been a friend. But Merrow was an outsider with ambition and now leverage—someone who could destroy everything if he chose to speak. Vestergaard’s stomach twisted. To survive, both Eli and Merrow had to be silenced. The thought sickened him—every step drew him closer to the ruthless pragmatism he loathed in his mother. But necessity left no room for sentiment. If he hesitated, he risked losing Siania, his house, and his life. The path was clear—and stained with choices he’d sworn never to make. His blade flashed—swift and final—grief raw in his eyes. As Eli crumpled, Vestergaard caught him, lowering him gently to the floor. He held him until the last breath faded—his voice rough with regret—longing for forgiveness, though unable to ask for it. When he finally spoke, his words were torn from him—raw and unsteady. “Loyalty should not have led us here.” The confession hung in the air—meant for Eli, for Siania, for himself, and a bitter rebuke to his mother, who used others' loyalty for her own ends. “I swore I’d never become my mother,” he whispered, voice breaking. “But today—I prove myself a liar.” <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Chapter 10 Away]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 10 Away</h2>Eli’s body lay still on the floor, the oil lamps casting stark shadows around his crumpled form. Siania turned away from the scene—her breath uneven — Vestergaard stood over his friend, his face torn between grief and resolve—. Eli’s confession had shattered something inside him. —Siania felt a pang for them both. She had been fond of Eli—he’d always greeted her with a warm smile, a ready joke, his kindness a rare comfort amid the harshness of her surroundings. Yet, in the end, it was Eli who had betrayed them—working with Vestergaard’s mother, setting events in motion that endangered Vestergaard, his house, Siania herself, and everyone who depended on them. Sympathy warred with sorrow and disappointment, but her own survival demanded focus. The words she’d overheard clawed at her—Vestergaard’s mention of her mother’s fate struck deeper, tying her to a mother she’d never known—killed by her father’s hand. Siania had always sensed the weight of her heritage, but now she understood the target on her back. By returning from exile, she was being pulled back into court politics—a world she barely understood, with rules she’d never been taught. She had no allies at court, no connections, no leverage to navigate its maze. The court was unpredictable, a labyrinth of ambition where House Vestergaard’s duties, Kren’s schemes, the Order of Severin’s pressure for her marriage, and the Emperor’s will all converged. If she stayed, she’d be a pawn—married off to secure alliances, discarded when her use ran dry, left to face the wolves alone. Here, at least, she understood the dangers. Exile had shaped her—taught her to fight, to survive. The desert was harsh but honest, and her training gave her an edge. At court, she’d be outmaneuvered before she could begin. Here, the threats were clear, and she knew how to navigate them. This was her ground, where her skills mattered. She had to go—now. Fleeing would release Vestergaard from the marriage— , her disappearance giving him the political space to manage his house’s difficult position. She owed him that much, for the unguarded honesty she’d glimpsed in him—a flicker of the man he might be, not the puppet of his mother’s schemes. In that moment, she saw a reflection of her own isolation. They were each alone—caught in webs spun by others. She felt the ache of what could have been—a partnership, complementary and fierce, that might have stood together against the plots encircling them. But Vestergaard’s mother had ensured they’d never had the time to forge that bond—her manipulations keeping them strangers, poised on the edge of trust but never crossing it. She couldn’t linger on what might have been. The Order’s contract would leave Vestergaard no choice—once her absence was discovered, he would be bound to find her, whether he wished to or not. Because of that, she’d need to stay ahead. No one would notice she was gone. Eight hours until the shift change. Siania glided through the passage—silent, her movements precise. She reached her chambers, steps measured. In the faint glow of the hearth, her eyes settled on the book lying on her desk—a quiet emblem of all she was about to lose. The fort had been her world: laughter in the corridors, the ring of blades, the camaraderie of those she’d fought beside. Leaving was more than exile; it meant wrenching herself from the only family she’d ever known. Soon, those same friends—many loyal to her house—would be ordered to hunt her. She lingered, grief and guilt tightening in her chest, knowing this was the last time she would stand in this room as herself. Her gaze lingered on the book—its familiar spine and worn cover a reminder of Vestergaard’s quiet thoughtfulness. She reached out and let her fingers rest lightly on the cover. He had chosen it for her, filled its pages with careful annotations, each line a silent conversation they’d carried on in ink. The book was more than a gift; it was a piece of him, a record of shared laughter and a beginning of understanding. Leaving it behind felt like closing the door on a part of herself she wasn’t ready to lose. Turning away, she moved to her armor, the weight of what lay ahead settling over her. As she tightened the last strap on her light scale armor, the cord around her neck caught on a shoulder buckle. She cursed under her breath, tugging too sharply—and the ring slipped free. It clattered against the stone floor, spinning wildly until it struck the leg of the desk and tipped onto its side. Careless. Stupid. She crouched, fingers trembling as she retrieved it, the familiar weight grounding her. She’d worn it since childhood—her mother’s only legacy, a comfort and a puzzle. Her thumb brushed the sapphire, normally flush and sealed, unyielding even when she’d pried at it as a girl. But tonight, it sat ajar, the filigree stars around it twisted into a new, spiraling pattern. A glint of metal caught the firelight—a fine, shallow engraving beneath the gem. What is this? She brought it closer. The filigree stars no longer formed the symmetrical sigil she’d known all her life. Now they tracked outward in a spiral—each with a distinct form. Not ornamental but purposeful. The first star’s base curved downward, marked by tiered, narrow grooves—an inverted cone she recognized instantly: a qanat entrance, the one set into the base of the southern cliff beneath Fort Kezarak. She’d seen it years ago—half-collapsed, overlooked—but likely still passable if the entrance was clear enough. Her breath caught. The spiral was clockwise—not random. A sequence. A route. Is this… a map? If the qanat was the first point, then the ring wasn’t just marking places—it was laying out a path. A specific direction: northwest, away from the fort, out through the ancient abandoned subterranean aqueduct, a relic from the time before. The sequence continued. She turned the ring, noting the next symbol—jagged, broken lines—a battlefield ridge. Then a coiled design—a stepwell. Another with an arched crest—a ruined temple. And always, at the center, the sapphire—deep blue, pure, still—the oasis. The spacing between them wasn’t even. The gaps widened as the spiral extended outward—suggesting distance. Time. The ring wasn’t just showing her where to go—it was suggesting how far, and in what order. More than that, she realized, each symbol was a landmark she would recognize—a feature she could see with her own eyes as she traveled. The battlefield ridge’s jagged silhouette, the curve of the stepwell, the arch of a ruined temple—each would rise from the desert as a signpost, a visual anchor to keep her on course, even when the world blurred with heat or storm. Interwoven with the spiral’s path, delicate filigree stars formed distinct constellations. The ring was designed to guide her by both land and sky—offering direction whether the sun was high or the night was dark. She had been ready to vanish into the dark with no destination—to take her chances and just adapt. But now—now she had orientation, a plan. The qanat was her exit, and from there the ring laid out a journey—etched in metal and stone, each symbol a beacon to guide her steps across the shifting sands. The oasis was real. It had to be. And if it lay at the spiral’s heart, it was more than refuge—it was the goal. The storm outside had begun to churn, the winds picking up, the sands shifting—already erasing the familiar paths. She felt the tension in her chest, the looming threat of getting lost in a desert that could swallow her whole. The storm would distort any sense of direction. But now, underground, with the qanat as her first point, she would be shielded from the chaos above. It couldn’t be redirected by a sandstorm—she couldn’t lose her way. Lucky the path starts belowground, she thought. The storm can turn the world sideways and it still won’t matter—the map is fixed. Set in metal. Unshifting. She turned the ring in her fingers. Why now? The sapphire flickered, a thin pulse of blue light arcing along the spiral, star to star, as if tracing the path in response to her attention. When her skin brushed the metal, it warmed—not from firelight, but from within. A pull in her chest, a low harmonic hum in her bones, the scent of roses and comfort—as if the ring had found its match in her. It had been made to wait—not for any bearer, but for her, today. Only house Ne’Tiriania had worn it, passed from mother to daughter an unbroken magical line, narrowed now to a single living heir. The ring responded to their blood, sealed until it recognized its match. It wasn’t just a comfort—it was a message, a guide, her mother’s final gift, waiting for the moment it was needed. She snapped the clasp shut, tucked the ring beneath her tunic, and straightened. Beneath her desk, she pulled a worn map, its desert paths faint but usable. She shouldered her soldier’s kit—rations, waterskin, sword, desert cloak—the weight steadying her. Moving quickly, she tipped a chair and scattered personal items near the window, staging a struggle to buy time and divert efforts. Her reflection in the mirror held her gaze briefly—sharp features, eyes forged by survival. No one knew she was leaving—not yet. Her flight would shatter her father’s alliances and Vestergaard’s plans, but that storm was hours away. The way was uncertain, a gamble, but it was her only shot. She pried open a hidden grate at the chamber’s rear, slipping into the darkness. The desert waited beyond—vast, unforgiving, her only refuge. She slipped into the passage, her steps silent, the ring’s hum a steady pulse against her chest. “If they wanted a fight, they would have to bring it to her. She might have lost this round, but the war was far from over.” <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Chapter 11 Escape from Kezerak]]</span>(set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 11 Escape from Kezerak</h2>Siannia pressed against the southwestern wall of Fort Kezerak, its jagged stone biting into her back. The sandstorm’s roar swallowed her ragged breaths, wind clawing at her cloak. She pulled it tight, shrinking her silhouette against the chaos. The ring on her finger flared warm and light, its etched symbols—qanat, battlefield, stepwell, temple—protected in her palm. Somewhere ahead, veiled by swirling grit and shadow, was the entrance to the qanat—an underground tunnel. Her only way out, if she could reach it. Each step was a gamble. The desert shifted underfoot, sand sliding over hidden air pockets. She hugged the wall, its rough surface her only anchor in the storm’s fury. The ramparts above flickered with movement—guards or drifting sand? She didn’t look up. Fear pressed at the edges of her mind, the doubts, uncertainties…., but she let her training take over, steadying her breath and narrowing her focus. Stay calm. Move. The outcropping loomed—a dark silhouette in the storm’s haze. It was her landmark, her entry to the qanat. She edged forward, testing each step. The wind shoved her sideways; her boots sank into loose sand. To her left, a shallow depression yawned. If she crossed it, the desert might swallow her whole. If she skirted it, the guards might spot her. There was no time to falter. She chose the edge, each step a quiet defiance of the sand’s treachery, her eyes locked on the outcropping’s jagged promise. The storm was both ally and enemy—hiding her from watchful eyes, yet threatening to betray her to the desert’s traps. Still, she pressed on, gaze fixed on her goal. Its harsh form pulled her closer, step by cautious step. Her mothers ring warmed faintly, as if sensing the entrance. She was close. The ground felt softer now, less certain. She scanned for the tunnel's hidden entrance, squinting through the stinging grit. One wrong move could end it all. Her boot sank. The sand hissed, giving way beneath her. Siannia’s heart lurched as the ground turned liquid, sucking her down. Ankles vanished into the cold, flowing grains, then calves—the flow relentless. A sharp, mineral scent hit her: ancient, dry, as if the desert exhaled centuries of secrets. She lunged forward, fingers clawing at a wiry shrub on the sinkhole’s edge. Its roots trembled, thin and frail, barely clinging to the rim. The sand reached her waist. Time slowed. The storm’s howl faded to a distant hum, overtaken by the strange, hollow hiss of sand filled with air. This was nothing like packed earth—this sand was loose, almost bubbling, as if she were sinking into a pit of dry foam. Every movement sent air pockets whispering and popping beneath the surface, the grains shifting with a faint, effervescent crackle. The sand was highly aerated, collapsing in on itself with every subtle shift. Her heartbeat thundered, frantic in her ears. The sand didn’t squeeze her; it yielded instantly, collapsing inward wherever she pressed. The aerated grains slipped and slid, always finding new gaps to fill, but never giving purchase. She could feel it seeping into every crevice—under her armor, boots, ears, grinding against her skin, the sensation oddly light yet inescapably downward. She kicked, searching for solid ground, but the sand only shifted, pulling her deeper. Her mind screamed—trapped, buried, gone—but she forced it silent. Panic was the enemy. She clawed at the shrub, its brittle stems cutting her palms. It bent, then snapped, roots tearing free with a sickening crack. She slid further, sand flooding over her chest, pressing against her collarbone. The grains stung her neck, her jaw, cheek, as if tasting her. The world above dimmed, the storm’s chaos reduced to a faint, mocking whisper. Her feet struck something solid—a brittle crust beneath the sand. Hope flickered, then died. If it held, she’d be entombed. Panic surged, raw and electric. The nearness of her goal burned in her mind—so close. Anger surged, fierce and bright. She kicked harder, heels pounding the layer. She would not die here. Not now. It cracked—a sharp, hollow snap echoing in the dark. She drove her weight downward, desperate, as the crust shattered. The sand roared, a deafening torrent, dragging her through the breach in a choking cascade. Grains battered her face; she squeezed her eyes shut and threw an arm across them, instinctively shielding her mouth and nose as best she could. She twisted, gasping, her free hand flailing for anything. A relentless current of cold, shifting sand drove downwards. The desert swallowed her whole Falling she hit the ground hard, pain flaring through her shoulder and hip. For a long moment, she just lay there, stunned, the world distant and muffled, as if she were underwater. The storm raged somewhere above, but it barely registered. Her heart thundered in her chest, a wild, uneven rhythm. She couldn’t move, couldn’t think—only breathe, each inhale raw and shallow, her lungs burning. Time blurred. For a few moments, she was aware of nothing but the dull ache in her shoulder and hip, the gritty taste of sand in her mouth. The world sharpened in fragments: it was quiet now, the chaos above replaced by the hush of the chamber. cool heavy air, the rough stone beneath her palms. She was alive. Somehow. Gradually, her senses returned. She lay in a low chamber, nearly filled with sand, the walls pressing close. The arched ceiling hovered just above her head, leaving no room to sit up. For a moment, she stayed still, listening to the silence and feeling the weight of earth above and below. At last, she forced herself to be alert, every muscle trembling. She wiped her mouth with the back of her hand, blinking away dust. A faint glow flickered in the far corner—a narrow gap. The ring on her finger pulsed steadily, guiding her. Trusting it, she began to crawl forward, pushing through the sand toward the light. The gap widened just enough. On her stomach, she wriggled through, tumbling as the high-piled sand cascaded her down into a broader tunnel. The air was cooler and cleaner here, carrying the scent of dry stone. The qanat. She was alive and had made it. Siannia rose, brushing grit from her face, steadying her raw trembling hands. The sand storm raged above, but it's howl was distant now. No alarms, no shouts—her fall had gone unseen, her tracks would be erased and the qanat’s entrance would soon be buried under debris. The fort’s isolation was her shield. Patrols wouldn’t brave this treacherous ground, She had several hours before anyone would notice her absence—, she estimated—until her attendants arrived in the morning around 6 bells to wake her up. The tunnel sloped gently downward, its close-set walls etched with the grooves and chisel marks left by ancient hands. Flickering shafts of light from luminaria above cast storm-shadowed patterns across the tool-scored stone. Siannia’s sword brushed against the wall, the faint metallic ring echoing back—clear and undisturbed, a sign that the passage remained open and unblocked. Each step reassured her: the way ahead was unbroken. There was only one path forward, and she would not lose herself in these depths. Tightening her grip on her sword, she pressed on. The ring’s symbol shifted, now pointing toward the battlefield ridge, guiding Siannia through the vast qanat beneath the earth. The cool stone promised shelter from the raging storm above and concealment from the fort’s patrols—at least until she was too far away for them to matter. The ring’s map would lead her to an oasis. She planned to move swiftly, knowing she had perhaps eight bells before her absence was discovered. After that, she would spend another three crossing open ground before finding a place to hide from the desert’s midday heat. When stealth was needed, she would make shelter, waiting out the worst of the sun. By nightfall, she would navigate by the stars, aiming for the ridge—her next waypoint. Above, the storm would soon erase all trace of her passage, keeping her entry into the qanat a secret. The fort’s isolation meant no coordinated pursuit by the Crimson Marshals would come for many weeks. Still, the thought of Severin’s enforcers made her shiver. Her unit would be duty-bound to hunt her. If they failed to find her, suspicion would fall on them. The knowledge that her escape could bring them suffering weighed heavily on her. Yet her burden was greater than fear for herself or her comrades. If the family set to marry her seized power, their cruelty would endanger everyone. Their rule combined with the order of Severin, would be far worse for the realm. That knowledge pressed on her with every step. She had about eight bells before her disappearance was noticed. The darkness ahead called to her. Now was the moment to make the most of her head start—before the hunt began. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Chapter 12: Night’s Cover]]</span>(set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 12: Night’s Cover</h2>With a groan muffled against her cloak, she pushed herself up. Every muscle protested. For the past several days, she had been moving ever deeper into the desert, repeating the same pattern: crafting a scrapped bed to form a barrier against the sun, draping her cloak over shrubs to create shelter. By late afternoon, she would cook over a low fire, extinguishing it before evening, when its embers might be visible. Then, as dusk fell, she would pack up and start moving again. She reached for the cloak, its coarse weave gritty under her fingers, heavy with a day’s worth of sand and heat. Methodically, she shook it out, watching the fine grains cascade like pale water in the fading light. Her hands, raw from her frantic clawing in the sinkhole, trembled slightly as she ran them over the familiar fabric. She flipped it over. The black side felt cooler, almost slick, absorbing the deepening shadows as she wrapped it around herself and pulled the deep hood low over her face. Concealment. Protection. The promise of night’s cover. She checked the ring. The etched symbols seemed sharper in the twilight, the arrow towards the battlefield ridge unwavering. Overhead, the first brave stars pricked the violet sky—the Scorpion’s Tail, the Steadfast Sisters, old friends for navigation. She triangulated her position against the ring’s guidance and the celestial map, plotting the night’s path: north, always north, skirting the treacherous soft sand near the dry riverbed she’d glimpsed before sheltering. The ridge was her lifeline, promising the oasis—and perhaps, answers about her mother’s ring and the path ahead. The ring’s warmth—the faint thrum against her skin—was a fragile ember of hope in the gathering dark. Guide me. Help me stay ahead. The thought was a silent prayer as she rose, brushing stubborn grit from her trousers and stretching stiff limbs. The desert stretched before her, vast and hushed under the weight of dusk, save for the restless whisper of wind over stone and the occasional skitter of a night creature. She paused, head tilted, straining her senses. No hoofbeats. No shouts. Only the desert’s own breath. For now. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Chapter 13 The Chase Begins: Signs and Shadows]]</span>(set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 13 The Chase Begins: Signs and Shadows</h2>The moon, a pale sliver, cast the world in shades of silver and ink. Siannia moved like one of the desert’s own creatures—silent, deliberate, exploiting every contour of the land. Her boots found the hardest earth, avoiding patches of silt that would hold her prints like accusations. She hugged the lee of rock formations, a shadow among shadows, her dark cloak merging with the night. The wind, now blowing steadily from the south, was her ally, scouring the sand behind her, erasing the faint traces she couldn’t avoid. Her mind worked as hard as her legs, engaged in active anti-tracking. She spotted a trail of jackrabbit tracks weaving away from the cracked bed of a long-dead river. Without hesitation, she stepped into the deeper prints, letting the desert’s own inhabitants mask her passage. In a patch of softer sand near a cluster of sage, she deliberately veered east for twenty paces, leaving clear tracks, before carefully backtracking onto sun-baked stone and resuming her true northern course. A misdirection only a tracker of Vestergaard’s caliber might notice—and pause to question. But her strategy went deeper than footprints. Near a weathered outcrop that hinted at a possible water source below, she knelt. Her fingers, still tender, found tough stalks of desert grass. With deliberate care, she wove them into a specific knot—the same clumsy, earnest knot Vestergaard had taught her during an early chaperoned meeting, fumbling with a blade of grass to break an uncomfortable silence. She tucked it into a crevice on the leeward side. Farther on, on a flat stone smoothed by ancient winds, she used a sharp rock to scratch a spiral—echoing the pattern he’d drawn in the dust during a formal dinner, his finger brushing hers as he explained it symbolized enduring hope. Each sign was a silent plea, a barb of memory: I remember. I regret. I endure. She hoped they would whisper doubt into his certainty, slow his relentless pursuit. Make him question why he chases me. Duty? Or something more? She rationed her water, the metallic taste sharp on her tongue. Hunger gnawed, a persistent distraction she pushed aside—there would be time later in the morning for her sling. Speed and stealth warred within her. She needed distance, but haste could betray her. She navigated by the stars, their cold light her compass, the ring’s steady warmth her confirmation. The dunes rose before her, great waves of shadowed sand. Here, she knew, the wind would be her greatest ally, smoothing her passage within minutes. She crested a low ridge, keeping her profile low against the skyline. Below stretched an open expanse of hardpan, shimmering faintly under the moon. And there, behind her on the horizon—movement. A solitary figure, distant but unmistakable in its purposeful stride. Tall, broad-shouldered, the lines of a cloak and the hint of a scabbard catching the moonlight. Closer than she’d feared. Much closer. Vestergaard. Her breath hitched. Even at this distance, the silhouette was ingrained in her memory—the set of his shoulders, the way he moved with predatory grace even across treacherous ground. He paused, head turning slowly, scanning the terrain, a hunter reading the whispers of the land. Her heart hammered against her ribs, a frantic counterpoint to the desert’s stillness. He was gaining. Soon, he’d be close enough to call out, to try to reason, to demand. She could not allow that. Not yet. Words were weapons he wielded as deftly as his sword, and she wasn’t ready to parry them. She had wanted time to work on her strategy, to get enough distance, to gain time that she would need... a gamble... Her gaze snapped to the left. The mouth of a canyon yawned, a deeper blackness cutting into the moonlit plain—a labyrinth of tumbled boulders, narrow clefts, and knife-edged shadows. The land itself offered her a shield. Without a second glance at the figure drawing inexorably closer, Siannia slipped off the ridge, melting into the deeper gloom at its base. She angled towards the canyon’s entrance, every nerve alight, the sand whispering beneath her boots. The cool, mineral scent of rock dust replaced the dry sage as she reached the threshold. She paused for only a heartbeat, listening. A distant sound carried on the wind, faint but clear: her name. “Siannia!” His voice, taut with urgency and something else—frustration? Desperation? She didn’t answer. Instead, she plunged into the canyon’s waiting shadows, letting the jagged teeth of stone swallow her whole. The hunt had truly begun, and the battlefield had shifted to the land’s own harsh embrace. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Chapter 14 Confrontation in Diplomatic Residence, Fort Kethian]]</span>(set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <h2>Chapter 14 Confrontation in Diplomatic Residence, Fort Kethian</h2>A liveried attendant’s voice cut through the heavy air of Lady Elara Vestergaard’s suite: “Presenting Adjudicators Soren Halvane, charged with justice and stewardship, and Valeria Sorn, guardian of property and oath.” Two figures in the severe black robes of Severin’s Order stepped inside. The attendant held the carved doors ajar, his expression unreadable. The Adjudicators’ cold eyes swept the opulent room—rich tapestries, gleaming silver, arched windows framing the bustling courtyard—before they advanced with silent, commanding grace. The attendant lingered, a mute witness to the rising tension. Elara turned from the window, her regal composure masking the storm beneath. She had sent her son to find Princess Siania, but he had not returned. Now, his scribe was found dead—in her son’s own chambers—and the contract binding the Order to her House—a private, seditious pact—had vanished. House Vestergaard stood exposed, vulnerable. He’s fond of her—too fond. That much was certain. But the scribe’s death—that spoke of ruthlessness. Had her son finally learned her lessons too well? Alarm prickled through her. The scribe had been working with her on that secret contract—one that, if discovered, would be a prize for any rival house. Had someone uncovered its existence? Had they come to steal it? Perhaps the scribe had been killed during the theft, or worse, tortured for information before the contract was taken. Or perhaps her son had taken it himself—a bargaining chip against her control. The possibilities twisted through her mind, each more dangerous than the last. She did not know who was behind it. Any of the great houses would have motive. Any would risk everything for leverage like this. The scribe’s death was a warning—and a threat. Elara’s ignorance of the details only deepened her alarm. For a fleeting moment, suspicion flickered toward her son. His absence was required, yet now he had disappeared—sent after the princess when she was discovered missing, the scribe silenced, the contract gone. Could he have orchestrated this? But she dismissed it almost instantly. He was no murderer; she knew that as surely as she knew her own ambition. Besides, he had no friends—she had made certain of that. He wouldn’t dare challenge her directly. Not yet. She, on the other hand, had always prided herself on her ability to do what was necessary—Machiavellian, some whispered, though never to her face. But her son? He was not cut from the same cloth. He lacked the cold pragmatism that survival here demanded. If anything, his innocence was a danger in itself. His affection for the princess made him predictable, not treacherous. No, the scribe’s death was not his doing. The threat came from elsewhere, from someone who understood the true rules of power in this place—she would need to deploy her spies and find the source. And now, the Adjudicators had arrived. The very agents of the Order with whom she had forged her secret pact. Their sudden presence in her chambers was a silent thunderclap. Did they know the contract was missing? Had word of the scribe’s death reached them? Did they suspect that other houses might have learned of the pact? Or did they suspect her son—or worse, her? Or were they here for something else entirely? She kept her face serene, every muscle schooled to stillness, but her mind raced. If they suspected her, would they confront her here, in her own chambers? Or would they simply watch, waiting for her to betray herself? She met their gaze, offering the faintest of nods—a gesture of respect, and nothing more. The Adjudicators gave nothing away. Their eyes, cold and implacable, seemed to strip the room of its opulence, leaving only the bare bones of power and threat. Elara could almost feel the weight of the vanished contract pressing against her chest. If the Order turned against her now, House Vestergaard would not survive the scandal. She must not falter. Not now, with everything at stake. Every possibility was perilous. If the Adjudicators knew the truth, her house could be ruined. If they suspected nothing, a single misstep could betray her. Elara forced herself to meet their cold, unreadable eyes, her mind racing to anticipate their questions, her heart pounding with dread. She drew a steadying breath, her voice calm when she finally spoke. “To what do I owe the honor of your visit?” The words were smooth, practiced. But beneath them, her thoughts churned: What do they know? And how much time do I have left to regain control? Soren Halvane’s lips barely moved. “Lady Vestergaard, we require an update on your son’s search for Princess Siania.” His gaze lingered, unblinking. “And we must address the death of his scribe, found in his chambers.” A chill ran through her. They know. Or do they? “A troubling matter,” she replied, careful to keep her tone even. “When the princess vanished, I sent my son to find her. He has not returned. As for the scribe, I am investigating. I have deployed every resource to locate both the princess and my son—and to uncover the truth behind the scribe’s death.” She could not let them see her fear. The contract’s loss, the scribe’s murder—both could be her undoing if the Order connected the dots. Halvane’s jaw tightened. “We can send reinforcements from the capital. Investigators and trackers. But they will not arrive for a month. Until then, we expect your full cooperation.” His gaze sharpened. “The scribe’s death casts a shadow over your house, Lady Vestergaard.” A shadow, yes—a noose tightening. “I assure you, Adjudicator, I will resolve this before your reinforcements arrive. My son’s loyalty is unquestioned—his devotion to Siania is known. If he has not returned, it is because he is delayed or detained, not because he has betrayed his duty.” She almost believed it. Almost. She could not allow them to take control. Their ‘aid’ would be a leash, and she would be the hound. Valeria Sorn’s voice was soft, but each word struck like a hammer. “If Princess Siania is found, and your son is not, the Order will require a substitute from your house to marry the princess. The alliance must proceed.” Elara’s features hardened. Outrage flared, but she forced it down. A substitute? They would see my son dead, the contract voided, my house broken. “My son is the designated party,” she said, voice icy. “The contract bears his name and mine. A substitute is unacceptable.” She could not let them profit from her misfortune. If they sensed weakness, they would press until she broke. Halvane’s eyes narrowed. “The Order prioritizes stability. If your son cannot be produced, we act in the realm’s best interest.” Valeria added, “A substitute ensures the alliance’s continuity, regardless of your son’s fate.” Elara’s tone sharpened, deliberate. “The contract is clear, Adjudicators. Until my son is found, any deviation is premature. His affection for Siania suggests he acts to secure her, not to undermine the alliance.” She saw their game. They wanted her to accept a substitute—to make her son’s death convenient. That would never happen. The Adjudicators exchanged a glance, then nodded stiffly. “For now, Lady Vestergaard,” Soren said coldly. “But our patience is finite. Delays will bring consequences.” The threat hung heavy, a silent blade at her throat. Elara’s resolve hardened beneath her calm exterior.
