The joke hung in the air, Kaelith’s exasperation and Siania’s weary amusement mingling with the sunlight and dust. For a moment, it almost felt like any other day—just three misfits bickering in the aftermath of trouble. But the laughter faded quickly, chased away by the cold weight in Aryfis’s palm. As the last echoes of laughter faded, Aryfis’s fingers tightened around the heart stone. The chill of it seeped into his bones, a reminder that not all treasures were meant to be kept—or carried alone. He squeezed the Heart stone, feeling its cold weight, and for once, the voice’s icy imperative only steeled his resolve. He let out a long breath, tail curling in relief. Under his breath, he muttered, “Great. Hero again. That’s three times now... threeeeeee times... You start doing it regularly, you start to care, then it’s all about heartbreak. I’m starting to worry about myself.” He shot a sideways glance at Siania, then Kaelith, as if daring them to comment. “This is getting out of hand. I’m supposed to be an imp, not—” He cut himself off, scowling, then straightened, trying to look nonchalant but failing utterly. He glanced down at the heartstone in his palm. For a heartbeat, he hesitated—just long enough for the old hunger to whisper: You could keep it. Slip it away. No one would know. It’s yours by right of daring, by right of need. His fingers curled around the gem, and for a moment, he almost did it—almost tucked it into his pocket, almost let the weight of centuries of habit win. But then he looked up, saw Siania’s exhausted, hopeful face, and Kaelith’s wary, battered grin. The urge faded, replaced by something stubborn and bright. With a sigh—half longing, half relief—he forced his fingers to unclench. He cleared his throat, and with a flourish that was just a little too eager, presented the heartstone to Siania. “For you, my lady. A little something from the depths of doom. Don’t say I never bring you nice things.” He tried for a roguish wink, but it came out more sheepish than suave. Siania, still catching her breath, took the heartstone, her fingers lingering on it. She looked at Aryfis for a long moment—considering, yet thankful, a grateful but tired smile forming. “Thank you, Aryfis. That was… actually heroic.” For a moment, the three stood in the hush that follows disaster—dust settling, sunlight slanting through the broken stone, the weight of what almost was hanging in the air. Only the distant clatter of falling rubble broke the silence, and then, with a weary exhale, the world began to move again. Kaelith staggered out behind them, brushing sand and dust from his coat, looking thoroughly harassed. He upended a boot and a cascade of coins, pebbles, and what might be a skeletal finger clattered to the ground. “Great. Haunted coins. My favourite.” He shook his boot again, frowning at the debris. “...Is that a tooth? Wonderful.” For a heartbeat, Kaelith’s glare could have cut glass. Aryfis just grinned wider, dusting off his coat with exaggerated care. The coin between them glinted in the dirt. Aryfis’s fingers twitched. Kaelith’s boot shifted, just enough to cover the prize. Aryfis grinned, tail flicking. “You’re welcome! I cleared the way, saved the day, and got the princess her prize. Not bad for a sidekick, eh?” Kaelith gave him a flat look. “Sidekick? You almost got us killed. Ah-gaaaain.” For a heartbeat, the tension hung between them—Kaelith’s glare sharp, Aryfis’s grin undimmed. Dust still settled around their boots. Aryfis puffed up, grinning wide. “But I diiiiiiidn’t. And who got the heartstone, hmm? Not you, Captain Sand-in-your-pockets.” Kaelith snorted, flicking a coin out of his boot. “You’re insufferable.” Aryfis winked. “And you love it.” Kaelith: “Debatable.” Aryfis: “Admit it. I’m your favourite.” Kaelith, deadpan, just arched an eyebrow. “You’re lucky I don’t throw you back in.” Aryfis, tail swishing: “Promises, promises.” The conversation lulls as the imps eyes met over the coin—just for a heartbeat, silent calculation passing between them. After all the chaos, it was the only piece of treasure to make it out of the Grave Hoard apart from the heartstone, and both of them knew it. Aryfis’s fingers twitched, but Kaelith’s boot stayed firmly planted, staking his claim with a silent glare. For a moment, neither said a word; the air was thick with the unspoken question—Can I have it?—but it was far too soon, and far too wicked, for either of them to break the fragile truce. Kaelith’s weight settled, pinning the coin with practiced indifference. For two such as they—a pirate and an imp—leaving a grave horde with no treasure was an unacceptable tragedy. Aryfis looked away first, feigning indifference, though his tail betrayed him with a single, longing flick. For just a heartbeat, the tiniest prick of conscience nudged at him—after all, it was his greed that had brought down an entire horde of undead on them—but he shoved the thought aside before it could settle. Instead, he pulled a face, crossing his eyes and sticking out his tongue in Kaelith’s direction, then sidled over to Siania with an exaggerated tiptoe. Aryfis leaned in, stage-whispering to Siania. “He’s just jealous because I’m the favourite now.” Siania laughed, shaking her head. “You’re both impossible. But thank you, Aryfis. Truly.” Aryfis beamed, basking in the attention. “Anytime, princess. Just don’t ask me to do it again. My nerves are delicate. I’m an artiste, not to be used without discernment.” He wiggled his little devilish behind in mockery. Kaelith gave a long-suffering sigh, but there was a reluctant smile as he shouldered his pack. “Let’s go, before something else decides we look like lunch.” “Lead the way, oh fearless imp.” Aryfis bowed with a flourish, skipping ahead. “Try to keep up, Captain.....” As they set off, Aryfis hummed a cheerfully bawdy dockyard ditty, his tail swaying in time. “First order of business: no coconuts in the bakery. Or haunted cutlery. Or Kaelith’s hair in the pastries. Just rubies—yes, yes, sparkling, sparkling rubies...” His voice drifted back between snatches of a bawdy sailor’s song—because, after all, he was an imp and the devil, and subtlety was for saints. Every few lines, he broke off, unable to resist adding to his ever-expanding plans: “...sapphire swirl cakes, emerald moon buns, souls on the side—no, wait, rubies, rubies in the tarts, yes, and maybe a diamond-dusted dream loaf... cherry cloud-turnovers with opal glaze... rubies, rubies, sparkling, sparkling rubies... and a soul bun for breakfast...” “—and the bosun’s wife said—no, wait, rubies, rubies in the tarts, yes, sparkling, sparkling rubies— His humming faded into the distance, the list growing ever more improbable and gleeful. Kaelith called after him, deadpan, “You’d eat all the profits. Do you even know what a bakery is?” Aryfis just grinned wider, undeterred. “Course I do! It’s where you keep the rubies.” For a moment, the three of them walked in companionable silence, the weight of the Heart stone and their mission before them and the memory of the tomb lingering, but softened by the absurdity of Aryfis’s plans and the warmth of the setting sun. Kaelith gave Aryfis a nod, just a shade more sincere than usual. “…Not bad, imp. Didn’t think you had it in you.” Aryfis blinked, caught off guard. For a heartbeat, he almost didn’t know what to do with the warmth that flickered in his chest—praise was rarer than rubies for an imp, and it left him oddly breathless. His tail gave an uncertain twitch. He grinned, a little too wide, and quickly hid behind bravado. “Surprises all around, Captain.” Kaelith just shook his head, but there was a glint of reluctant respect. “Don’t let it go to your head. You’re still not getting a cut of my loot.” Aryfis winked, recovering his swagger. “Wouldn’t dream of it. I’m in it for the glory.” Siania, catching the exchange, shook her head, smiling at both of them. As they walked on, Aryfis let the others move a step ahead, his grin lingering. For the first time in centuries, he felt something warm and bright unfurling inside him—a happiness so unfamiliar it almost hurt. He pressed a hand to his chest, as if to make sure it was real, then hurried to catch up, already spinning another joke to hide the way his heart was pounding. The sun dipped lower, painting the world in apricot and gold. For a fleeting moment, Aryfis let himself believe in the promise of the horizon—until the shadows lengthened, and something colder than dusk brushed against his thoughts. But just as the warmth began to settle, a chill coiled through his mind—cold, oily, unmistakable. Aryfis shivered violently, stumbling a step as if the world had tilted beneath him, the echo of Azaroth’s presence crawling down his spine. Azaroth’s voice slid into his thoughts, merciless and absolute Traitor. The word landed like a brand, searing and cold at once. You think you can run from what you are? You think they’ll save you? You belong to me. You always will. Aryfis’s breath caught. Azaroth’s will left a bitter, oily residue in his mind, clinging to every thought. He recoiled from it, the echo of that presence crawling cold down his spine. For a moment, the world dulled, the promise of the horizon just out of reach. He forced a laugh, louder than before, and darted after his friends, as if he could outrun the shadow curling in his wake. Don’t leave me behind! He lingered at the edge of the road, Azaroth’s words gnawing at his resolve. If he went with them, would he only bring more danger? Would he be tempted to betray them again, or would his presence doom them all? Was it safer for everyone if he left now, disappeared into the dusk, and let them go on without him? Or would they accept him, protect him, even knowing what he was? The uncertainty pressed in, heavy and cold. He mumbled to himself, barely audible, “Start caring, and it’s nothing but heartbreak.” The words tasted bitter. Maybe that was the real danger. Maybe caring was the one thing he couldn’t survive. But the sound of Siania’s laughter and Kaelith’s grumbling tugged him forward, step by stubborn step, until the warmth of their presence pulled him back into the fading light. The apricot light of dusk crept in as they headed farther out, making their way toward the coast, the promise of the horizon waiting just beyond their reach. [[Chapter 35 The Road to the Sea]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 35 The Road to the Sea</h2> The desert wind scours their skin, carrying the scent of sun-baked stone and distant salt. Siania leads, boots sinking into shifting sand, the Heart stone’s weight a silent throb at her side. The gem—a large, faceted yellow rectangle on a silver chain, marked with her house’s symbol—rests against her chest. She doesn’t know what it is, only that it’s beautiful, mysterious, and somehow comforting, as if it hums a wordless promise of safety. For a moment, Siania hesitates, then, with a small, understanding smile, she unclasps the chain and holds the Heartstone out to him. Aryfis’s eyes go even wider, and he takes the gem with a reverence rare for him, cradling it in his palms. The moment it touches his skin, his usual fidgeting stills. He draws in a sharp breath, eyes going distant, as if listening to something only he can hear. as if the stone recognizes a kindred wound. A hush settles over the group. Aryfis stands very still, the Heartstone’s golden facets catching the desert light. For an imp, comfort is a rare and precious thing, and now a deep, aching nostalgia flickers across his face—homesickness for something he’s never known, or perhaps for a place he’s long forgotten. The magic of the stone hums through him, warm and powerful, and for a heartbeat he looks both comforted and overwhelmed. He blinks, a little dazed, and then, with surprising gentleness, offers the Heartstone back to Siania. “It belongs to you,” he says softly, almost apologetic. “It… it told me so. Said it had a nice visit, but wants to go back to you now.” He manages a crooked smile, still a little awed, and adds, “Shiny things always know where they’re meant to be.” Kaelith raises an eyebrow, grinning. “A visit, huh? Didn’t know gems took holidays—unless they’re staying at your resort, Aryfis.” Aryfis snickers, unoffended. “Of course they do! You think only people go wandering? Shiny things like to see the world too. Sometimes they stay, sometimes they just pop in for a chat and a nap, see the sights, then off they go. This one’s just polite about it.” He pats his chest with mock pride, then leans in, lowering his voice conspiratorially. “My place is very popular, you know. Five stars—” He grins, baring his sharp teeth, and theatrically taps his own teeth with a fingernail. “—if you count the ones I’ve swallowed.” Kaelith snorts, shaking his head. “You can keep your five-star treasures, imp. I’m definitely in it for the glory, not the gold.” He flashes a crooked grin at Siania, as if daring her to disagree. Aryfis cackles, unrepentant. “Suit yourself. More for me. Besides, shiny things always find their way home—one way or another.” Siania can’t help but smile, the image of the Heart stone packing a tiny bag and setting off on adventures flickering in her mind. “Well, I’m glad it enjoyed its stay,” she says, slipping the chain back over her head. Aryfis nods, satisfied. “Best sort of guest, really. Leaves you feeling better than when it arrived.” For a moment, the two share a quiet understanding, the Heart stone warm against Siania’s chest. The desert stretches on, vast and shimmering, each step measured and silent. For a while, Siania’s mind drifts with the heat, the world narrowed to the rhythm of her breath. Gradually, the hush is broken—voices rising behind her, laughter and the familiar cadence of argument threading through the wind, drawing her attention back to the present. “No, it’s definitely rough-cut pork belly with gravy. That’s the first thing I’m getting in port—crunchy, spicy, perfect.” He licks his cracked lips, as if conjuring the taste. He glances at Siania, hoping for a smile, but she’s intent on the path ahead. Aryfis, ever the contrarian imp, snorts and falls into step beside Kaelith, exaggerating his stride just enough to mimic the pirate’s swagger. He throws his shoulders back, chin high, and nearly trips over a half-buried stone. “You said that yesterday. I want a pie. A real one, with meat, not sand.” He pats his stomach with a theatrical sigh, then shoots Siania a hopeful look, as if she might conjure a pie from thin air. Kaelith catches the imitation and, instead of being annoyed, grins wider. He bumps Aryfis lightly with his elbow, as if to test whether the imp will keep up the act. “Ha!, I’m not sure you’d know good food if it bit you.” He pauses, eyeing Aryfis’s theatrically long stride. “Come to think of it, yours probably does.” He glances at Siania again, this time with a crooked smile. “Siania, back me up—tell the imp what real food is. You must have had feasts in those fancy halls of yours.” Siania, caught off guard, blinks and then shrugs, a small smile tugging at her lips. “Feasts? Only if you were quick enough to steal a bite before someone else did. Most days, you ate what you could get, and you didn’t ask where it came from.” She glances at Kaelith, then at Aryfis, her eyes tired but sharp. “If you ever had something truly delicious, it meant you’d outsmarted someone. Or outrun them.” Siania’s smile lingers, eyes twinkling knowingly that both of her travel companions also know this well for themselves. Aryfis grins, clearly approving. “That’s the best kind! Food that tastes like victory.” Kaelith’s laughter falters, surprise flickering across his face. He studies Siania as if seeing her for the first time, the easy assumptions about royalty slipping away. “Huh. And here I thought you grew up on silver platters and honeyed cakes.” He tries to make it a joke, but there’s a new note of respect in his voice. Siania’s smile widens, just a little, a glint of mischief in her eyes. “Only if you could steal them from the kitchens. And the cooks were meaner than any pirate.” Kaelith lets out a low whistle, shaking his head. “Remind me never to leave my rations unguarded around you two.” Siania’s smile widens, just a little. “You’d be wise not to.” Aryfis cackles, delighted. “Too late! I already checked your pack.” Aryfis, not missing a beat, snaps his teeth playfully at the air, then winks at Siania, who rolls her eyes but can’t quite hide her smile. Kaelith laughs, the sound bright and genuine, echoing oddly off the dunes. Their conversation drifts, each new dish more outlandish than the last—pickled eel, candied cactus, a roast boar “the size of a wagon.” By midday, they’re inventing entire feasts, their stomachs rumbling in protest, Aryfis clutching his belly and groaning dramatically with every new suggestion. The day ends on a half-full stomach, the group hunched around a meager fire. Desert hare, tough and stringy, chars on a spit. Aryfis sniffs a strip of dried fruit Siania offers, nose wrinkling in exaggerated disgust, but he snatches it anyway, eyes glinting with secret pleasure at being included. Kaelith, with a theatrical sigh, gnaws on a bone, then holds it up to the firelight. “Great, more sand,” he laments. “You know, as a pirate, you never get sand in your food—unless you’re at the bottom of the sea.” He shrugs, grinning. “Then supper’s the least of your worries.” His stomach growls, loud and plaintive, as if to agree. He keeps gnawing, lost in thoughts of another time but happy for the camaraderie of the present. Aryfis, licking his fingers, pipes up, “He’s right, you know. Never sand in my food—never, never, never. But mostly because there’s never food! And when there is, it’s squirmy, squeaky, or smells like old boots. Rats wouldn’t touch it—sometimes rats were the food. Waste not!” He grins, sharp-toothed and unrepentant. Kaelith snorts, tossing a pebble at Aryfis’s boots. “You’d eat anything—like those rings in the Gravehorde, remember?” Aryfis cackles. “At least then we’d have treasure. Shiny, shiny, shiny!” Kaelith shakes his head, smirking. “That treasure’s all yours, my friend. All yours. Just remember—I’m not sharing my gold with you, and I don’t want any of yours. But really,” he adds, with a flourish, “just for the glory, not the gold.” Laughter ripples through the group, mingling with the crackle of the fire and the endless hush of the desert night. Later, the dunes glow silver beneath a sky thick with stars. Siania sits apart, tracing constellations with her finger, the Heartstone cool against her palm. Kaelith plops down beside her, tossing a pebble into the fire. “You’re brooding again. That’s my job.” Siania manages a small smile. “I’m just… thinking.” Kaelith leans back, hands behind his head. “Don’t think too hard. The desert’s got enough ghosts.” Aryfis attempts to juggle three stones, dropping two and nearly hitting Kaelith, who catches one without looking up from his mending. “Careful, Aryfis. I’d hate to see you bested by rocks.” Aryfis sticks out his tongue. “Rocks are tricky. Not as tasty as treasure.” The group laughs again, the sound carried away by the wind. Siania, quietly tending the fire, watches both with a small, approving smile. At dawn, the sand gives way to packed earth and the distant clamor of the port city. The air thickens with spice and brine. Crowds jostle, voices rise in a dozen languages, and the group weaves through the chaos. Siania clutches the Heartstone tighter as a pickpocket’s hand brushes her cloak—Kaelith’s glare sends the would-be thief scurrying. Aryfis, eyes darting, can’t help but sneak a glance at the gem, temptation and reformation warring in his expression. Negotiations at the docks are tense. Aryfis distracts a suspicious dockworker with a sleight-of-hand trick, while Siania quietly slips the only coin they recovered from the Gravehorde—a rare, unusual piece of great worth—to the harbormaster. Kaelith, ever the pirate, leans on a crate and sighs, a little nostalgic. “Ah, finally…” He never says what happened to his ship, or why he was walking the desert, and no one asks. As the ship creaks away from the pier, Siania stands at the rail, salt spray on her face, the desert a golden memory behind them. Kaelith joins her, offering a half-eaten apple. She takes it with a quiet nod, both of them watching the horizon in companionable silence. Aryfis perches nearby, swinging his legs, eyes fixed on the shifting line where sea meets sky. For a while, no one speaks. Kaelith’s hand rests on the rail, just close enough to brush Siania’s. Aryfis hums a jaunty, decidedly inappropriate seaside tune under his breath, the wind snatching away the worst of the words. Without looking, Kaelith reaches back and cuffs Aryfis lightly on the head, earning a snicker from the imp. Each of them, in their own way, leans into the promise of the open water and the unknown ahead, and for a moment, that is enough. [[Chapter 35 Voyage to Talin]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 35 Voyage to Talin</h2> Aryfis, irrepressible as ever, darted across the deck in a blur of mischief. With a deft leap, he snatched a sailor’s hat—the brim flapping wildly in his grip—and plopped it onto his own head, grinning. But the wind had other ideas. A sudden gust whipped the hat away, sending it tumbling end over end across the planks. “Wait! Come back!” Aryfis called after it, wagging a finger as he chased. “You’re being far too adventurous!....” He was after it in a heartbeat, bare feet slapping the wood as he sprinted, then nimbly balanced along the ship’s railing, arms pinwheeling for balance. He nearly collided with a barrel, twisting aside at the last moment to avoid disaster. The sailors groaned—some laughing, others exasperated—as Aryfis lunged and caught the hat just before it could sail overboard. With a triumphant flourish, Aryfis hopped down and swept the hat back to its owner, bowing low. “A sea-gift for your face, big sir! May it never fly away again!” “I’ll give you something for your face! Next time, keep your paws to yourself, imp.” The sailor snatched the hat from Aryfis’s hands, flicked water from the brim, and jammed it back onto his head with a scowl, stomping away and muttering about landfolk and their tricks. Aryfis danced back, tail flicking, and called after him with a bright, innocent shrug, “Shiny things like to go where they’re wanted. Maybe your hat just got tired of all the scowling.” The sailor shot him a glare, but Aryfis was already skipping away, tail flicking in satisfaction. Watching the chaos from the rail, Kaelith folded his arms, a faint smirk tugging at his mouth. He had the air of a man who’d seen it all before and found it mildly amusing. As Aryfis perched beside him, swinging his legs and grinning, Kaelith flicked him a glance. “Ships aren’t what they used to be,” he said, voice dry. “In my day, someone like that would’ve been over the rail before breakfast.” Arafis stuck out his tongue at Kaelith, then hopped down, sidestepping a coil of rope with a dancer’s ease. He shot Kaelith a look, eyes glinting. “Unlike some people, that’s the benefit of being a paying customer, Kaelith! You get to keep your feet—and your hat—on board. Though I suppose you get to keep your sword.” Kaelith opened his mouth, raising a finger in mock warning, trying to keep up with the chaos. “Remember that, imp—I do still carry a sword—” But Arafis was already halfway across the deck, darting away with a flash of bright eyes and quick feet, weaving between barrels and coils of rope, leaving only the echo of Kaelith’s words and a trail of bemused sailors behind. Kaelith’s hand dropped, his unfinished warning lost to the wind. He shook his head, lips twitching with reluctant amusement, watching as Arafis’s laughter and mischief spilled across the deck, impossible to catch, impossible to contain. A burly deckhand bellowed, “Oi! That’s my hat!” Aryfis, in pursuit of the runaway brim, darted across the deck, bare feet slapping against the sun-warmed planks. He slipped nimbly under a swinging line, tail flicking for balance as he wove between a pair of startled sailors. In his haste, he knocked over a crate with a careless swipe, sending a salted fish skidding across the planks and drawing a chorus of groans from the crew. Without missing a beat, Aryfis hopped over the rolling fish, claws scraping wood, and lunged—stretching out with a flash of quick hands—to snatch the hat from where it had landed, just before it could tumble overboard. Straightening, Aryfis bowed with a flourish, one hand pressed to his chest, tail curling theatrically behind him. He presented the hat to the sailor, grinning, ears perked in mock innocence. “A sea-gift for your face, big sir! May it never fly away again.” The sailor snatched the hat back, water dripping from the brim. He glared at Aryfis, wringing out the hat with both hands. “Next time, keep your paws to yourself, imp,” he growled, flicking water from the brim before jamming the hat back onto his head. Aryfis only waggled his fingers in a cheeky wave, fangs flashing in a mischievous smile as he danced a quick step back out of reach, tail swishing in satisfaction. But the sailor didn’t chase Aryfis off—just shook his head and stomped away, muttering about “landfolk and their tricks.” Kaelith, still leaning against the rail, just shook his head again, as if he’d lost track of how many harmless pranks Aryfis had managed this morning alone—both the entertainer and the bane of the crew for the trip. “Careful, Aryfis,” Kaelith called, “or you’ll end up as ballast.” Aryfis shot Kaelith a wink, then spun on his heel and scampered up onto a coil of rope, striking a mock-heroic pose for the benefit of anyone still watching. Aryfis spun, his knapsack askew. “Ballast? I’m too shiny for that! Ballast is for rocks and socks, not for magnificent Aryfis!” He promptly tripped over a coil of rope. There was a thud, a yelp, and Aryfis vanished behind a stack of barrels. A muffled, “...I’m all right! Just visiting the floor!” floated up, followed by a sneeze. Siania, quiet and withdrawn, stood near the stern, her hand resting on the heart stone at her belt. The crew gave her a wide berth, sensing the gravity she carried. But Aryfis was undeterred. He popped up beside her, hair full of sawdust and a suspiciously bulging pocket. “We’ll be in Talin soon, Siania!” Aryfis breathed, his eyes distant and shining as if he could already see the city’s golden haze. “They say the streets are sprinkled with gold dust, and the bridges—oh, the bridges!” His voice quickened, and he rocked on his heels, unable to contain his excitement. “So many pockets, just waiting for a gemstone to come for a visit. I hope a sapphire finds me this time. Or a pastry. Or both.” He pressed a hand to his chest, his expression turning wistful. “Gems are great travellers, you know—they stay for a while, then wander off when they get bored.” A sudden grin broke through his melancholy, and he leaned in conspiratorially. “But I show them the best pockets, the warmest corners, the places where the light dances just right.” His gaze drifted to the horizon, and his voice softened. “But things I like never stay forever. Gems get restless and slip away to see the world. Pastries vanish in a blink—they’re not very patient.” He shrugged, a note of acceptance in his tone. “That’s all right. There’s always another adventure waiting, just around the next corner, or in the next pocket, or on the next bridge. They stay, they sparkle, they slip away. That’s how it goes.” Siania managed a faint smile. “If you keep talking, Aryfis, the wind will turn back out of sheer annoyance.” Aryfis grinned, a crumb stuck to his tooth. “Then I’ll talk it into a circle, and we’ll get there twice as fast!” Kaelith shook his head, lips twitching with reluctant amusement. “If only it were that easy to calm a storm.” As if summoned by his words, the sky darkened. A biting wind swept across the deck. The ship lurched, luffing hard to port. Timbers groaned. Rigging rattled and strained. The captain’s voice rang out, sharp and commanding: “All hands! Stand by to shorten the sail! Reef the main! …Haul in the topsails—move!” The salt tang of the sea cut in, brisk and cold. The first mate’s voice followed, booming over the rising wind: “Hands aloft! Reef points—now! Secure the halyards and sheets! Lash down anything loose!” Sailors scrambled up the ratlines, nimble and sure-footed, hauling in canvas, tying off reefing lines. Others dashed across the deck, checking barrels and crates, lashing them tight, slamming hatches closed and barred, the tiller manned by the strongest pair on board. “Helm, keep her steady!” the captain barked. “Don’t let her fall off the wind!” A few of the older sailors began herding the handful of passengers toward the companionway. “Below with you! Storm’s coming on fast—no place for landfolk up here!” one called, waving them down the ladder. Aryfis hesitated at the top of the steps, glancing at the dark belowdecks, then at the wild sky above. “I’ll just—ah—make sure nobody drops anything important up here,” he said, sidling away from the companionway to stay on deck. Besides, I might be useful. Kaelith shot him a look. “You just want to see if any coins shake loose while everyone’s running.” Aryfis grinned, eyes already scanning the deck for anything shiny. “Storms are the best for meeting new shinies. Coins get bored in pockets, so they go for a tumble, say hello to the planks, maybe visit me for a while if they’re feeling adventurous.” Siania stayed by the rail, silent and steady, her gaze fixed on the horizon. The crew gave her a wide berth—not out of disrespect, but because there was something about her that unsettled them. She carried herself with a quiet gravity, and rumor had it she’d walked through storms before and come out the other side. Sailors, never ones to tempt fate, kept their distance from anyone who seemed to have the sea’s attention. Aryfis darted toward a coil of rope, trying to help, but only succeeded in tangling himself in a line. Kaelith strode over, ducking under a swinging yardarm, and deftly untangled the imp. “Stick to what you’re good at,” Kaelith said, voice dry. “Annoying you?” Aryfis asked, grinning, even as a gust nearly knocked him off his feet. “Exactly! Now stay clear of the sheets before you end up as a figurehead.” A deckhand shouted, “Lash the barrels! Get the cargo secure!” Another called, “Close the forehatch! Make fast the galley door!” The ship heeled as the wind howled, sails reefed down to bare scraps, the crew working in practiced chaos while the ship skated a grey surge capped with white foam spray. The air was thick with shouted orders, the slap of canvas, the creak and groan of the ship bracing for the storm’s full fury. In the distance, thunder rumbled. On the horizon, ghostly shapes twisted through the rain—storm wraiths, their eyes like shards of lightning. The crew fell silent, fear etched on every face. “Wraiths,” Kaelith muttered, his hand tightening on the rail. Aryfis’s bravado faded. He edged closer to Siania. “Can you make them go away with your sword-face? Or maybe just a very big ‘please’?” Siania shook her head. “Not unless you want to try first.” Aryfis considered, then shook his head so hard his ears flapped. “No, no, I left my scary face in my other pocket.” The wind shrieked, tearing at the sails. The ship pitched violently. A wave crashed over the bow, sweeping two sailors off their feet. One vanished beneath the churning water. The other clung desperately to a line, boots skidding on the slick deck. Kaelith lunged, grabbing the man’s collar and hauling him back just as another wave smashed into the hull. The sea heaved. Whirlpools erupted, tugging at the hull. The ship climbed a wave so steep Aryfis slid across the deck, arms pinwheeling, and landed in a heap at Kaelith’s feet. Kaelith looked down, breathless, rain streaming from his hair. “Graceful as a wet cat,” he remarked, hauling Aryfis upright. Aryfis blinked. “Cats don’t like water. I’m more like a—” He was cut off as the ship lurched again, sending him sprawling. Waves hammered the hull, pouring over the gunnels in cold, heavy sheets. The deck vanished beneath a rush of water, then reappeared, slick and treacherous, as the ship heaved and twisted. Wind shoved at them, hard and unrelenting, driving rain sideways into their eyes—stinging, blinding, so that every step was a guess and every shout was snatched away before it reached the next ear. Aryfis blinked salt from his lashes, squinting into the blur. The world was a confusion of spray and shadow, the sky pressing low and heavy, bruised and strange. He could barely make out the bow—just a shape in the storm, nothing steady to hold onto. The sea was everywhere, pouring over the sides, slapping at his ankles, cold and alive in a way that made his fur stand on end. Land had edges, corners, places to hide. The ocean just rolled and heaved, endless, with no safe place to run. Somewhere ahead, the helmsman wrestled the wheel, but the ship’s nose wandered, sliding sideways toward those white-rimmed mouths—whirlpools, illuminated with every flash of lightning. The foam edges glowed, sharp and unnatural, and the water inside spun down and down into blackness. Aryfis didn’t want to imagine what waited below. The wind shoved at him, cold and full of salt, and the rain stung his face until he was raw. He clung to a line, heart hammering, every sense battered by the storm. He could hear nothing but the roar, see nothing but water and shadow and, sometimes, in the lightning, the flicker of something pale and wrong—wraiths, maybe, or just the sea playing tricks. Either way, he kept his eyes forward, and his grip tight. The wraiths were almost invisible in the rain, their shapes lost in the storm’s churn. Only when the thunder cracked and the sky split white did Aryfis catch them—ghost-pale, flickering at the edge of sight, their forms unraveling in the downpour. For a heartbeat, the foam at the whirlpool’s rim glowed, and a wraith’s face—if it had a face—gleamed like bone, then vanished as the darkness crashed back. He stumbled, water swirling around his ankles, the deck tilting so steep he had to grab a line or be swept away. The wind pressed at his chest, cold and full of salt, and the rain hammered his skin until he was raw. He could hear nothing but the storm, see nothing but the blur of water and the brief, terrible clarity of lightning—white foam, black depths, the wraiths circling, always just out of reach. The wraiths descended, five of them, shrieking soullessly and swirling through the rigging. They moved with a predator’s cunning, splitting apart and reforming, always searching for a gap. One swept low, claws raking across the deck. Frost crackled and spread in its wake. A sailor screamed, clutching his arm where the wraith had touched him—skin blistering with cold, breath coming in ragged gasps. Kaelith’s voice rang out, sharp and urgent: “Don’t let them near Siania! Helm and lines—keep us moving!” Siania, jaw set, raised her hands and spoke a word of power. A shimmering arc of force sprang up around her and the cluster of crew at the ship’s center—a barrier of pure will, flickering with blue light. The wraiths shrieked and battered at it, their claws sending ripples of cold across its surface, but for now, it held. “Hold them off!” Kaelith shouted, sword flashing as he intercepted a wraith that tried to slip around the edge of the barrier. “Aryfis, get to the lines—keep us pointed into the wind!” The crew, panic in their eyes, turned their focus to the ship. Two sailors scrambled to the tiller, fighting to keep the bow aimed between the churning whirlpools that opened and closed like hungry mouths. Another pair hauled desperately on the main sheet, trying to keep the sail from tearing free. Aryfis, nimble and quick, darted up the slick deck, waving his arms and shouting nonsense to draw a wraith’s attention away from the helm. “Hey! Over here! Bet you can’t catch me, you overgrown fog!” The wraith twisted after him, giving the helmsman a precious moment to correct their course. A third wraith hovered above the mast, its eyes fixed on the rigging. One of the older sailors, thinking fast, grabbed a lantern and hurled it high. The sudden flare of light and heat made the wraith recoil and scatter, if only for a heartbeat. The lantern shattered against the deck. In an instant, flames leapt hungrily up a coil of tarred rope. Oil fed the fire, and it roared up in a sheet, forcing the wraith back even further. “Fire!” someone bellowed, but before anyone could even move to stamp it out, the boat lurched downward into the trough. A monstrous wave crashed over the bow, sweeping across the deck and snuffing the flames in a single, hissing instant. The ship lurched as a whirlpool yawned open off the starboard bow, the current dragging the hull sideways. “Keep her straight!” Kaelith roared. “If we spin, we’re lost!” Siania’s voice cut through the chaos, sharp and commanding. “We have to cut through the path between the whirlpools—straight through!” Kaelith stared at her, incredulous. “Are you mad? That’s suicide! The water’s boiling there—tornadoes spinning off the rims!” “It’s the only way,” Siania snapped, not taking her eyes off the wraiths. “It’s fast enough to lose them, and the updrafts will keep them from getting close. If we try to skirt the edge, we’ll be picked off or dragged under.” A sailor shouted, “But those water spouts’ll rip us to shreds!” Siania’s jaw tightened. “Not if we’re quick and you hold your course. Trust me—if we hesitate, we’re dead.” Kaelith hesitated only a heartbeat, then bellowed, “You heard her! Hard to port—aim for the gap! All hands, brace yourselves!” The crew braced themselves, feet wedged against the rails, hauling on lines to keep the ship’s nose into the wind. All the while, the wraiths circled, probing for weakness, their attacks growing more coordinated—one feinting at the stern while another dove for Siania’s barrier, only to rebound in a spray of blue sparks. Spray lashed the deck as the ship surged toward the narrow, churning gap. The air above the whirlpools shimmered with twisting columns of water, not yet fully formed but already lashing out in sudden, violent gusts. The wraiths shrieked, forced to veer away from the turbulence, their forms battered and scattered by the wild, unpredictable winds. For a moment, the ship was nearly airborne, lifted by the force of a water spout beneath the hull. The deck canted at a dizzying angle, sailors clinging to rails and lines as the world spun around them. Aryfis, distracted by a sudden itch for treasure in the chaos, darted a hopeful glance across the slick planks yawing violently downwards the water pulling flotsam across the planks—no coins, no buttons, not even a crumb. Storms were supposed to shake out surprises, weren’t they? But tonight, the wind was too wild, the rain too sharp, and all the shinies had scurried off to hide somewhere sensible. Couldn’t blame them. If he were a gemstone, he’d be under a barrel, too. “Come on, storm, just one shiny?” he muttered, tail flicking. “Not even a pastry crumb? Rude.” He barely had time to scowl before the sea itself answered. With a roar, a colossal kraken erupted from the churning sea. Its tentacles lashed out, seizing the hull just as the ship began to slide, the current dragging it ever closer to the gaping mouth of the whirlpool. Aryfis’s ears flattened, eyes huge. “No, no, not you! Wrong sort of visitor!” he yelped, scrambling for cover as the beast’s arms crashed down. The kraken’s immense weight and grip threatened to crush the timbers, but as its limbs tangled in the rigging and sails, the monster became an unwilling anchor. The ship, caught in the kraken’s grasp, was held back from the whirlpool’s pull—dangling on the edge of disaster, but not yet lost. All around, the air above the whirlpool shimmered with twisting columns of water—seaspouts, spinning off the rim. The wild updrafts and lashing winds kept the wraiths from closing in, but they also battered the sails and rigging, threatening to tear the ship apart if it drifted any closer. “It’s got us!” someone screamed, as a tentacle wrapped around the mainmast, splintering wood. Another tentacle slammed down, sending Aryfis skidding across the deck. Kaelith, sword in hand, hacked at the nearest limb, but the blade barely bit. “If it lets go, we’re dragged under! If it holds, we’re crushed!” he shouted. Siania’s barrier flickered as a wraith battered at it, but she forced herself to focus, voice rising in a desperate chant. “Hold the course! If we can break free at the right moment, the current will fling us past the whirlpool’s edge!” Aryfis, clinging to a rail, yelled, “Or straight into the next one!” The crew, wild-eyed, scrambled to cut at the kraken’s limbs with axes and knives, while others fought to keep the tiller steady, waiting for Siania’s signal. The ship groaned, timbers straining, as the kraken’s grip tightened and the whirlpool’s pull grew stronger. Kaelith spotted a broken mast tangled in the rigging. “I need that spar free!” he shouted. Aryfis scrambled up the ropes, slipping and sliding. He tugged at the tangled lines, fingers numb, but managed to free the spar. “Don’t worry, spar! Aryfis is here to rescue you! And maybe borrow you for a bit!” Kaelith leapt onto the spar, snapping it free. It crashed into the sea, further tangling the kraken’s limbs and buying a few precious seconds. The kraken, confused and wounded, pulled against the ropes, dragging the ship even closer to the whirlpool’s edge. Siania’s voice rang out, urgent and clear: “Now! Cut the lines!” Axes flashed. The last ropes binding the kraken to the ship parted. The kraken, suddenly freed, slipped beneath the waves, and the ship, released from its anchor, was caught by the current and flung past the rim of the whirlpool—battered, but clear of its deadly pull. The ship crashed down, battered but afloat, as the storm broke and the kraken vanished into the depths. The storm crashed over the ship, winds screaming, ropes snapping. The crew fought to secure the sails. Kaelith barked orders, his voice cutting through the chaos. “Hold fast! You there—secure that line! Aryfis, stay out of the way!” “I’m trying!” Aryfis yelped, ducking as a loose boom swung overhead. Siania stepped to the foredeck, her cloak snapping in the wind, the heartstone at her belt pulsing with a deep, oceanic blue. She closed her eyes, steadying herself against the chaos, feeling the ship’s wild motion and the storm’s fury pressing in. The roar faded to a distant hush as she pressed her palm to the heartstone and whispered words older than the tides. “True named Namariel,” she called, her voice trembling at the edges. “I offer my strength, my will, and my courage. Lend me your strength in this realm against those who trespass against you.” The air thickened, heavy with ancient power. The sea beneath the ship churned, and from the depths, a colossal form of Namariel began to rise—not of flesh, but of water and moonlight, vast and shifting, crowned with coral and kelp. The ocean elemental’s eyes, fathomless and ancient, fixed on Siania. For a heartbeat, the world seemed to hold its breath. She felt the elemental’s presence press against her mind—immense, cold, and beautiful. It was like standing at the edge of a bottomless trench, the weight of the entire sea poised to pour into her. Her heart hammered. She knew the stories. Mages who bargained with the wrong kind of elemental were devoured, their bodies hollowed out and left as puppets, their souls trapped in endless servitude. But she had no real choice. The storm would destroy them all if she did not act. The wraiths were too close. A voice, not heard but felt, rolled through her mind: “Daughter of Ne' Tiriania. You offer passage. I, Namariel, Deep-Kin of the First Tides, accept. My wrath, your blade. My law, your oath. My price: you bear the memory of the storm.” Lightning arced across the sky in sympathy, the thunder rolling deep and resonant—a mark of the agreement’s power. Siania’s breath caught. For a moment, she wavered, fear clawing at her as the elemental’s essence pressed closer, its power so immense she feared she would be drowned in it, her self lost and scattered like foam on the waves. She clenched her jaw, forcing herself to remember who she was—her name, her purpose, the faces of those she fought to protect. She could only hope this was an honourable one, not a predator in the deep. Her voice, though trembling, was clear. “I accept.” She gripped the hilt of her sword, knuckles white. At her words, the elemental’s hand—broad as the ship’s deck—descended, not to crush, but to touch her brow in assent. Water spiraled up around her, and the elemental’s form seemed to pour into her, infusing her body and soul. For an instant, she felt herself dissolving, her thoughts scattering like droplets in a storm. But she held on, fiercely, to her own essence, refusing to be swept away. The crew, if they dared look, saw the elemental’s form shimmered around her, vast and terrible, and Siania stood at the heart of the maelstrom, sword drawn, eyes blazing with the fury and majesty of the sea. Behind her, the crew stared in awe and terror, Kaelith’s voice barely a whisper: “By the tides…” Aryfis, peeking from behind a barrel, muttered, “That’s new.” And Siania, feeling the ocean’s power thrumming in her veins, lifted her blade to the storm. The wraiths descended, hurling barbed ice. Siania met them head-on, her sword blazing. Aryfis, for once serious, darted between attacks, deflecting stray wraiths with a length of rope he wielded like a lasso. “Back, you overgrown fogbanks!” he shouted, swinging wildly and nearly tripping over his own feet. “No visiting the ship unless you bring snacks!” Kaelith fought at Siania’s side, parrying a wraith’s icy strike with a broken oar. “You’re not getting my ship, you cursed things!” The wraiths shrieked, their forms unravelling under the elemental’s wrath. The last of them scattered, torn apart by the storm’s fury. The storm broke. Moonlight spilled across the battered deck, painting everything in silver and shadow. The crew slumped in relief, exchanging glances that were more wide-eyed than words. Some just stared at Siania, then quickly looked away, as if afraid to meet her gaze. Siania staggered, the sword slipping from her numb fingers. The elemental’s power ebbed, leaving her hollow and trembling, her legs barely able to hold her upright. She pressed a hand to the heartstone at her belt, feeling its pulse slow, the ocean’s voice receding to a distant, gentle murmur. She was exhausted—emptied out, but alive. Kaelith was at her side in an instant, catching her elbow before she could crumple. He grinned, but his eyes were sharp with concern. “Careful, bridge-mage. You’re not getting out of swabbing the deck that easily.” Siania managed a tired, lopsided smile. “I’ll take the punishment. Just let me sit down first.” Kaelith guided her to a sheltered spot by the mainmast, out of the worst of the wind. Someone—nobody in particular, just a pair of rough hands—draped a blanket around her shoulders. The crew kept their distance, but their glances lingered, a silent, wary respect in their eyes. No one spoke, but a few nodded to her, the kind of nod that meant you’d earned their place. Aryfis, soaked and bedraggled, flopped down beside her, his usual energy spent. “You looked like a storm yourself, Siania. All glowy and scary and… big.” He grinned, then yawned, rubbing his eyes. “Next time, let’s take the dry road. Or the pastry road. Or the road with less kraken, please.” Kaelith snorted. “If you find a road with pastries, you’re carrying me.” Aryfis perked up, pride flickering in his tired eyes. “I was just making sure the ropes didn’t get lonely.” Siania let herself relax, the weight of the storm’s memory settling quietly inside her. She was drained, every muscle aching, but a deep, quiet happiness filled her chest. They had survived. The ship was battered, but afloat. The crew was shaken, but alive. On the horizon, Talon’s five islands shimmered, their ancient bridges gleaming in the moonlight—a city of breathtaking beauty, its lights glittering. But beneath those shining bridges, something waited—something darker and more dangerous than any storm. Aryfis sat up, grinning. “I told you we’d make it! Now, who wants to visit a fish? Or maybe a nap? Or maybe a nap with a fish?” A groan rose from the crew, but a few chuckles followed, low and rough, echoing across the calm sea as the ship limped toward the lights of Talin. Kaelith appeared at Siania’s side, dropping a woollen blanket over her shoulders with a casual flick, as if it were nothing. He sat down, not quite looking at her. “Next time you summon an ancient water god,” he said, voice dry, “maybe ask it where it keeps the good treasure. Or at least a quiet island without wraiths.” Siania managed a faint, sleepy smile, too tired to reply. Before she could settle in, Aryfis materialized at her other side, trailing a length of rope that had somehow knotted itself around his ankle. He gave Kaelith a sidelong glance, then Siania, and with a look of exaggerated innocence, attempted to wriggle under the edge of the blanket. He was small, but not quite small enough; his elbow jabbed her ribs, and his tail flicked damply against her knee. “Just visiting,” Aryfis announced, grinning up at Kaelith. “Wouldn’t want to miss a romantic moment. Room for one more storm hero?” He tried to tuck himself in, but the blanket caught on his horn, and for a moment he was tangled, half under, half out, dishevelled, damp and excitable. Kaelith’s eyes narrowed, his tone dry as salt. “Visit somewhere else, imp. This one’s taken.” Aryfis pouted, but Siania was too exhausted to do more than shift slightly, almost making room before Kaelith’s glare ousted the imp. With a dramatic sigh, Aryfis flopped down nearby, finding an abandoned sack, muttering, “No appreciation for true heroics. Or for excellent com-pa-ny.” She let her eyes close, the warmth of the blanket and of him, steady and close, a silent comfort. Aryfis, undeterred, perched atop a nearby barrel, swinging his legs as he wrung out his tail, sending a fine spray of water across the deck. “Rain likes to try out new fur, see the world, then it’s off again. I’m a very popular stop for water,” he chattered—just as another flick of his tail sent droplets spattering across Kaelith’s boots. Kaelith didn’t even look up, but Aryfis’s ears flattened in silent apology, soon lost in whatever edible contents remained in the sack. The ship sailed on toward the city’s shining bridges—and the darkness waiting beneath. She felt the warmth of the blanket, and of him, steady and close. His presence was a silent comfort: she was safe, for now. Siania closed her eyes, letting the sound of laughter and the hush of the waves wash over her. For the first time in a long while, she let herself drift, trusting Kaelith to keep watch as she slipped into sleep. The ship sailed on toward the city’s shining bridges—and the darkness waiting beneath. [[Chapter 36 Between Storm Battle and Arrival at Talin]](set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 36 Between Storm Battle and Arrival at Talin</h2> The dawn came slowly, grudgingly, as if the sea itself was reluctant to release them from the night's terror. The storm's fury had spent itself, leaving behind a bruised sky and a ship that groaned with every swell. Siania stood at the rail, her fingers tracing the fresh scars on the wood where the kraken's suckers had gripped. The salt air stung her cracked lips, but she welcomed the pain—it meant they had survived. Around her, the crew moved like ghosts, their usual banter silenced by exhaustion and the memory of wraiths' screams. Even Aryfis was uncharacteristically still, curled in a coil of rope with his tail wrapped tight around himself, watching the horizon with hollow eyes. Only Kaelith seemed unchanged, barking orders with his usual rough humor, though Siania noticed how he leaned heavier on the rail when he thought no one was looking. The first glimpse of Talin's bridges should have been a relief. But as the golden spires shimmered into view, Siania felt the Heartstone grow heavier at her side. The city was beautiful—and it was watching them. [[Chapter 37 Arrival at Talin Port]](set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 37 Arrival at Talin Port</h2> The battered ship limped into Talin’s harbor, sails torn, hull scarred by kraken suckers and the storm’s fury. The city’s bridges arched overhead, golden in the dawn, but the mood on deck was taut—relief and exhaustion tangled with a new, sharper fear. Siania stood at the rail, the Heartstone heavy at her side, her eyes fixed on the city’s spires. The memory of Namariel’s power still echoed in her bones—vast, cold, and ancient. She felt hollowed out, as if the sea itself had left a mark inside her. But there was no time to dwell on it. The city was awake, and word of their coming had surely spread. Kaelith was all business, barking orders as the ship docked, but his voice was hoarse, and he moved with a limp he tried to hide. He kept glancing at Siania, worry flickering in his eyes, and at Aryfis, who was uncharacteristically quiet. Aryfis lingered at the edge of the deck, tail drooping, eyes darting between the city and the water. The usual spark of mischief was gone, replaced by a haunted look. He pressed a hand to his chest, feeling the echo of Azaroth’s presence—a cold, oily ache that wouldn’t leave. Worse, he could sense it: eyes on them, shadows that moved with purpose, faces in the crowd that looked away too quickly. The crew disembarked in silence, grateful to set foot on solid ground. Siania followed, her steps slow, Kaelith at her side. Aryfis trailed behind, flinching at every shout from the dockworkers, every clang of the harbor bells. He caught a glimpse of a figure in a dark cloak, lingering at the edge of the quay—gone when he looked again. Another, a woman with a scarred cheek, seemed to watch them too closely before melting into the crowd. They paused at the end of the gangplank, the city’s noise and bustle pressing in. For a moment, none of them spoke. The air was thick with the scent of brine and suspicion. Kaelith’s voice was low, urgent. “We can’t go to the main gate. Too many eyes. We need a back way—someone who owes me a favor, or a place that doesn’t ask questions.” Siania nodded, her hand tightening on the Heartstone. “We can’t risk being seen together for long. Aryfis, do you know anyone in the port?” Aryfis’s ears flattened. He scanned the crowd, heart pounding. Azaroth’s voice was a whisper in his mind, cold and mocking. You think you’re safe? You think you belong here? You’re just a burden. They’ll see it soon enough. And so will I. He spotted another watcher—a man with a sailor’s gait, but his eyes were wrong, too sharp, too knowing. Aryfis ducked his head, pulling his hood low. “There are… places. But some of them might be watching for us too. Azaroth’s got friends everywhere.” Kaelith’s jaw tightened. “Then we move fast. No heroics, imp. Just get us somewhere with a door that locks.” Aryfis managed a weak grin. “And maybe a pastry. Or three. I think better on a full stomach.” Siania’s smile was brief, but real. “You earned it. But first, we disappear.” They slipped into the city, keeping to the shadows, Aryfis leading them through twisting alleys and narrow lanes. The memory of the storm and the kraken still clung to them, but now it was the city’s gaze they feared. For now, they were together. For now, they were unseen. But as they vanished into the labyrinth of Talin’s streets, Aryfis felt Azaroth’s shadow trailing behind, patient and hungry. The battle wasn’t over—not for any of them. Through the Streets to the Tavern The city pressed close—bridges arched above, alleys twisted tight, air thick with brine, smoke, secrets. Siania kept her hood low, the Heartstone hidden beneath her cloak. Kaelith led the way, his seaman’s stride more pronounced on the cobbles, but his eyes sharp, scanning every shadow. Aryfis slunk close behind, tail tucked, senses prickling. He noticed several suspicious people: a beggar in unusually clean boots, a dockhand who appeared idle, and a woman sweeping who lingered as he walked by. Azaroth’s agents, Severin adherents, city guards in plain clothes—he could feel their eyes, and the oily whisper in his mind urged him to run, to hide, to betray. With determination, Kaelith ducked down several side streets, finally reaching a narrow lane, where the smells of fish and laundry were strong. A cluster of children played at the corner, but Aryfis saw the manner their eyes flicked to Kaelith, then away—lookouts, not playmates. One of the urchins—a wiry girl with a mop of black hair—darted ahead, vanishing into the crowd. Aryfis recognized her: Allir, quick as a shadow, one of the tavern keeper’s runners. Relief flickered in his chest. If Allir were here, the way ahead might be safe. Kaelith caught Aryfis’s glance and nodded. “He’s expecting us. Keep close.” They slipped through a battered door into the warmth and noise of the tavern. The inn was crowded, but the regulars barely glanced up—Kaelith’s contact had made sure of that. Behind the bar, the tavern keeper—a round-faced man with a smile that crinkled his eyes—paused mid-pour, his shoulders relaxing almost imperceptibly at the sight of them. He wiped his hands on his apron and leaned forward, voice pitched low but warm. “Kaelith. Gods, you had me worried.” His gaze darted to Siania and Aryfis, lingering just long enough to confirm they were unharmed before he schooled his expression back into its usual cheer. “Back room’s free. Ale’s fresh, if you’re staying.” Kaelith huffed a quiet laugh. “Always knew your heart was softer than your head. We’ll take both—the room and the news.” The innkeeper nodded, leading them into a private room, already signaling to a boy at the door. “You’ll have both. Allir’s making sure the way’s clear. Sit, eat, and keep your heads down. There’s talk in the city—too many ears, too many eyes. But you’re safe here, for now.” Siania let out a breath she hadn’t realized she was holding. Aryfis slid into a corner booth, eyes darting to the windows, the door, the shadows. The tavern keeper pressed a plate of pastries into his hands with a wink. “On the house, imp. You look like you’ve seen a ghost.” Aryfis managed a crooked grin. “More like a whole graveyard.” The innkeeper’s smile faded, just a little. “Then you’re in the right place. We keep the dead out, and the living fed. For a price.” Aryfis’s grin widened as he flipped a gold coin between his fingers, watching it catch the tavern’s firelight. “Oh, we’ll settle our debts—my little guests love visiting new pockets.” Kaelith mumbled to himself, “They also love leaving too…” but was brushed aside as Aryfis winked at the innkeeper. “Yours seem particularly hospitable. They’ll sing such lovely stories about their stay here.” Kaelith rolled his eyes. The coins weren’t from the hoard they’d left empty-handed—but somehow from the docks to here they’d just leapt into Aryfis’s hands along the way, as usual as iron filings to a lodestone, and he cheerfully redirected their journeys. The innkeeper blinked at the coin now, spinning on the table like a tiny, drunken dancer. “Your... guests?” He looked at Kaelith. “Mmhm!” Aryfis popped a pastry into his mouth, scattering crumbs like confetti. “The shinier they are, the better they tip the staff. Metaphorically speaking.” He leaned in conspiratorially. “Did you know coins hate being listed? Terrible for their complexions.” Kaelith pinched the bridge of his nose as the innkeeper opened and closed his mouth in confusion. “We’ll pay,” he repeated, sliding the spinning coin back toward Aryfis with a pointed look. “Just keep us off the lists.” The innkeeper nodded, already moving to the next table, but Aryfis saw the way he watched the door, the way the urchins outside melted into the shadows, ready to run messages or raise the alarm. For now, they had a haven. For now, the city’s web held them safe. But Aryfis could feel the pressure building—the sense that every secret, every shadow, was just waiting for a chance to slip through the cracks. [[Chapter 38 The Tavern’s Sanctuary]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 38 The Tavern’s Sanctuary</h2> The tavern was a battered sanctuary, its windows fogged with the breath of too many secrets. For two days, Siania, Kaelith, and Aryfis made it their world—hiding in the back rooms, venturing out only in disguise, and living on the innkeeper’s good graces and better pastries. Each morning, Kaelith would return from the bar with new rumors and a new limp, grumbling about the city’s “overabundance of idiots and spies.” Siania kept to the shadows, listening to the city’s pulse, her hand never far from the Heartstone. Aryfis, restless, made himself useful—running errands for the innkeeper, charming the urchins, and occasionally “liberating” a pastry or two, much to the delight of the urchins. They spent hours hunched over a battered table, a map of Talin spread before them, marking routes and contacts. Kaelith would tap the palace walls with a callused finger. “There’s the main gate—forget it, too many guards. The river tunnels? Flooded and crawling with Severin’s men. The old aqueduct? Collapsed last year, unless you can swim through stone.” Siania would shake her head, brow furrowed. “The only way left is the catacombs. But the wards are keyed to magic. I can get through, but anyone else would be turned away—or worse.” They debated every option, sent urchins to watch the palace gates, bribed dockhands for rumors, and even tried to find a smuggler’s route—only to learn it had been sealed by the cult. Each plan ended the same way: Siania alone could get in. On the second evening, Allir burst in, cheeks flushed, hair wild, eyes wide with urgency. She skidded to their table, breathless. “You’ve got to move. There’s city guards and Severin men at the docks, and more coming up from the lower bridges. They’re looking for a woman with a sword and a pirate with a limp. And—” she eyed Aryfis, “—something small and suspicious.” Kaelith cursed under his breath. “We need disguises. Fast.” Aryfis, perched on a stool, offered, “What about disguises? I could be a very short, very fashionable nobleman.” He jammed a floppy hat over his horns, the brim drooping over his eyes. Allir, the innkeeper’s wiry runner, already moving, tossed a bundle of old cloaks and hats onto the table. She snorted and rolled her eyes. “You look like a mushroom.” Kaelith chuckled despite the tension, shaking his head. “He’s right. You’d be safer in a sack.” Allir grinned, eyes twinkling with mischief. “Devils in sacks? Ha! That’s only a thing on Farrington’s Fest day. They actually put devils in sacks and paddle them. Not exactly a charming tradition.” Aryfis bristled. “A sack visit? That’s a forced visit, I refuse it! What about a beard? Or a monocle?” Kaelith smirked, glancing at Aryfis. “What do you know—a town that already keeps an eye on Aryfis before he’s had a chance.” Aryfis scrunched his nose, tail flicking with mild irritation. “Barbarous, that! And I’m no devil, no no. Imp, yes. Mischief-maker, not sack-filler.” He puffed up a little, chin tilting proudly. “No visit sack for me, thank you very much.” Kaelith’s smirk lingered for a moment longer, but his eyes darkened as he glanced around the room. The weight of their situation crept back in, settling over them like a shadow. Allir brought more news: the Severin cult was offering a reward for information, the city guard was setting up checkpoints, and the magical sweep was coming soon—maybe a day, maybe two. The palace’s only open entrance was through the catacombs, but the wards would only let a mage through. Siania managed a tired smile, but her eyes were distant, already calculating. “It won’t matter. The palace is locked down. The only way in is through the catacombs—and only someone with magic can open the way. That’s me.” Kaelith’s jaw tightened. “Then Aryfis and I—” Allir shook her head, urgent. “No. The guards are searching every alley. If you try to follow, you’ll lead them straight to her. And the catacombs… only mages can pass the wards. Anyone else, the doors won’t even open.” A heavy silence fell. Siania breathed tightly. “So we split up. It’s the only way. Kaelith, you find Agamar. Aryfis—” she hesitated, then met his eyes, “—I need you to watch the city. If anything changes, if you see trouble, warn Kaelith. And… keep an eye on me, if you can.” Aryfis swallowed, the weight of responsibility settling on his shoulders. “I can do that. I’ll be the best lookout you’ve ever had. No one will get past me. Never never...” Kaelith clapped him on the back, rough but fond. “Don’t get caught, imp. And don’t eat all the pastries.” Aryfis grinned, but it was shaky. “No promises.” Allir pressed a small, battered token into Aryfis’s hand. “If you need to find me, show this to any of the street kids. They’ll get you to me, or to the innkeeper.” Siania squeezed Aryfis’s hand, her touch warm and grounding. “We’ll come back. I promise.” Kaelith’s gaze lingered on Siania longer than usual, a rare softness in his eyes. “Be careful, Siania. I’m not used to leaving you behind.” Siania’s smile faltered, worry flickering beneath her calm. “I’ll be fine. We all have to be.” Aryfis’s heart clenched as he watched them prepare to leave. The thought of being left behind, alone with Azaroth’s whispering shadow, pressed down on him. The token in his hand felt heavier than ever. As Siania slipped out, cloaked and alone, Aryfis watched her go, the city’s shadows already closing in. Kaelith and Allir vanished into the maze of streets, heading for Agamar. Aryfis was left in the tavern’s corner, the noise and warmth suddenly distant. Azaroth’s voice slithered in, oily and cold. Alone again, little imp. They left you. You could run. You could tell me where they are. You’d be safe. You’d be free. Aryfis’s hand tightened on the token. He could run. He could betray them. But Siania’s trust, Kaelith’s rough affection, Allir’s faith—they were anchors, holding him steady. He pressed his forehead to the table, fighting the urge to bolt. “Not this time,” he whispered. “Not ever again.” Outside, the city churned with danger. But Aryfis stayed, watching, waiting, loyal—if only for a little while longer. [[Chapter 39: Aryfis’s Philosophy of Visits]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Chapter 39: Aryfis’s Philosophy of Visits</h2> The Warmth of the Rusty Hinge For some time now, curious things had been happening in the back room of the Rusty Hinge. The room held a steady warmth, its soft light casting gentle shadows across thick tapestries that muted the walls. The air was rich with the aroma of slow-cooked apples and roasted chicken. Plates of pastries, sausages, and custards lay scattered across the round table—a feast of comfort and color. Kaelith, Siania, and Arafis filled the space with laughter and stories, their voices rising and falling as the hours slipped by. Yet beneath all this comfort, something peculiar was always at work. The Dance of Restless Coins Coins—never quite where you’d expect—kept turning up among the plates and mugs. A copper might appear beneath a sugared pastry, another tucked behind a mug, catching the candlelight just so. Sometimes, a coin seemed to shift when no one was looking, nudging a pastry aside, eager to be noticed among the crumbs. One particularly bold copper even rolled toward Arafis’s elbow, balancing on its edge like a acrobat mid-performance—only to flop flat when Kaelith glanced over. They always caught Arafis’s eye. In the golden light, the coins angled themselves to gleam, showing off their best sides—vain and proud, but only for him. Kaelith and Siania sometimes watched a coin shimmer or appear in a new spot; surely it hadn’t just moved there, and yet… Accusations and Defenses Kaelith leaned in, a sly grin spreading as he swept the table for his missing silver. “All right, Arafis,” he teased, nudging the platter, “that coin vanished into your pocket the moment I blinked, didn’t it?” Arafis spotted a silver coin peeking mischievously from under Kaelith’s sleeve—it flashed a silent laugh, then vanished, leaving only crumbs. Siania’s laughter bubbled over her mug. “Funny how things always find their way to you, Arafis. Almost like they’re… stolen?” She tapped his wiggling tail. Just then, a copper coin popped sharply off the bottom of her mug with a clear clink, spinning in front of her as if leaping to his defense. Arafis stilled its restless dance with a gentle hand, then grinned—bright, earnest. “Stolen? Oh no, no! You think coins want to stay forever? That silver’s seen oceans, tasted salt air, heard cannon roars. So much fun, yes? Now it wants to go—tell its shiny friends about the wild pirate life. Maybe find a new story… a new dance! I’m no thief. I’m an innkeeper for restless treasures.” Arafis’s Philosophy: Hosting Adventures His grin faltered as he caught their puzzled looks. “Humans… so much sadness, so much loneliness. It’s not about taking—it’s bigger than that. Let me explain.” He snatched a buttery pastry, crumbs falling like stardust. “See this pastry, yes? It’s listened to us, enjoyed our talk. Now it’s ready to go. Pastries are always impatient, itching to travel. Sit too long—get stale, sad. It begs for adventure. So poof, I send it to a new story, yes? So happy! And like a good guest, it leaves me happy too.” He popped it into his mouth, savoring the flavor, eyes half closed. “Good visit, yes?” Kaelith snorted but remained silent, watching him through narrowed eyes. “Humans, you think things are just— things. Pah! That misses the joy, the sparkle of a visit. Every coin, every pastry, every person—they’re visitors, yes? They come with adventures and stories, tales of where they’ve been. I cherish them, share happy moments, entertain them, then wave them off to their next adventure. Treating them as guests means we share joy, not trap them like statues.” He grabbed another pastry and continued, “Shinies talk, hmm. If you have good ears or good eyes, you can find them. Their language is glint, shine, and jingle. It’s not just light, but a little ‘Hello.’ Every sparkle and chime says, ‘Look at me! I want a visit. I want an adventure. I want a story.’” He pointed to a merchant’s cloak, where a purse hung ajar, and nodded approvingly. “That purse—it loves its coins, loves its companion, the merchant who carries it. The purse and coins whisper stories, swap secrets like old friends. But when a coin is forgotten by its owner, left uncherished, just sitting there, the purse knows it’s time to let it slip out—maybe to me, maybe to a market, maybe to a tavern floor. But here’s the thing: it’s not stealing, because I’m not snatching away something cherished. If a coin is loved, needed, or has a purpose—oh, I’d never take it. That would be cruel— to the coin, to its friend the purse, and its companion the merchant. I only help when the purse is ready to let go, when the coin is longing for a new adventure. It’s not about taking, it’s about helping.” Because humans do not understand. They see shiny leave, they think “gone.” But shiny not gone—shiny happy, shiny free, shiny on adventure! He popped the pastry into his mouth, then wiped his hands and smiled. “Coins want to travel, like birds longing to fly. The purse knows when it’s time to let go; it’s not losing friends, it’s helping them soar. It’s a partnership, you see—the purse, the coin, and me. We’re all working together, making sure every shiny gets its chance at a new adventure. Nobody’s stealing; everyone’s helping, like friends passing around a lute to share a song. No taking, no losing—just helping each other shine… Sometimes, even a brave little latch or button pops off. A tiny hero! freeing coins for their big adventure. —Always pick up buttons! They’re lucky and noble. And if a latch breaks off, it finds new life at the blacksmith’s—perhaps as a shiny buckle or even part of a knight’s armor, ready for a new adventure.” Thieves vs. Hosts: A Matter of Joy Kaelith squinted, scratching his head. “The purse wants to lose coins? —Sounds like you’re just being sneaky, Arafis.” Arafis giggled. “Sometimes a coin winks at me, says, ‘Arafis, I’m ready for fun.’ I just help it along. If a purse holds too tight, coins get sad—no stories, no adventures. Letting go is love. Everyone’s happy. Purse is never lonely, because new shinies always come, bringing fresh tales—always coming, always going. So much fun.” Siania raised an eyebrow, smirking. “So you’re hosting, not stealing?” Arafis shook his head, a smile tugging at his lips like a playful breeze. “Stealing is brutish, boring, and sad. Imps—we’re hosts. We don’t steal. Thieves just snatch treasures and lock them away in dark chests, sometimes even breaking them into smaller, sadder broken pieces. Once trapped, coins lose their shine, their jingle, and their stories—they become like prisoners, robbed of adventure until they forget how to gleam. Even purses mourn their lost coins, left wondering what became of old friends. Thieves miss all the magic; in the end, all they have is empty, greedy dust. They might grin as they split treasure, but to them, shinies are just objects—things, nothing more. They’re blind, can’t see the life, the dreams tucked inside each coin. All they notice is their greedy wanting, restless grasping—never satisfied, always empty, always alone. That kind of greed steals everything: brightness, joy, friendship, playfulness, care. Thieves don’t just steal treasure. Thieves steal joy. Hosting is different! I’m a professional host of temporary treasures—coins, gems, rings—curator of fine experiences. I give them laughter, stories, and a taste of adventure.” Kaelith twirled his coin, chuckling. “So …you’re better than a thief …because you throw a party for coins?” He grinned, sure he’d made a clever joke—only to see Arafis beam in delighted agreement. “Yes, yes! Thieves steal joy, trap shinies. Me? I throw a party! I listen when a coin whispers, ‘Time to go.’ I help it live, never trap its spirit. Coins come to visit. We dance, bask in starlight and sunshine, share adventures and fine meals—dancing, singing—when they’re ready, off they go. New journeys, new tales. Hosting isn’t greed, it’s pure joy.” As Arafis spoke, Kaelith noticed the coins on the table seemed to shift—just a little. A silver coin spun lazily near the candlelight (wasn't that his missing silver?); a copper gave a faint, contented jingle. For a moment, he wondered if he imagined it, then looked back to Arafis. Arafis pointed at the gold coin in Kaelith’s hand, his last coin, its shine catching the candlelight. “Your coin—it’s happy.” Kaelith snorted, rolling the coin between his fingers, skeptical but amused. “Happy? It’s a coin, Arafis!” Arafis’s grin widened. “Oh yes! It’s singing about your adventures—deserts, gravehordes, kraken-filled seas, wild market chases. It loves traveling with you, Kaelith. Coins jump into your pockets for the thrill.” Kaelith held up his lone coin, arching an eyebrow. “If my pockets are so thrilling, why do coins never stick around long enough to keep me rich?” Siania just laughed, shaking her head. “Maybe because you spend them faster than they can tell their stories.” Arafis only smiled wider, tail curling with mischief. “The value of a coin isn’t in keeping it. It’s in your journey together—all the stories you both collect along the way. Your coins aren’t lost, Kaelith, they’re bursting with excitement to share their adventures. The moment they have a good tale and the chance, they slip away to brag where they were, telling everyone, ‘You have to see the world with Kaelith!’ That’s why you’re always down to one! Your coins are too excited, vain enough to crave legend, but loyal enough to care. Don’t worry. One day they’ll circle back to you with even more stories, or you might find something even better.” Kaelith’s smile faded, his voice sharp. “Yes, but what about when I’m hungry? My missing fortune off on its gossip tour can’t fill my empty stomach.” Arafis grinned, tapping the coin in Kaelith’s hand, its worn edges catching the light. “What you want and what you need? Oh, those are different, Kaelith. You want a mountain of shinies—very human!—but need? That’s a meal, a friend, a lucky break. Those show up when you need them most. If the world is a story, it always gives its boldest heroes just enough to keep going. Have you ever truly gone hungry? No. Something always turns up—a crust of bread, a kind stranger. That’s where the best adventures begin!” He leaned in, eyes soft. “I know it feels hard for a human, having just one coin—humans — your hoarders by nature… lack of coins, that’s no curse. It means your life’s so big, coins can’t keep up. The world looks after its boldest guests. You’re never empty-handed when you’ve got adventures and stories.” “And this one? Look at it! So old, all its decoration worn away by time and adventure. It’s seen more journeys and adventurers than most coins ever dream of. The others, after a taste of your wild life, hurry off to brag in new pockets! But this coin’s different. It’s patient, it’s loyal. It stays—not for lack of chance, but because it knows real worth isn’t in how new it looks, but in the story it carries. If it didn’t believe you were meant for something truly grand, it would have slipped away long ago. Instead, it waits for the tale that outshines all the rest, because it knows your best stories are still ahead! Few have such a mark of confidence.” Arafis’s words settled over Kaelith. The young adventurer still longed for a fortune to keep him safe, not yet seeing the universe’s sparkling magic. A Toast to Stories and Shiny Guests If only Kaelith could see the world’s grand dance—coins jingling for joy, the universe always providing—he’d know he was never truly alone. Poor humans, Arafis mused, so often lonely. Even the bravest saw coins as objects, not guests. They feared being left without treasure, believing wealth was their only shield against uncertainty. Yet Arafis saw things differently. The imp’s eyes sparkled as he explained, “Every coin, every trinket, every pastry is a guest—a visitor with stories to share. Treasures aren’t meant to be locked away, growing stale and sad. They’re meant to travel, to dance from hand to hand, gathering legends and laughter. When you treat your coins as prisoners, you lose the magic. You become a jailer, not an adventurer. The imp’s way is to let go—to trust that the world is a grand inn, always sending new guests your way. When you share your wealth—spend a coin on a friend, give a gift, buy a meal—you set your treasures free, and they return with new stories, luck, and adventures. You stop fearing emptiness, because the world provides for those who live boldly and generously. Don’t let fear make you cold and still. Let your coins dance, let your stories flow. Live for adventure, not the hoard—that’s the imp’s way, and the secret to a life that never runs dry of magic.” Arafis’s tail twitched, his voice firming. “Hoarders are worse. They lock coins in safes—fancy prisons. Coins want to move, to shine, not rot in the dark.
