Valerius, the ultimate realist, must now gamble on something beyond his usual calculus: redemption and magic. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>The Dangerous Shift in His Thinking</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[From Survival to Sacrifice:] He has always had an exit strategy. Now, he must consider that there may be no escape—only a fight that could consume him and his house. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Ultimate Test of Pragmatism:] If he backs Siania, he risks everything. If he doesn’t, he ensures House Kren’s slow death under Severin’s shadow. His usual tools—poison, espionage, economic sabotage—may not be enough against magic. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Elven Magic Factor:] If Siania truly embodies the old magic, then this isn’t just a succession crisis. It’s a battle for the soul of the empire. And Valerius, the man who has always played the game, must now decide if he’s willing to burn the board, and take a bet on unpredictable magic.... (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Conclusion: A Man at the Crossroads</h2>] Valerius is being forced to evolve beyond the cynical operator he has always been. The question is no longer how to survive—it’s what is worth dying for? And for the first time in his life, he might have an answer. —does he fully commit to Siania’s cause, or does he retreat into the safety of House Kren’s interests? Or does he find some brutal middle path, where he sacrifices his own morality to ensure her victory or find a way to ensure it while protecting his morality? (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>3. Why Doesn’t Valerius Just Kill Vestergaard Now?</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Risk of exposure:] If he acts too soon, the Order will retaliate against House Kren. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Need for Siania’s cooperation:] If she’s a potential ally, eliminating Vestergaard before securing her loyalty could backfire. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Waiting for the right moment:] Assassination is a last resort—he’s gathering intel first. Purhaps there is another way... He hopes so for his own humanity. Logical Consistency: ✔ Yes—his hesitation is strategic, not cowardly. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>5. The False Molar: Practicality?</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Last-resort weapon:] It’s not for daily use—it’s a suicide pill if captured. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Undetectable:] If the court has poison-sniffing hounds or mages, this could be a flaw—but if not, it’s plausible. Logical Consistency: ⚠ Debatable—depends on how thorough security is. - thorough security checks are possible but resource-intensive and not consistently applied. This is a key point. The court could implement stricter measures, but the cost (in manpower, resources, and disruption) is deemed too high until a certain threshold of incidents is reached. This is analogous to real-world safety regulations that are often reactive rather than proactive. - Valerius's skill in detecting threats is rare, making him a valuable asset but also highlighting the general lack of vigilance. - The perception of the court as a "perfectly safe place" is a calculated risk, a facade maintained to lull potential threats into complacency. The Emperor’s tournament is not a game to Valerius—it is the opening salvo in a war for survival. While the court fixates on duels and feasts, he tracks the flow of grain and iron with the desperation of a besieged commander. His allegiance is absolute: Siania’s Tirianian bloodline is the rightful heir, and House Kren’s very existence hinges on shattering Severin’s stranglehold on the empire. Every concession wrung by Count Vestergaard—every trade pact signed under duress—is a nail in Kren’s coffin. The border garrisons are not merely being denied luxuries; they are being starved of the iron needed to forge weapons and the grain to feed their soldiers, leaving Kren’s lands and allies vulnerable to raiders and invasion. Valerius sees the truth: Severin’s greed is not just weakening Kren, it is tearing the kingdom apart, demanding Vestergaard divert vital resources to their coffers while Kren’s borders crumble. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>What Valerius Needs from Siania:</h2>] 1. Can she inspire? Will soldiers and nobles rally behind her? 2. Is she strong? Can she handle war, or will she crack under pressure? 3. Is she smart? Can she outplay Severin in court and on the battlefield? 4. Can she neutralize Vestergaard? His trade deals are strangling Kren—she must break his alliance with Severin. If Siania fails, Valerius will abandon her and find another way to save Kren. If she proves herself, he’ll back her fully—even if it means open rebellion. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>His Plan:</h2>] - Short-term: Steal, bribe, and threaten to keep Kren’s supplies flowing. - Medium-term: Stoke rebellion among Tirianian loyalists, ready to rise if Siania wins. - Long-term: If she loses, burn Severin’s trade networks and vanish Vestergaard’s caravans. If she can't do these things, she's useless to House Kren. Valerius will find another way to survive. If she can, he'll back her all the way, even if it means war. He's betting everything on whether she's a real leader or just a pretty face with a famous bloodline. He has no illusions. If the Severin-Vestergaard alliance solidifies, Kren’s defenses will collapse within months, their people left to the mercy of bandits and rival houses. So he fights on multiple fronts. Short-term, he uses every trick at his disposal—bribes, threats, outright theft—to keep Kren’s supply lines open, even as Severin’s agents close in. Medium-term, he fans the flames of rebellion among the Tirianian loyalists, preparing them to rise behind Siania when the moment is right. And long-term? He is ready to unleash chaos, disrupting Severin’s trade routes and ensuring Vestergaard’s convoys vanish into the wilderness. House Kren will not be allowed to wither and die. They will fight—for their lands, for their people, and for a ruler who understands that a kingdom is only as strong as its borders, and its borders are only as strong as its supply lines. The tournament will determine his next move: open rebellion if Siania prevails, or a shadow war of sabotage and assassination if she falls. Either way, Valerius will ensure that Severin’s greed chokes on its own ambition. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Early Life</h2>] Born into a minor branch of House Kren, Valerius was raised on the restive northern border, where loyalty was enforced by steel as much as blood. His childhood was marked by skirmishes with rival houses and the ever-present threat of Severin-backed raids—lessons in survival that shaped his pragmatism. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Training & Formative Years</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Martial Education:] Sent to Kren’s military academy at 14, he excelled in blade-work and tactical games but showed greater aptitude for psychological warfare. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Poison & Politics:] A near-fatal poisoning during his first diplomatic mission (allegedly by a Severin agent) left him with a permanent distrust of banquets and a habit of carrying antidotes. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Rise Through Shadows:] Earned his council seat not by birthright but by uncovering a plot against House Kren’s matriarch—a feat achieved through blackmail, not bloodshed. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Current Role</h2>] Now Kren’s foremost "whisper and dagger" diplomat, Valerius operates where courts and battlefields blur. His reputation: a man who smiles while calculating six exits from every room. But his true allegiance—to House Kren’s survival, not its honor—makes him both indispensable and dangerous. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Defining Quote:</h2>] "Battles are won with steel, but wars are won with grain shipments and diplomacy. The wise know this; the victorious exploit it." "Steel breaks armies, but grain breaks kingdoms." We hold the harvest, thus we hold the throne "Feed the people and they'll ignore your knives." Echoes real-world historical strategies (siege warfare, Roman annona, modern sanctions) Lasting conquest requires controlling supply lines or starving dissent (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Points</h2>] Councillor Valerius of House Kren (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Political Strategist:] Highly skilled in political manoeuvring, as evidenced by his calculated movements and awareness of courtly games. However, his strategic thinking is primarily focused on the interests of House Kren, potentially limiting his objectivity. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Loyal to House Kren:] Deeply invested in the power and security of House Kren, particularly concerning their border fortresses. However, this loyalty makes him biased against any alliance that would strengthen the imperial line or the Order of Severin at Kren's expense. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Suspicious of the Order of Severin:] Aware of the Order's schemes and their potential impact on House Kren. However, his knowledge is incomplete, forcing him to consider both spying and potential threats to his own life. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Supporter of a Tirianian Heir:] Believes Siania ne'Tiriania has a legitimate claim to the throne and sees her as a potential disruptor of the current power structure. However, this support is conditional, dependent on her ability to weaken the Order of Severin and potentially benefit House Kren. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Pragmatic and Ruthless:] Willing to consider extreme measures, including violence, to protect House Kren's interests. However, he is also cautious, aware of the risks involved in such actions and the need for discretion. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Observant and Detail-Oriented:] Pays close attention to the actions and motivations of others, memorizing gestures and glances for his reports. However, his interpretations may be influenced by his own biases and the limited information available to him. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Combat & Tactical Expertise</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Trained in Self-Defense (Likely Blades or Dueling):] His stance—dominant side angled toward exits, weight subtly balanced—suggests formal combat training, possibly in courtly dueling or military tactics. However, whether he is a master or merely proficient is unclear. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Aware of Assassination Methods:] Recognizes poison symptoms (froth, blackened lips) and carries an antidote, implying either personal experience with courtly poisonings or intelligence training. However, his reliance on antidotes suggests caution rather than mastery of poisons himself. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Prepared for Sudden Violence:] His instinctive readiness (fingers brushing hidden antidote, assessing Vestergaard’s sword-handling) indicates he expects threats. Yet, his restraint suggests he prefers subterfuge over direct confrontation. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Political & Intelligence Background</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Espionage-Capable:] Considers infiltrating the Order of Severin by "playing the fool," implying skill in deception. However, his internal anger at Vestergaard risks compromising his cover if unchecked. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Resource Strategist:] Understands supply lines (iron, grain) as political leverage, tying economics to military power. Yet, his focus on House Kren’s needs may blind him to broader alliances. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Risk-Assessment Mindset:] Weighs assassination as an option ("accidents happen") but hesitates, indicating a strategist’s patience rather than a killer’s impulsivity. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Psychological Profile</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Controlled but Not Emotionless:] Clenches fists, lips thin—he feels anger but channels it into calculation. This discipline suggests training, but his tells (tightened chest, jaw) hint at pressure points an enemy could exploit. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Cynical Realist:] Dismisses court narratives (e.g., "dysentery" cover-ups) and embraces brutal pragmatism. However, his fixation on Siania’s Tirianian bloodline risks ideological bias. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Potential Weaknesses</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Overestimates His Influence:] Assumes he can manipulate events (spying, disrupting Vestergaard), but the Order of Severin may already be steps ahead. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Physical Tells:] Subtle tension (fist-clenching, jaw) could betray him in high-stakes negotiations. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Conclusion</h2>] Valerius is a lethal hybrid—part diplomat, part spymaster, with the reflexes of a survivor. But his loyalty to House Kren may be both his driving force and his blind spot. [[Emperor Lucius IV (Tharion)]] [[Ash]] [[Court Envoys/Figures]] [[Order of Severin]] [[Jaro]] [[Tarek]] [[Lady Vestergaard]] [[Count Vestergaard (Son)]] [[Agamar]] [[Kaleith]] [[Arafis (Aryfis)]] [[Halak (Rasha’ni Chief)]] [[Draethlyn (Giant Spiders) ]] [[Siania]] [[Aelira]] Emperor Lucius IV (Tharion) Role/Stance: Imperial authority, originally a brilliant commander named Tharion who rises to Emperor with hope, but becomes a tragic, corrupted figure under Azaroth’s influence. Driven by grief over Aelira’s death and a desperate bargain to resurrect her, Tharion fragments his mind to resist Azaroth, creating the innocent psychic fragment, Ash, while he transforms into Lucius IV—a ruler in a Machiavellian world where harsh punishments, threats, and enforced power dominate over earned loyalty. His stance toward Siania is one of sacrificial love hidden beneath ruthless control—he exiles her to Fort Kezarak in the southern desert to protect her from his darkening soul and the brutal political landscape, though she perceives it as rejection. Early on, before slipping too far into cruelty, Tharion leaves instructions for subtle support at the fort before breaking off his psyche, where loyalist guards and officers shield gatherings of hope, allowing Kren caravans—to bring gifts of dates, stories of her fallen House Ne’Tiriania, and flickers of inspiration for Siania and other children. He also leaves instructions for a courier to deliver a personal treasure - through House Kren—her mother’s ring (chosen by her mother as a gift for her 16th birthday), a secret emblem of her heritage. These acts, planned before he loses capacity to Azaroth’s influence, reflect his deep desire to bolster her courage and preserve her lineage’s hope, even as he can no longer sustain such efforts. In the final chapters, his corrupted self is a puppet of Severin and Azaroth until Siania’s psychic battle breaks their hold. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): As Lucius IV, he poses a formidable threat through his calculated cruelty and iron grip on power, capable of crushing Siania’s rebellion if not freed from Severin and Azaroth’s control. During the psychic battle in the temple’s mindscape, the merging of Ash with the Emperor allows for his redemption, expelling Azaroth and restoring the temple. This act transforms him from a ruthless antagonist to a redeemed figure, though at great personal cost, sacrificing his life along with ash. ensure Siania’s victory and the city’s future. His early efforts to protect and inspire Siania through the fort’s loyalist network and her mother’s ring underscore the depth of his love, shaping her resilience and the realm’s renewal, even as his role as Emperor ends to make way for a future consort. (with his uncorrupted will driven through House Kren and Valerius who are the personification of the emperor after his ‘death’) Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance (or Redemption): Avoid aligning with loyalists openly until the end to prevent early failure as a figurehead. Siania must navigate the psychic battle with Ash’s guidance to break Severin’s magical hold over Lucius IV, fighting their corruption *and gaining more understanding of why he became evil. Uncovering Tharion’s true intentions through House Kren and Ash (last chapter)— Sianias capture in the catacombs will allow the merging of Ash and the Emperor, leading to Azaroth’s expulsion and Tharion’s redemption. This act, supported by allies like Valerius, ensures the realm’s stability and Siania’s rise as a symbol of hope, countering the harsh Machiavellian rule Lucius IV enforced while honoring the hidden gestures of love he left behind. Ash (Psychic Fragment of Tharion) The Creation of Ash Tharion realizes he's being used by dark forces He understands he's becoming a danger to the kingdom and his daughter In a desperate act to limit the damage he can cause, he decides to split his mind He performs a ritual to create Ash, fragmenting his consciousness This makes him "less useful" psychically to his manipulators He sacrifices his compassion and true self to protect what remains of his kingdom Role/Stance: Potential ally, the innocent psychic fragment of Tharion created during his forbidden ritual to fragment his mind and resist Azaroth’s possession. Ash embodies the uncorrupted essence of Tharion’s love and protective instincts for Siania, acting as a mysterious guide or guardian. Their stance is supportive but conditional, testing Siania’s worthiness and resolve to ensure she can carry forward the bloodline’s legacy and heal the city’s curse. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Ash could be a critical ally in Siania’s journey, offering guidance, hidden truths about Tharion’s sacrifices, or spiritual power in key confrontations, especially in the desert or against Azaroth’s influence. If Siania fails to prove her strength or honor, Ash may remain distant or neutral, withholding vital knowledge or support at crucial moments. Their alliance could reveal the depth of Tharion’s love and shape Siania’s understanding of her exile, influencing her emotional and strategic decisions in the climax. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Siania must demonstrate resilience, honor, and compassion in the face of Ash’s who guides her through the painful history of her family. protecting Ash—recognizing them as a fragment of her father’s true self—will require a commitment to understanding Tharion’s burdens. Protecting Ash from Azaroth’s reach the Order of Severin will solidify their role as a steadfast ally, potentially unlocking key revelations about the bloodline and the temple’s curse. House Kren or Lady Vestergaard Court Envoys/Figures Role/Stance: Representatives of imperial power, political influencers aligned with Lucius’s court, often driven by personal gain or loyalty to the throne. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Likely to support Siania if she gains favor and Torren aligns with duty; may undermine or oppose if loyalty is questioned or weakness is shown, potentially siding with rival houses or the Order of Severin. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Siania must gain support from House Kren and key diplomats like Valerius. If Torren remains too closely tied to the Emperor, it complicates working with loyalists and aiding Vestergaard to secure critical documents for Kren Valerius, weakening potential court support. [[Councillor Valerius of House Kren]] [[Lady Vestergaard]] Order of Severin Role/Stance: Shadowy faction seeking control, views Siania as a threat due to her bloodline and potential to disrupt their plans. Obsessed with uniting Vestergaard and Ne’Tiriania bloodlines for their own ends, making them relentless hunters of Siania. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Already targeting her bloodline, they will hunt her down if she rises as a loyalist queen. Antagonistic if Siania proves strong and uncontrollable; may underestimate or manipulate if she appears weak or dishonorable. Their influence could doom her or the rebellion if not countered. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance (or Counter Them): Siania’s actions must inspire loyalty among allies to counteract the fear and terror Severin inflicts on houses suspected of aiding her. She must remain largely hidden, working through Torren, Jaro, Valerius, Tarek, and other allies to avoid direct confrontation until the climax.Role/Stance: Comrade, secondary influence, loyal to Torren and Siania, part of their tight-knit group at Fort Kezarak. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Likely to aid if Torren prioritizes Siania and fort bonds; may grow distant or indifferent if duty to the Emperor overrides personal ties. His support is crucial in protecting Vestergaard during key escapes. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Jaro will follow Torren and Tarek wherever they go, akin to the Three Musketeers with Jaro as the lovable D’Artagnan. His loyalty is reinforced by shared history and trust in Siania’s cause. Role/Stance: Comrade, fort ally, values loyalty, part of the core group with Torren and Jaro. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Similar to Jaro, likely to support if Torren focuses on protecting Siania; potential indifference if imperial duty dominates. His presence strengthens the loyalist efforts in critical moments. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Siania’s actions must appeal to and inspire Tarek. Leading by example and showing commitment to their shared bonds will secure his unwavering support alongside Torren and Jaro. Lady Vestergaard Role/Stance: Machiavellian enemy, seeks to isolate Siania to control her as a pawn for her son’s ascension. Opposes Siania under all circumstances but needs her alive to secure the crown for her son, ruling through him. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Antagonistic, delighted by Siania’s weakness or dishonor as it makes her easier to manipulate without allies. Her schemes could derail Siania’s fate and the rebellion if not thwarted. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance (or Counter Her): Avoid her schemes by leveraging other alliances and actions. Exposing her plot against the Emperor and Siania through Vestergaard’s evidence can neutralize her influence in the final conflict. [[Count Vestergaard (Son)]] Count Vestergaard (Son) Role/Stance: Potential noble ally, a good man despite his evil mother, torn between duty and personal honor. Develops a complex bond with Siania, falling in love with her strength and defiance, though bound by political contracts. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): May offer aid or sympathy if Siania shows strength or honor, though limited by his mother’s influence; ambivalent or disappointed if weakness or dishonor is shown. His support could be pivotal in securing evidence against his mother and aiding the rebellion, impacting Siania’s fate and the empire’s future. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Avoid killing him, allow him to escort Siania back to the fort when necessary, and talk him through his duty to realize his need to escape with her. Building a personal connection and showing mutual defiance against corrupt systems will solidify his alliance. [[Councillor Valerius of House Kren]] Role/Stance: Potential ally, noble, ancient sorceress related by bloodline to Siania from millennia ago. A mystic with deep ties to the desert and spiders, offering sanctuary and knowledge. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Will aid Siania in the desert, but without spider allegiance or if spiders are killed, she lacks the necessary support as bodyguards, leading to her death and Siania’s failure. Her survival and alliance are critical for Siania’s desert journey and magical growth. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Initially aids Siania, but securing spider allegiance (building a relationship, not just saving them from Scar Marshals) is essential for Agamar’s protection and success in aiding Siania through the desert challenges. Role/Stance: Potential ally, pirate prince, internally noble, displaced royalty living as an adventurer (Sinbad/Prince of Persia type). A roguish figure with a hidden sense of honor. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Can provide crucial hiding spots in Talin at the pirate inn if allied, preventing Siania’s capture upon entry to the city. His support offers a strategic base for urban operations in the climax. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Free him from captivity, show worth beyond just a title, and give him a cause to believe in. Leading by example can push him toward greater deeds than usual, as he typically avoids “causes.”Arafis (Aryfis) Role/Stance: Potential ally, imp, chaotic, random, a source of hilarity, annoyance, and added danger, but lovable. A mischievous companion with unique perspectives on treasure and stories. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): If allied, provides valuable information on Siania’s capture, ensuring the group can infiltrate the citadel to rescue her. His chaotic nature can turn the tide in unexpected ways during critical moments. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Free him, tolerate his impish quirks, visiting, and chaos, and build a relationship with him. Caring for him and leading by example will inspire bravery, making him a key informant and ally.Role/Stance: Spymaster and diplomat, loyal to Siania’s Ne’Tiriania bloodline, a pragmatic figure seeking to root out court corruption and support a legitimate rebellion. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Critical to the rebellion’s success, offering strategic leverage and resources if Siania survives as a symbol of legitimacy. His alliance can unite fractured houses against Lucius and Severin, shaping the empire’s fate. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Support his covert operations, protect Siania as the true heir, and secure Vestergaard’s evidence against Lady Vestergaard and Severin. Building trust through shared goals of justice and reform will cement his commitment. Halak (Rasha’ni Chief) Role/Stance: Desert ally, leader of the Rasha’ni tribe, bound by a debt of honor to Siania for saving his daughter. A solemn protector offering sanctuary. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Provides shelter to Vestergaard and loyalists in the desert, crucial for their survival and strategic regrouping. His camp in the Bleak Peaks can be a turning point for rebellion planning if secured. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Present the bone hare toggle to Halak with the message “Siania of the Fort sends a friend needing the wind’s shadow.” His recognition of the debt ensures protection for Vestergaard and allies like Jaro, Torren, and Tarek.Draethlyn (Giant Spiders) Role/Stance: Childlike, pony-sized spider allies, tied to Siania and Agamar through trust and ancient bonds. Gentle farmers with conditional passivity unless defending directly. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Essential bodyguards for Agamar and Siania in the desert; without their allegiance, Agamar’s death and Siania’s failure are likely. Their support offers protection and tactical advantages in key confrontations. Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance: Build a relationship beyond mere rescue from Scar Marshals—show kindness, earn trust, and integrate their fragmented memories into Siania’s journey. Protecting them from slavers and hunters solidifies their loyalty.V. The Era of Lucius IV / Tharion 1. Tharion and Aelira's Love Early relationship and marriage Aelira's awareness of the bloodline's significance and the temple's importance Their hopes for their daughter's future Tharion watches Aelira move through the garden, sunlight catching in her hair. For a moment—just a moment—he forgets the weight of the crown, the whispers of the court, the shadows that seem to follow him. "You're staring again," she says without turning. "How could I not?" he replies, and the smile she gives him is worth every burden. Later, as they walk the palace grounds, she takes his hand. "There's something I must tell you," she says, her voice low. "About the temple. About our child's future." But a messenger interrupts, and the moment passes. It will be weeks before she tries again—weeks that change everything. 2. Of Death and Dying Background: darkened palace bedroom. Prince Tharion weeps in silent shuddering bursts. His wife is dying. There is nothing he can do to ease her suffering. "These gods of yours!" He continues, "Why do they torment me, how is it to be borne! To be a commander yet, still a slave to the whim of fate!" He pauses, thwarted in his powerlessness. Looking at his strong hands in contempt. "How is one to barter or be an equal with such masters as this..." His tears fall despairingly. "What good is a crown if I can't be with thee my love, if I cannot protect you." The once beautiful Aelira has almost passed, only a whisper of her strength remains. She holds onto him to steady his tears. The poison had been fast acting, and its damage irreversible, there is nothing that the healers can do to stop its course. "All is as it should be, have faith my love." She pauses gathering her strength. "If you cannot continue for yourself, remember our daughter. She needs you." She holds his hand in comfort, Leaning together in silent tears of exhaustion. They both draw strength from each other, aware of the small time remaining to them. And the unfairness of it all. His voice shakes. "I cannot let you go.., not yet, please not yet..." A sob escapes Tharion. He bows his head on her shoulder in silent quaking. His desperation growing. "I will find who did this." 3. Voices in the Dark (Severin's Plotting) Background: The catacombs, Severin's throne room Hidden deep beneath the city, the chamber exudes an air of opulent malevolence. Ornate decorations do little to dispel the oppressive sense of anguish and devastation that permeates the space. Eerily carved friezes, depicting scenes of torment and struggle, gaze down from the ceiling, guiding the eye towards the vast circular room inscribed with cryptic glyphs. Doors, recessed evenly in heavy arches, glower like sullen lidless eyes. Before each door, shadowed life-sized plinths display diabolic creatures frozen in moments of torment or poised to strike. These figures loom seven to eight feet tall, their towering forms unmistakably humanoid yet twisted by some forgotten nightmare. Their long, powerful arms end in cruel, curved claws, and their faces are elongated and fleshless-more skull than visage, with hollow, shadowed eyes and sharp, bird-like beaks that hint at an insatiable hunger. Their skin is a dark ash color, dry and rough like ancient stone. Their bodies are lean and sinewy, built for speed, with legs that taper into reptilian claws, and long, whip-like tails that curl along their spines. Plate-like structures, resembling a grotesque natural armor, stud their backs and limbs, glinting dully in the eerie light. Their expressions are frozen in silent agony or predatory anticipation, a silent, watchful army encircling the central throne, bearing the weight of eternity, indomitable in their watchfulness and pain. [Threaded through the chamber's architecture, the ancient geometric patterns-interlocking circles, sigils of balance, and celestial motifs-are still visible, but now they are cruelly defiled. The new corruption is not content to simply obscure the old beauty; instead, jagged, mocking glyphs are carved through and around the original designs, twisting symbols of harmony into warped parodies and turning motifs of protection into snares and spirals of torment. This blasphemous weaving calculated to wound those who cherished this place, turning memory of beauty, light, and unity into a source of anguish. A relentless, living reminder of the sacred harmony that has been desecrated and lost.] The mirrored proportions of the chamber, reflected in the flawless obsidian, amplify the crystal's dominance, imposing its will upon all who enter. The floor's liquid blackness shimmers with a strange and surprising brilliance, shifting and undulating like opal in the night, an ebb and flow of an ancient, cosmic power. Its solid, impenetrable surface dissolves into swirls of inky darkness and shimmering opalescent light, like distant galaxies collapsing and reforming, a panorama of time shown by the majestic conquests of the stars. But above this universe rests the central arch, where a dominating crystal outcropping converges, its massive size and slightly green colouring creating an imposing presence. It hangs sharply with menace, its jagged edges and points seeming to drip with an almost tangible threat. The crystal's pale green hue deepens towards its core, where it shimmers with a cold, otherworldly radiance, suggesting a flow of energy drawn from the city above, channelled and concentrated within this chamber. In it, and in the very air itself, you sense a concentrated air of malice—a darkness that clings in oily maleficence to every surface, and beneath the silence, the faintest echo of dimensional duality—a nexus point where overlaid realms press against each other, their separation thin and fragile. The air crackles with an unnatural tension, hinting at the immense power gathered here, a gateway poised to tear open the fabric of reality, bridging the gap between worlds. An indefinable vaporous presence, born of this concentrated energy, speaks. "You must get him to agree. In only a few days he will become king. We must turn him before then!" The vaporous voice, emanating from the heart of the crystal, echoes through the chamber, carrying a weight of ancient malice. The cowled figure, barely discernible in the gloom, bowed its head. "I shall, my lord. He won't risk losing her. They are bound. He will agree to whatever we offer!" A cruel smile twisted his lips, revealing a set of sharpened teeth. "Tharion trusts me." A flicker of unease passed through the shadows, The inky blackness of the floor. It's eternal mirror, rippling in a new found energy and trajectory. "You must bring him here, but only if he agrees to our terms." The oppressive weight of power ripples and distorts the air, a tangible manifestation of the entity's malevolence. "His cooperation must be certain..." A moment of silence hung heavy in the air, broken only by the faint echo of distant screams - a discordant, otherworldly counterpoint to the chamber's oppressive stillness, pressing into the room. A chilling reminder of the power emanating from the crystal above. The oppressive weight of power ripples and distorts the air as it continues as a cold afterthought. "Otherwise take his daughter.., She may be useful." The voice pauses considering. "It is desirable we keep him alive, everyone has their use... until they don't." 4. A Bargain Made Background: darkened palace bedroom. "We give you a choice, we promise to bring back your wife to you. In return you must serve our master, He who grants power beyond all you can imagine. The choice is simple! You can let your wife die. Or, you can bring her back from death." Tharion is conflicted, not only is he surprised at the messenger but also of the message. He knows of the followers of Severin and their dominion over death itself. But he had always considered it gossip of the superstitious, or the ignorant. To have the power of the gods.., To have an equal say in fate. Never again just a pawn, or to be powerless. Surely this is what he had been praying for. "It may be true what you say," He says somewhat doubtfully. "But what proof do you have that you can perform such a miracle?" The Lord Chancellor summons his attendant. A lifeless bird is brought in front of him. Not to be disrespectful to the dead. Prince Tharion examines it thoroughly, but with care. There is no trick, surely the bird is dead. The eyes are sunken a blue pearly grey the membranes dried now sit like damp paper unarranged over soulless orbs. The bird lies limply and cold in his cupped in his numb hands. On them, the attendant places the heartstone, its crystalline surface a brilliant red violet, refracts lights in geometric beauty, shining with power. The heartstone is warm and soothing against his flesh. As Tharion listens he can hear and see the bird happily flying within the stone. Its essence is protected and maintained within the precious jewel. The assistant then places the heartstone onto the bird. Incredibly the taught dry skin begins to colour with new found vitality, life returns like an essence to fill the skin of the bird's skull, the eyes become clear and sharp alert. It comes to life! Tucking its wings up and looking about while drawing power from the stone. When finally strengthened, it flies off. Unaware of the marvel just performed. "You see how easy it is my lord?, Even though your wife is dead. She could still be revived. The oily voice pauses, of course, we should give you time to think about it." "I don't need time to think, and I'm not interested if you can do this with a bird, Show me if it really can be done. Bring back my wife." "We shall fulfill your desire, my lord". The Lord Chancellor smiles and bows deeply. The Corrupted Return Aelira is brought back, but Tharion gradually realizes something is wrong The "revived" Aelira is a corrupted version of his wife Tharion becomes increasingly isolated and distrustful He sends his daughter away for "education," following advice from his counselors He begins to understand he's made a terrible bargain and is to blame A pact Tharion, although blindfolded, is aware a large circular room. Somnolescent voices drone in a chant. The sound panning out, around a vast area. Echos rise upward into blank silence. There is an eager anticipation to the room, prickling expectancy. His strong hands hover flat palmed over his sword. The sword of ages. The blade is held silently like an offering, or a sacrifice. While the two attendants holding the sword stand rigid and unmoving. With only an unhearable prayer on their lips. All are listening to the high chancellor chant. In the blackness, his voice takes on an otherworldly quality. The words come in finality, as a pledge. An unbreakable promise. There is something about this scene, it weighs on you; You can feel a split in the fabric of it. A veil of duplicity. Not everything here is visible. You focus on the words Paying more attention. The hue of them, the grouping. And it is there you feel the mental underlay. Brushing away its deceptions you pull all the hidden meaning into view, back into a whole form. As spoken and thought by the speaker. The memory plays again, you re-watch the Chancellor intone. “I will return all that you love,” In thought the Chancellor adds, “Broken and in torment.” “You will thank and worship me..,” “Regardless, you low, wretched martyr...” “Your love of life and its continuity..,” “A canker, defiling all you treasure.” “Your kindness wielded is a force for light..,” “Monumental in its horror. You shall debase all you love.” “Therefore, I treasure you..,” “Nothing could be more broken and disfigured.” “Because, you are like me. We are one.” The Chancellor intones again. “... And will you King Tharion, hold your promises given to us?” Tharion slumps his shoulders slightly and heavily replies. “The things which I have here before promised, I will perform, and keep.” You can sense a silent prayer and discouragement, along with desperation. But he holds his tongue in silence. The ancient blade glows as if enraged, then fades from sight. As if it has forsaken him, or been banished. <Note to self: in its place a near perfect replica of the sword is placed, this sword is tainted, and will not identify the corrupt officials of followers of severin, including now the king, within the kings court, neither can the give the king the power to know who they are in case he would try to betray them> In finality, the Lord Chancellor speaks. “Then it shall be as you wish...” “He was deceived!” You mouth to yourself, the slight power in your voice barely vocalises the words. A presence with deep regret can be felt but it quickly snaps off and vanishes. The voice snickers, “You’d like to think so.., you self commiserating little rat.” “But I’ll have you know..,” He pauses with relish. “Such promises can only be made if they are known and agreed to! Never make deals with the devil, As it was he that invented contracts!” You perceive a misty form capering around you mockingly. Leaning in sharply, it whispers musically…, “What he didn’t know, was just how much the chancellor hated him!… Memories.., Ahhh!. So en-ter-tain-ing!” With several mocking flourishes, He skips off back, fading into the blackness! Coronation of the Sun “Once again from above, with waves I do forment, I incite the waters and lead them ashore the gray torrent. Frothing in torment fights with the wall. Where the shadow stands watchful The ridge over the deep; Then obscured behind it blended with the sea comes another surge.” The day of the coronation brings excited and grateful crowds. Prince Tharion is admired across the land, as noble and brave. His wife the elegant Lady Aelira stands together with him lovingly, Holding their baby, the princess Siania. The final lines of the ceremony flow into the crowd, marking a new age. “… And so receive this kingly sword, The sword of ages, in innocence and judgment, as a proof of the gods’ protection; and also as an emblem of a promise that binds you with your nation, its lands and people. Be strong and of good courage, that you may be a king of our age in justice and glory!” The blade signifies acceptance of him, as of pure heart and true. It is a blade that can never lie.<Note to self: highlight it as a fake sword in Aeliras dreams, They iterate with new details each time, to finally reveal the truth> Finally to the crowd the Lord Chancellor turns. “And you dear people, we ask for your recognition. All who come this day to do homage and service. Are you willing to do the same, and have this man as your king?” Tharion has for years been a respected leader, holding the region strong through battles or famine. All feel proud and confident to have such a king. In these thoughts, The People proclaim their enthusiasm with joy, by loud and repeated acclamations. All with one voice crying out. Solemnly the crown is placed on Tharion. He steps forward gravely and bows weighted and thoughtful, almost as if in penitence. His blade flashing magnificently, its elven crated metal swirls with power as he holds it high in the spring sun. In resolution of the ceremony, trumpets ring true and clear, accompanied by a flock of white birds soaring up into the sky. With light hearts red rose petals fall in scented showers touching servants and nobles alike, bonding them in joy. “Red.., the colour of sacrifice..,” the voice mocks in ironic mirth. Rebirth of the moon <Notes to self Rebirth of the moon: The queen has a night mare, and realises she had died But doesnt yet realisewhat has happend, Tharion deal etc, but instead worries she may be losing her mind> It is the day of the coronation. The Lord Chancellor’s words ring above all. “Be strong and of good courage, that you may be a king of our age in justice and glory!” Theodoric’s words ring in acceptance of this command with vibrancy, The words echo and fade, distorted against the columns of the mighty cathedral. Looking at the crowd, Aelira is buoyed by the joyful faces she sees, looking at him in tenderness. Luminous and effervescent crowds. The velvety rose petals fall, their fragrance sweet and enduring. A small peasant boy runs smiling at her. In his hands a hidden gift which he imparts to her wordlessly, with solemn innocence. She opens her cupped hands to reveal a small dead bird. In shock she looks up, back to the boy. He studies her face with sadness. His eyes dark and wise, aged with care.., seemingly at congruities with such a young body. He seems to fade back into himself somehow. Leaving the young boy to run off. In revulsion she stares at the dead bird, her hands feel immobile, unable to release the corpse to the ground. The flesh is Rotten and pustulant, pocked with small maggots moving within the thin shell of semitransparent skin. They feast uninterrupted, indifferent to her horror. However, It is the coldness of the body that shocks her, the emptiness so consuming... Almost as if she is being sucked into the blackness. It draws her in... Queen Aelira wakes sharply. “I died.., I am sure it is so.” She scans back to her last memories, although clouded... She felt the hopelessness of her sickness and final acceptance of death. In the last days she had welcomed it. A strange blankness and sudden fragility stops her from probing her thoughts further. She mouths to herself. “But it cannot be.” Aelira tries to calm her thoughts. Reaching for the princess, she holds her gently, tucking in the soft woollen blanket. Attempting to rock them both to sleep. Failing, she continues to stare into the night silently, swaying back and forth. The Night Before Battle Background: A military tent on the outskirts of the Eastlands. The night before battle. The map before Tharion shows the terrain where tomorrow's blood will flow. His generals have departed, leaving him alone with his thoughts and the flickering lamplight. Outside, the camp settles into an uneasy quiet—thousands of men trying to find sleep before dawn brings death. He doesn't believe in this war. The "Eastland Rebellion" feels manufactured, a convenient enemy conjured by his counselors. Three months ago, these people were loyal subjects. Now, they are traitors who must be put to the sword. "For the security of the realm," Lord Chancellor Severin had insisted. "These dissidents threaten everything we've built." But what have we built? Tharion wonders, staring at the map without seeing it. The city he left behind is no longer the place he once loved. The streets have grown dangerous, neighbors suspicious of neighbors. People disappear—critics of the new policies, scholars who question the historical records, priests who speak of the old ways. And Aelira... something is wrong with Aelira. She moves differently, speaks differently. Sometimes he catches her staring at their daughter with an expression he cannot name but that chills his blood. When he confronts her, she smiles in a way that doesn't reach her eyes and speaks of being "merely tired." He takes out parchment and quill. Perhaps writing to her will help him find the woman he once knew in the stranger who now wears her face. Excerpt from the Personal Diary of Lucius IV "In some cases, I gladden the minds of many. From a distance, I comfort those I turn war against. The harm and healing, they sense it. Now and again, over deep woe, I better their fortunes." From the Unsent Papers of Lucius IV (Written before the Battle of Eastlands) There are those whose gifts are not gifts at all, but preludes to suffering, their favours bestowed with a smile as cold as the blade that follows. I have seen such workings-how a shadow moves among men, weaving hope and despair with equal skill. …A shadow, a presence that gladdens the mind with promises, only to draw out the marrow of a soul in the next breath. From afar, he soothes the very hearts he intends to break, his comfort a poison, his distance an illusion. It is his way to turn kin against kin, to set war in motion with a whisper, then offer solace to the wounded-never for healing's sake, but to deepen the wound, to ensure the cycle continues. Those who have felt his hand know both the sting and the balm, for he is the master of both harm and healing. His power is a tide, receding only to return stronger, dragging all beneath its undertow. Suffering becomes his harvest, and in the aftermath of every calamity, he is there-offering fortune, but only after the soul has been hollowed by woe. So it is, and so it has always been: his gifts are the prelude to ruin, his comfort the herald of conflict. In the end, all that is left is the echo of his laughter, and the knowledge that every fortune he bestows is but the beginning of another fall. Forgive me, for it was with such a one that I made a bargain… These were not choices freely made, but necessities pressed upon me by fate and duty-each step taken because there was no other path, or none I could see. In the end, I did only what was demanded. And for that my dearest, I lost you. Sometimes I wish I could go back-just once-to those childhood days before these bitter fruits…, when I was only Ash, and you were still by my side, before the world grew so heavy. I will look for you always, although I know I shall never see you again in this life. Please, forgive me. ~ Ash He stares at the words he has written, particularly the childhood name he hasn't used in decades. Ash. The name his mother called him, before titles and duties weighed him down. Before the bargain that changed everything. The letter will never be sent. He knows this even as he folds it carefully and seals it with wax. Tomorrow, he will lead men to die for a cause he no longer believes in. And when he returns home—if he returns—Aelira's will be waiting. But he finds instead of his heart being at ease at the thought that it is unsettled… Something must be done. Something to protect what remains of his kingdom, and his daughter. < Uh, this is the part we don't tell the reader because it's the big reveal at the end. The ash is the emperor. The thought comes to him then, remembered from ancient texts in the forbidden section of the royal library: a ritual of division, of protection through fragmentation. A desperate measure for desperate times. As the camp falls silent and the night deepens, Tharion begins to plan.> The Creation of Ash Tharion realizes he's being used by dark forces He understands he's becoming a danger to the kingdom and his daughter In a desperate act to limit the damage he can cause, he decides to split his mind He performs a ritual to create Ash, fragmenting his consciousness This makes him "less useful" psychically to his manipulators He sacrifices his compassion and true self to protect what remains of his kingdom The Arranged Marriage The counselors, now controlling the corrupted Tharion, arrange for his daughter to marry a cruel partner They target her because of her mother's bloodline, which is the one connected to the temple The corrupted Tharion, now completely evil, approves of this arrangement This planned marriage becomes the catalyst for the protagonist's escape and the beginning of the main story Excerpt from the Personal Diary of Lucius IV “In some cases, I gladden the minds of many. From a distance, I comfort those I turn war against. The harm and healing, they sense it. Now and again, over deep woe, I better their fortunes.” From the Unsent Papers of Lucius IV (Written before departing the city) There are those whose gifts are not gifts at all, but preludes to suffering, their favours bestowed with a smile as cold as the blade that follows. I have seen such workings-how a shadow moves among men, weaving hope and despair with equal skill. …A shadow, a presence that gladdens the mind with promises, only to draw out the marrow of a soul in the next breath. From afar, he soothes the very hearts he intends to break, his comfort a poison, his distance an illusion. It is his way to turn kin against kin, to set war in motion with a whisper, then offer solace to the wounded-never for healing’s sake, but to deepen the wound, to ensure the cycle continues. Those who have felt his hand know both the sting and the balm, for he is the master of both harm and healing. His power is a tide, receding only to return stronger, dragging all beneath its undertow. Suffering becomes his harvest, and in the aftermath of every calamity, he is there-offering fortune, but only after the soul has been hollowed by woe. So it is, and so it has always been: his gifts are the prelude to ruin, his comfort the herald of conflict. In the end, all that is left is the echo of his laughter, and the knowledge that every fortune he bestows is but the beginning of another fall. Forgive me, for it was with such a one that I made a bargain… These were not choices freely made, but necessities pressed upon me by fate and duty-each step taken because there was no other path, or none I could see. In the end, I did only what was demanded. And for that my dearest, I lost you. Sometimes I wish I could go back-just once-to those childhood days before these bitter fruits…, when I was only Ash, and you were still by my side, before the world grew so heavy. I will look for you always, although I know I shall never see you again in this life. Please, forgive me. ~ Ash Scene Summary: At the story’s end, after the Emperor’s death and Azaroth’s defeat, this wish is finally granted-not through power, but through release and forgiveness. As the psychic realm dissolves, you witness a vision in a sun-dappled forest clearing. The little boy-Ash-stands uncertain at the edge of the light. Slowly, he transforms into a young, innocent version of the Emperor, unburdened by years of darkness. There, waiting in the golden, silvery sunlight, is a young woman: his wife, your mother, also freed at last. For a moment, they hesitate-tentative, almost not daring to believe. Then recognition dawns, and their faces brighten with wonder and relief. The young Emperor reaches out; she takes his hand. Before they step into the radiant light, both turn and look at you. The young woman’s features are strikingly similar to your own. She smiles-a smile filled with both happiness and sorrow, joyful to be free and reunited, yet sad because she cannot stay with you. Their eyes linger on you, conveying love, pride, and a silent farewell. Together, they step into the sunlight, laughter and joy echoing as the forest closes protectively around them-accepting, sheltering, and finally, at peace. In this moment, Lucius/Ash’s deepest wish is answered: He returns to the days before everything became so heavy, finds her again, and is welcomed home by the gentle light and the embrace of the forest. The cycle of suffering is broken, and what was lost is, at last, restored-not in the world he ruled, but in the peace he could never find until now. The heartstone The Pact: Azaroth’s Vision of Betrayal You stumble through the labyrinth, the world lurching beneath your feet. The air thickens, heavy with the scent of incense and old stone. Azaroth’s presence coils around your mind, cold and suffocating. Suddenly, you are not yourself. You are seeing through another’s eyes—your father’s, long ago, in a secret chamber beneath the palace. Tharion, although blindfolded, is aware a large circular room. Somnolescent voices drone in a chant. The sound panning out, around a vast area. Echoes rise upward into blank silence. There is an eager anticipation to the room, prickling expectancy. His strong hands hover flat palmed over his sword. The sword of ages. The blade is held silently like an offering, or a sacrifice. While the two attendants holding the sword stand rigid and unmoving. With only an unhearable prayer on their lips. All are listening to the high chancellor chant. In the blackness, his voice takes on an otherworldly quality. The words come in finality, as a pledge. An unbreakable promise. There is something about this scene, it weighs on you; You can feel a split in the fabric of it. A veil of duplicity. Not everything here is visible. You focus on the words. Paying more attention. The hue of them, the grouping. And it is there you feel the mental underlay. Brushing away its deceptions you pull all the hidden meaning into view, back into a whole form. As spoken and thought by the speaker. The memory plays, but now, as if a thin seam has opened, you sense another presence—Ash, silent, careful, threading through the vision. The scene flickers, fractionates. For a moment, you see two things at once: the surface, and the truth beneath. “I will return all that you love,” In thought the Chancellor adds, “Broken and in torment.” “You will thank and worship me..,” “Regardless, you low, wretched martyr...” “Your love of life and its continuity..,” “A canker, defiling all you treasure.” “Your kindness wielded is a force for light..,” “Monumental in its horror. You shall debase all you love.” “Therefore, I treasure you..,” “Nothing could be more broken and disfigured.” “Because, you are like me. We are one.” The Chancellor intones again. “... And will you King Tharion, hold your promises given to us?” Tharion slumps his shoulders slightly and heavily replies. “The things which I have here before promised, I will perform, and keep.” You can sense a silent prayer and discouragement, along with desperation. But he holds his tongue in silence. The ancient blade glows as if enraged, then fades from sight. As if it has forsaken him, or been banished. In its place a near perfect replica of the sword is placed, this sword is tainted, and will not identify the corrupt officials or followers of Severin, including now the king, within the king’s court, neither can it give the king the power to know who they are in case he would try to betray them. But the vision stutters, and in the corner of your eye, Ash moves. He is not part of the memory, but he is here, slipping between the shadows, unseen by the others. He glances at you, and for a heartbeat, the walls of the chamber seem to thin. You see him press his hand to a section of stone, and a hidden compartment slides open. The true Sword of Ages gleams, untouched, hidden away. The false blade remains on the altar, its heart hollow. Ash’s eyes meet yours, full of warning and sorrow, before he fades back into the vision’s edge. But Azaroth twists the vision, forcing you to see not just the ritual, but its consequences: Tharion’s hands stained with the blood of allies, the kingdom’s oldest friend betrayed, chaos and war unleashed. The faces of the fallen—men, women, children—flash before you, their eyes full of accusation. Tharion stands at the center, the false sword in his grip, his face a mask of guilt and resolve. Azaroth’s voice slithers through the memory, cruel and triumphant: “He chose this. He gave them up. He made war on his own friends, his own people. He was not tricked—he was willing. This is the man you would redeem?” You try to look away, but the vision holds you. In the shadows at the edge of the chamber, you glimpse a small figure—Ash, watching, his eyes wide and unbearably sad. He does not speak. He only watches as the pact is sealed, as your father’s innocence is lost. There is something in his gaze—a sorrow, a knowing—that you cannot understand. In finality, the Lord Chancellor speaks. “Then it shall be as you wish...” “He was deceived!” You mouth to yourself, the slight power in your voice barely vocalises the words. A presence with deep regret can be felt but it quickly snaps off and vanishes. The voice snickers, “You’d like to think so.., you self commiserating little rat.” “But I’ll have you know..,” He pauses with relish. “Such promises can only be made if they are known and agreed to! Never make deals with the devil, As it was he that invented contracts!” You perceive a misty form capering around you mockingly. Leaning in sharply, it whispers musically…, “What he didn’t know, was just how much the chancellor hated him!… Memories.., Ahhh!. So en-ter-tain-ing!” With several mocking flourishes, He skips off back, fading into the blackness! You stagger forward, Ash’s presence lingering at your side. He does not comfort you. He only looks at you with that same, deep sadness, as if he knows a truth you cannot yet see. You are left uncertain, shaken. Is any of this real? Am I going mad? Is it lies? Did he really betray—make war on his own friends, his own people? He was not tricked—he was willing? The vision’s aftertaste clings, bitter and unresolved. <h2>Scene: Port of Talon – Aryfis’s View</h2> Aryfis the marketplace imp flowers sulkily and stomps his tiny clawed foot on the salt-stained planks of the Talon docks. The city’s air is thick with brine, fish guts, and the shouts of sailors, but Aryfis is in no mood for the bustle. His tail flicks in irritation, nearly tripping a passing dockhand, who yelps and scurries away, muttering about “devil-kin and their curses.” He should be proud. He, Aryfis, has crossed deserts, braved haunted citadels, and survived Siania’s cooking. Yet here he is, ignored, his grand plans for mischief stifled by the seriousness of their mission. Siania is all business, the pirate is sharpening his cutlass, and nobody has even noticed the clever way Aryfis “borrowed” a pouch of silver from a distracted merchant. (He’ll return it. Maybe. If he remembers.) He scampers between crates, eyeing the bustling port for opportunity. A glint of something shiny—buttons, coins, a polished boot buckle—always draws his gaze. But today, even the prospect of petty theft feels hollow. Siania is tense, her eyes fixed on the distant palace spires. Aryfis senses the weight of her purpose, and it makes his own claws itch. Still, an imp’s got to do what an imp’s got to do. He slips away from the group, ducking behind a stack of barrels, ears pricked for gossip. He’s halfway through pilfering a string of dried fish when he overhears two dockworkers grumbling in hushed tones. “Orders from the top,” one says, glancing nervously at the palace. “No one in or out without the mark. The Black Sorcerer’s expecting trouble.” Aryfis’s ears perk up. The Black Sorcerer—Azaroth. His old master. The one who’d sent him to spy, to sabotage, to collect souls. The one who’d promised him glory and given him nothing but singed fur and a sore bottom. He creeps closer, heart thumping. The dockworkers mention a patrol, magical wards, and a “red-haired girl” matching Siania’s description. Aryfis’s stomach drops. Azaroth knows they’re here. He darts back to the group, nearly colliding with the pirate, who grumbles and shoos him away. Siania kneels, her hand on Aryfis’s shoulder, her eyes searching his face. “What is it, little one?” Aryfis hesitates. Old habits war with new loyalties. He could keep this to himself, earn favor with Azaroth. But Siania’s kindness, the pirate’s gruff camaraderie, the memory of the grave hoard and his own moment of heroism, hell even the fuzzy bottom 6 eyes spiders—they all tug at him. He lowers his voice. “Azaroth knows. He’s waiting. The city’s crawling with his spies.” Siania’s jaw tightens, but she nods. “Then we move quickly. I’ll go to the catacombs alone. You and the pirate—find Agara, find the spiders. We’ll need them if we’re to have any chance.” Aryfis puffs out his chest, trying to look brave. “Leave it to me, mistress! I’ll rally the spiders, the sand-walkers, the whole desert if I must!” He glances at the pirate, who rolls his eyes but offers a grudging nod. As Siania slips away into the city’s labyrinthine streets, Aryfis watches her go, a strange ache in his chest. He’s still a devil, still selfish, still hungry for shiny things and mischief. But for the first time, he wants something more: to be worthy of her trust. He turns to the pirate, grinning his toothiest, most impish grin. “Well, mate, ready to cause some trouble?” And with that, Aryfis the imp—marketplace menace, would-be soul collector, and unlikely hero—leads the way into the desert, mischief and loyalty warring in his heart. (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>The Psychic Labyrinth Showdown</h2> Climax: The Psychic Labyrinth Showdown Vision 0 flying over the ancient city - a memory not your own The memory is so ancient that even the stars have shifted in the sky. Terrius, the hunter’s constellation, sits further north, its familiar pattern altered—two stars, Teruis and Nova, now missing from its celestial array. It is the same city as Talon. You can tell from the layout of the islands and castle. However, other aspects of the city are altered. Some buildings are missing. No longer is the population completely human, but is mixed. Groups of elves walk in flowing robes freely, mingling pleasantries with market holders and citizens alike. In the harbour, boats connect goods from the outlying islands. Cobbled streets snake up the hill between mansions, parks, and taverns, converging at the city square, where colorful markets and a festive air announce the coming coronation. In a few days, a new king will take the throne. Overlooking all from the hilltop, the majestic castle Celnaer rests-pale marble and delicately carved columns supporting its elegant form, dashed with turrets and long halls. Flowing tiered gardens spill down from the grand ceremonial staircase, which ends at imposing gates that mark the boundary between the bustling market square and the stillness of the royal gardens. Several Crystalline towers glow with an effervescent light. They accompany the king’s road in harmony. Both styles of the elven and human are sympathetically united. Each augmenting the beauty of the other. Counterbalancing the strength of heavy and certain stones. Combined with the light pleasant filigree of details, organic and heartfelt. Achieving what would be impossible individually. The effect is awe-inspiring.. You can detect strong magic in the air. Some, directed at the towers, holding them aloft in their impossible height. Delicate swirling glyphs glint refracting rainbow eddies of colour sporadically. Along with an ambiguous sheen of deep magic murmuring deepening in its nebulous core. Other streams power the delicate fairy lights sprinkled throughout the marketplace. Some denote guilds, stone-masons, armorers, embroiderers and weavers. Others are new to you, holding symbols you can only guess at. You become aware of a harmony held within the land itself, which is no longer mute. Almost as if the land and the castle are part of a deeper intermeshed harmony. The phrase springs to your mind, ringing in your blood “The song of the land.” The metropolis of Talin sweeps across the mainland of Alteer, its sprawl reaching out in a graceful sequence to five smaller islands, each one glimmering in the pale morning light. The islands extend outward from the peninsula, each connected to the next by slender filigree bridges that arch over the turquoise sea like delicate threads of silver. [Beneath the bridges, the ancient stonework still bears the faded sigils of the city’s founders, half-overgrown with flowering vines and moss. Here and there, weathered statues of forgotten guardians watch silently from their perches, their features softened by centuries of salt and wind.] From above, the bridges form a luminous path, weaving the city together in a shimmering line across the water. You vaguely notice the air above the sea carries not a true scent, but the faint impression of brine and the sweetness of flowering vines clinging to the bridge railings-more a memory woven into the fabric of the city than a sensation you can truly grasp, there but not there.… “Home..,” you whisper weakly. The words escape crackling and dissipating into an echoing silence.. The effort of speaking presses painfully against your ribs, the longing for those shores presses deeply like a sharp wound.. Your voice seems remote, as if left back in the cell reverberating, cold echoes against unforgiving walls. Some awareness tells you that somehow, you are in two places at the same time. A dark cold cell, and here, flooded in light. Your lips are parched and dry. You wonder if you are delirious or going mad. You let yourself drift, escaping the coldness and pain. And float above it all. Surveying it in its delicate vastness. This is how the city was before the dark times came. Yet as you drift in the memory, a quiet sense of displacement stirs within you-an uncanny awareness that these sights and feelings, vivid as they are, do not quite belong to you. It’s as if you are witnessing through another’s eyes, their longing and hope threading through your senses, familiar yet not entirely your own. The warmth and hope of this city belong to another-someone who once called this place home, long before ruin and betrayal. A deep longing and appreciation mixed with remorse. Together, bonded for a few precious moments, you both dwell on the beauty of the scene before you-a fleeting nostalgia. You sense his caution, a wariness that lingers just beneath the surface, before the other entity flickers suddenly away from your senses.. *Notes: The only piece of Ash’s true self left is his childhood core, hiding and fighting to help his daughter resist Azaroth’s corruption. Ash’s core self is cautious, only surfacing when Azaroth’s attention is elsewhere.* Moving on alone, your eyes follow each jewel-like island linked along the king’s road. Tall, filigree-arched bridges span the serene turquoise sea. Large-sailed ships-bearing spices, bright silks, crates of citrus and rare woods-pass beneath, bound for distant lands, with white gulls trailing in graceful arcs, their wings flashing in the sun. You watch them, wondering if you should pursue the freedom of the open sky. The gulls call to you, offering the promise of light and adventure, inviting you to follow them into something boundless and bright, as if you might simply rise and be carried away. But something within you resists. You draw your gaze back to the island cities- and, weightless as thought, you drift downwards, unseen and untouched, gliding above rooftops and lantern-strung streets. [The rooftops themselves are a patchwork of old and new: some crowned with domes of weathered copper and others with the sharp angles of more recent repairs. In the oldest quarters, you glimpse the intricate mosaics and carved lintels that once marked the homes of honored guardians.] You pass over sunlit plazas and winding alleys, catching fragments of laughter, flashes of color, the shimmer of celebration. You hover at the edge of life, a silent observer, drawn irresistibly closer. Each island city prepares for a celebration. Paper lanterns sweep colourfully from street to street. Markets bustle, excited in activity. You notice residents scuttling hurriedly to buy scent-filled spices. Others competitively haggle for ripe fruits and exotic materials. Near shaded fountains, servants and masters alike consume cool and refreshing honey Java, all while catching the gossip of the day. Each moving back and forth through the jumbled cacophony of rambunctious merchants. Drawn by the sights below, you let yourself slip lower, gliding through the lattice of filigree bridges that link the islands in silver arcs. You sweep past the masts of anchored ships, sails snapping in the sea breeze, and thread between wheeling gulls whose wings flash bright in the sunlight. The scent of brine and citrus drifts up from the harbor as you skim above the cliffs, rising with the wind and dipping down into the winding streets. You choose a market square alive with color and sound, drifting just above washing lines and baskets of goods. Children dart between stalls, faces flushed with excitement, while merchants call out their wares, laughter and voices mingling in the air. Here, in the heart of the celebration, you hover unseen-close enough to catch every detail, yet always apart. You feel distant from them all, but appreciative of the scene. The normality and steady flow... The full flushed and gleeful faces of children, smiling merchants working and creating. Gentle hands of grandparents and carers. Simple people living good hearted lives. Yet even as you watch, a quiet ache settles in your chest-a sorrow that feels both ancient and immediate. These are not your own memories, but the bittersweet recollections of another: a ruler who once walked these streets, now left only with regret for all he could not save “Pitiful ingrates...” A sharp sneer breaks your attention, rising from its previously quiet niggling at the fringes of your consciousness. The voice is bitter, heavy with old wounds and contempt-a presence both familiar and alien, as if the memory itself is haunted by a shadow that will not let go. You push it back, refusing to let it take hold. It whines as it fades: “There will be consequences if you ignore me,” it snarls. “You need me...!” But you feel a bright mind pressing on you, distracting you from the shrill, piercing, threatening voice. At first, you don’t understand what’s happening—there’s only a sense of warmth, a flicker of presence that isn’t your own. The city’s memory wavers, the laughter and color of the market fading to a hush. You sense someone beside you, a boy’s presence—small, anxious, but fiercely protective. You turn, and for a heartbeat, you see him: a boy with tousled hair and wide, watchful eyes, his form shimmering at the edge of your vision. He looks at you with a mixture of hope and fear, as if he’s not sure you’ll recognize him. Then, Before you can speak, his shape begins to dissolve. Light spills from his edges, shimmering like mist in the morning sun. His form blurs, softening into something fluid and weightless. For a moment, he is only a glow-a luminous silhouette against the world-before the light ripples and reshapes itself. Feathers appear, not as solid things, but as strands of radiance, delicate as threads of dawn. the boy is gone, and in his place stands a seagull—white and grey, delicate and bright, perched on the nearby railing. The gull cocks its head, fixing you with a sharp, intelligent gaze. For a moment, you see the echo of the boy’s face in its features—hopeful, wary, determined. He gives a soft, urgent cry, then flutters his wings, glancing back at you as if to say, “Follow me.” You do, drawn by the certainty in his movements. The gull weaves ahead, gliding low over the rooftops and winding through the narrowing streets. The city’s festive noise falls away behind you, replaced by a growing hush. The crowds thin, lanterns grow sparse, and the air grows heavier, tinged with the scent of stone and distant earth. Shadows stretch longer across the cobbles, and the laughter of the market is replaced by the quiet echo of your own footsteps. You realize you’re being led somewhere—somewhere important, though you don’t yet know where. The gull pauses at the mouth of a narrow alley, where the city’s light gives way to a deeper gloom. The silence here is different: watchful, expectant, as if the city itself is holding its breath. The gull waits for you, unwavering, a silent promise that you are not alone, even as the way ahead grows more ominous. Bridging Passage: Entering the Labyrinth You hesitate at the mouth of the alley, the gull urging you forward. The city’s noise is a distant murmur now, muffled as if by thick fog. The alley stretches ahead, its cobbles slick with an unseen damp, the air heavy with the scent of stone and something older-ashes, perhaps, or the memory of fire. You step forward-but as you do your world shifts. The walls of the alley ripple, their surfaces shimmering like water. You feel yourself unraveling; your edges blur, your thoughts scatter. You are neither here nor there, but somewhere in between, a shadow slipping through a crack in time. The sensation is dizzying, your body light and insubstantial, as if you are a fragment of yourself inserted into a reality long past and yet impossibly present. You move, but not as you once did. You are flying, or gliding your form rippling through the city. You slip under small bridges, over cobbled roofs, past carts laden with produce, their bells chiming faintly. You weave through children at play and the market’s colorful lanterns, their laughter and chatter muted, as if heard through thick glass. But there is no music like there was before….You are not wanted here. The city does not remember you, does not recognize your presence. You float-unseen, a ghost among ghosts. And yet, the land knows you somehow…faint echoes swell and ripple around you…you are needed-for what purpose, you cannot say. It pulls at you, silent, insistent, drawing you deeper into the city’s heart. The alleys narrow, the walls pressing close. The light dims, and the air grows thick with anticipation. Lanterns and laughter fade, replaced by a deepening hush. You sense the market’s vibrant life receding, the city’s festive clamor giving way to something older, quieter, more secret. Then, without warning, the ground beneath you gives way-not to darkness, but to something stranger. The cobbles dissolve, and you find yourself standing at the threshold of the labyrinth. Its corridors stretch before you, shifting and alive, every shadow a threat, every turn a test of will. Ash is beside you, his small hand finding yours. “You made it,” he whispers, his voice trembling with relief and fear. “Now we have to move. Quickly or he will see us….” You step forward, and the labyrinth swallows you whole. The air changes instantly-thick, electric, laced with the scent of damp stone and something older, something faintly metallic. The walls seem to breathe, shifting just beyond your vision. Shadows move, not quite shadows, more like memories given form. You and Ash move together, your hands brushing, your breaths shallow. The ground beneath you is never steady-one moment firm, the next giving way like sand. Doors flicker in and out of existence, their edges blurred as if seen through smoke. Then, a voice-Azaroth’s voice-slithers through the chaos, low and intimate, as if spoken directly into your mind. The words are not loud, but they cut through the noise, each syllable weighted with malice. “Do you like it?” The voice is everywhere-above you, behind you, inside your skull. “I made this just for you. Every corridor, every shadow. Your fears, your failures, laid bare. I know you, little ghost. I see you.” The walls pulse, their surfaces slick with something dark. Shadows writhe, forming shapes-faces you recognize, voices you thought you’d forgotten. Azaroth’s laughter echoes, a sound like glass shattering. “You will break just like your father did….how pathetic” You try to speak, but your voice is swallowed by the maze. Azaroth’s presence presses closer, his words dripping with satisfaction. “Ash can’t save you forever. He’s only a child, and children break so easily.” The air shifts, a cold draft curling around your ankles. The labyrinth groans, its corridors tightening. Azaroth’s voice drops to a whisper, intimate and cruel. “But don’t worry. I’ll make sure you remember this moment. Every second of it.” Then, silence-heavy, expectant. The labyrinth waits, and Azaroth’s gloating lingers in the air, a promise and a threat. You stagger, buffeted by psychic waves-images of your own failures, voices screaming, corridors collapsing. Ash is gone, his hand torn from yours. The labyrinth convulses, and for a terrible moment, you are alone, certain you will be lost here, swallowed by the maze. Ash’s fingers brush your wrist-light, tentative, but steady. He doesn’t speak. Instead, he moves ahead, his small frame slipping through the shadows. When the corridor splits, he hesitates only a moment before tugging you down the narrower path, his grip tightening when you flinch at the sound of something scraping behind you. He leads you under a low arch, ducking as if he’s done it a hundred times before. When your foot catches on a loose cobble, he catches your arm, his breath quick but his touch firm. You see the tremor in his hand, the way his eyes dart to every movement in the dark, but he steps forward anyway, his shoulders squared. At the mouth of a dead end, he stops, listening. The air is colder here, the silence heavier. Azaroth’s voice rises, taunting, but Ash only sets his jaw and turns, pulling you into a crevice you hadn’t noticed. He presses a finger to his lips, his eyes wide, warning you to stay silent. The corridor shudders, the walls groaning. Ash stands between you and the shifting dark, his back to you, his hands clenched at his sides. When the danger passes, he lets out a shaky breath and glances back, his expression easing when he sees you unharmed. He keeps going, keeps leading, keeps shielding you from the worst of the maze.
