His shoulders are tight, his breath quick, but he doesn’t stop. He moves forward, and you follow. You press on, the labyrinth alive around you, every shadow a threat, every corridor a test of will. The way forward is never clear, the ground shifts, doors vanish, and the walls themselves seem to whisper your fears. Streams of psychic energy ripple through the air, carrying the stench of sickness and decay. Azaroth is everywhere and nowhere, his presence twisting the corridors, his laughter echoing in your mind. [[Vision 1: The Labyrinth and Ash]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Vision 1: The Labyrinth and Ash</h2> Vision 1: The Labyrinth and Ash You and Ash move together, hearts pounding, every sense straining for Azaroth’s presence. The way forward is never clear; the ground shifts, doors vanish, and the walls themselves seem to whisper your fears. Streaming, oozing psychic waves envelop you—a black stench of sickness and decay that clings to your skin and seeps into your mind. Azeroth is everywhere and nowhere, his laughter echoing, his power twisting the air. Panic claws at your thoughts as paths you thought were safe dissolve into traps, your own tricks turned against you. Every step forward is met with resistance, every breath thick with dread. You press on, but Azaroth’s presence presses back, warping the labyrinth around you. The air pulses with psychic force, the walls closing in. You stumble, nearly falling as the ground beneath you seems to rot and ooze, threatening to swallow you whole. “He can’t catch us here,” Ash whispers, but his voice trembles. “Otherwise we’re doomed. We have to get to the door. We have to get out…” He hesitates, then his voice quiets with sudden resolve. “No—you have to get out.” He squeezes your hand. “You know the way now. Trust what I taught you!” Before you can protest, Ash darts away, his small form flickering through the psychic haze. He doesn’t fight Azaroth head-on—he can’t. Instead, he uses every scrap of cunning he has left: darting, doubling back, creating distractions, leading Azaroth’s focus away from you. He appears, then vanishes, always just out of reach, always drawing the mage’s attention. You feel the labyrinth shift, the pressure of Azaroth’s presence momentarily lessened. Ash’s psychic signature is everywhere—a flash of laughter, a glimmer of hope, a child’s voice echoing in the maze. Azaroth’s rage grows, the darkness thickening as he chases after Ash’s illusions. You seize the opening, pushing forward through the twisting corridors, every step a struggle against the suffocating tide. Ash’s presence is a flickering guide, his bravery and selflessness lighting the way even as he grows fainter. You stumble, separated from Ash, and for a terrible moment, you are utterly alone. Doubt floods in. What if you’re not strong enough? What if you fail, and all hope is lost? You force yourself to your feet, battered but unbroken, and push deeper into the maze. You reach the final door—the one you’ve never been able to open. Behind you, the labyrinth convulses with Azaroth’s fury, but Ash’s last distraction buys you the moment you need. You press your hand to the door, feeling the mark burn with purpose. Ash’s voice finds you again: “Don’t give up,” but he’s fading, his strength gives you resolve. For a heartbeat, nothing happens. Then, with a blinding surge of light, the door shatters. The labyrinth collapses. Ash smiles at you, proud and grateful, even as he begins to fade. You stumble through the labyrinth’s next threshold, and the world lurches. The air thickens, the scent of incense and old stone pressing in. Azaroth’s presence coils around your mind, cold and suffocating. [[Vision 1b: The King’s Bargain (The Sword of Ages)]](set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Vision 1b: The King’s Bargain (The Sword of Ages)</h2> Vision 1b: The King’s Bargain (The Sword of Ages) Suddenly, you are not yourself. You are seeing through another’s eyes—your father’s, long ago, in a secret chamber beneath the palace. The Sword of Ages rests on a black altar, its light cold and pure. The High Chancellor’s voice is a blade. All are listening to the High Chancellor chant. In the blackness, his voice takes on an otherworldly quality. The words come in finality, as a pledge. An unbreakable promise. There is something about this scene, it weighs on you; you can feel a split in the fabric of it. A veil of duplicity. Not everything here is visible. You focus on the words. Paying more attention. The hue of them, the grouping. And it is there you feel the mental underlay. The memory plays, but now, as if a thin seam has opened, you sense another presence—Ash, silent, careful, threading through the vision. The scene flickers, fractionates. For a moment, you see two things at once: the surface, and the truth beneath, the meanings that slip under the skin of the words. The words echo in the chamber, but beneath each one, a second meaning coils—unspoken, poisonous, revealed only by the split in the room Ash has made. As the vision fractures, something stirs in you—a faint tingling in your blood, a shiver of recognition you cannot name. The Chancellor intones, “I will return all that you love,” Broken and in torment. “You will thank and worship me…” Regardless, you low, wretched martyr... “Your love of life and its continuity…” A canker, defiling all you treasure. “Your kindness wielded is a force for light…” Monumental in its horror. You shall debase all you love. “Therefore, I treasure you…” Nothing could be more broken and disfigured. “Because, you are like me. We are one.” Your vision shifts slightly to focus on the Chancellor as he intones again. “... And will you, King Tharion, hold your promises given to us?” Tharion slumps his shoulders slightly and heavily replies, “The things which I have here before promised, I will perform, and keep.” You can sense a silent prayer and discouragement, along with desperation. But he holds his tongue in silence. The ancient blade glows as if enraged, then fades from sight. As if it has forsaken him, or been banished. In its place a near perfect replica of the sword is placed, this sword is tainted, and will not identify the corrupt officials or followers of Severin, including now the king, within the king’s court, neither can it give the king the power to know who they are in case he would try to betray them. But the vision stutters, and in the corner of your eye, Ash moves. He is not part of the memory, but he is here, slipping between the shadows, unseen by the others. Light bends, fractionating strangely around him, a shimmer that is ethereal and fragile. He glances at you, and for a heartbeat, the walls of the chamber seem to thin. You see him press his hand to a section of stone, and a hidden compartment slides open. The true Sword of Ages gleams, untouched, hidden away. The false blade remains on the altar, its heart hollow. Ash’s eyes meet yours, full of warning and sorrow. Then, as quickly as it came, the light folds back into shadow. Ash fades into the vision’s edge. But Azaroth (not aware of Ash’s intervention in the vision) twists the vision, forcing you to see not just the ritual, but its consequences: Tharion’s hands stained with the blood of allies, the kingdom’s oldest friend betrayed, chaos and war unleashed. The faces of the fallen—men, women, children—flash before you, their eyes full of accusation. Tharion stands at the center, the false sword in his grip, his face a mask of guilt and resolve. Azaroth’s voice slithers through the memory, cruel and triumphant: “He chose this. He gave them up. He made war on his own friends, his own people. He was not tricked—he was willing. This is the man you would redeem?” You try to look away, but the vision holds you. In the shadows at the edge of the chamber, you glimpse a small figure—Ash, watching, his eyes wide and unbearably sad. He does not speak. He only watches as the pact is sealed, as your father’s innocence is lost. There is something in his gaze—a sorrow, a knowing—that you cannot understand. In finality, the Lord Chancellor speaks. “Then it shall be as you wish...” “He was deceived!” you mouth to yourself, the slight power in your voice barely vocalizes the words. A presence with deep regret can be felt but it quickly snaps off and vanishes. The voice snickers, “You’d like to think so… you self-commiserating little rat. But I’ll have you know… such promises can only be made if they are known and agreed to! Never make deals with the devil, as it was he that invented contracts!” You perceive a misty form capering around you mockingly. Leaning in sharply, it whispers musically, “What he didn’t know was just how much the chancellor hated him!… Memories… Ahhh! So en-ter-tain-ing!” With several mocking flourishes, he skips off back, fading into the blackness! You stagger forward, Ash’s presence lingering at your side. He does not comfort you. He only looks at you with that same, deep sadness. His eyes drop, unable to meet yours for long. His shoulders draw in, hands fidgeting at his sides, restless. For a moment, he seems to want to speak, but the words never come. Instead, he stands silent, gaze fixed somewhere just beyond you, as if weighed down by something he cannot share—not yet. You are left uncertain, shaken. Is any of this real? Am I going mad? Is it lies? Did he really betray—make war on his own friends, his own people? He was not tricked—he was willing? The vision’s aftertaste clings, bitter and unresolved. [[Vision 2: The Heartstone and the Queen’s Return]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Vision 2: The Heartstone and the Queen’s Return</h2> Vision 2: The Heartstone and the Queen’s Return You are thrust into another memory, the world flickering with sickly green light. The Emperor stands over the dying Queen, his hands shaking, the air thick with incense and dread. The High Chancellor (Severin) offers him a choice: “Serve us, and she will live. Refuse, and she dies tonight.” You see the Emperor’s face, twisted with grief and desperation. He agrees. The ritual begins. The Queen’s body is laid upon the altar, her hair fanned out like a dark halo. Severin presses the Heartstone to her chest—a crystal pulsing with a hungry, unnatural light. Dark magic stirs, swirling in the incense-laden air, and the Queen’s soul is drawn screaming into the stone. Her back arches, her mouth opens in a soundless cry. When her eyes snap open, they are wrong—cold, empty, the warmth of her spirit stripped away. Azaroth’s voice hisses in your ear, venomous and triumphant: “He chose this. He sacrificed her soul for his own weakness. He brought her back, knowing she would never be the same. He condemned her to a living death, all for his own selfish love. This is the man you would redeem?” The vision shifts. You see the Queen, alive but changed. Her laughter rings hollow in the marble halls, her touch chills the skin. The Emperor cannot meet her gaze, nor that of their daughter. He wanders the palace like a ghost, haunted by the cost of his bargain. The city grows darker, the temple’s harmony broken. The Emperor’s hands are stained, and the stain spreads. Rumors begin as whispers in the kitchens and servants’ quarters and among the common people: whispers of forbidden magic that brought her back but left her changed. At first, these are only hushed stories—servants glimpsing the Queen’s coldness, healers noting the unnatural pallor in her eyes, old women muttering that the dead should not walk. But as the King’s corruption deepens, these rumors become dangerous. The King—now a puppet, his will bent by Severin and Azaroth—cannot bear the rumors. His pride is wounded, his shame a festering wound. He lashes out. Secret police, the Black Mantle, are formed, their faces hidden behind black steel. They move through the city at night, rooting out “sedition” and “blasphemy.” Any mention of the Heartstone, of the Queen’s unnatural state, is met with swift, brutal punishment. Neighbors turn on neighbors. Families vanish. The plazas, once filled with music and laughter, are watched by silent, armored figures. The old songs of the Queen’s kindness are replaced by fearful silence. The King’s rage is a mask for his terror. Every rumor is a reminder of his own failure, the bargain he made, the horror he unleashed. He cannot destroy the evidence in himself, so he tries to destroy it in the world. The realm becomes a place of fear and repression. The Heartstone’s true nature is buried beneath layers of lies and violence. The Queen, now a shadow, is kept out of sight. The King’s court is a place of paranoia, where even the highest nobles fear a careless word. The city’s spirit is broken, its harmony shattered. Azaroth weaponizes these memories: “See what he became? He destroyed his own people to hide his shame, visions of terrified citizens, secret police raids. He is beyond redemption.” But the vision stutters. The green light flickers, and suddenly Ash is beside you, his presence gentle and warm. The memory shifts, and you see what Azaroth tried to hide. The Emperor, kneeling by his wife’s bedside, his shoulders shaking with silent sobs. He presses her hand to his lips, begging the gods for any way to save her. The Queen, her voice barely a whisper, brushes his cheek. “Let me go. Don’t bargain with darkness. I love you. Protect our daughter.” The Chancellor’s offer comes when the Emperor is at his lowest, his mind clouded by grief and exhaustion. He hesitates, torn between hope and terror, love and fear. The ritual’s true cost is hidden behind words of salvation. You see the Emperor’s regret, the horror dawning in his eyes as the Queen’s soul is trapped, her body left vacant, her love twisted into something cruel and unrecognizable. You see his isolation, his growing madness, his desperate attempts to make things right, all while Azaroth’s shadow tightens around him. Ash sits beside you, knees drawn up, his eyes wide and searching. He hugs his arms around himself, voice soft and uncertain. “I remember when things felt safe. When people smiled, and the halls were bright. I liked it when everyone was kind. But then… people started whispering. They said things about her—things that made everything feel heavy and sad. I didn’t like it. I wanted it to stop.” He looks down, fingers twisting in his sleeves. “I don’t understand why it all changed. The king… he stopped smiling. He got so quiet. He loved her. He loved you, and then got so angry. I just wanted everyone to be good again. I wanted the bad things to go away. I wanted to help, but I didn’t know how. I just… wanted things to be gentle, like before.” Ash’s hand finds yours, small and warm. He says nothing more, but his sadness settles over you like a blanket. Ash is the Emperor’s innocence and kindness, but he’s been separated so long that he experiences the “king” as someone else, almost like a sibling or a distant self. Siania’s Realization The weight of both visions presses on your heart. You see your father not as a monster, but as a man—flawed, desperate, manipulated. Once, perhaps, he was capable of love and regret, but now you cannot be sure. The man you remember is lost somewhere behind the shadows and the madness. You don’t know if anything of him remains, or if forgiveness is even possible. Over time, rumors spread among the commoners about a “Queen’s soul stone,” but no one knows the truth. The Heartstone’s existence is actively covered up by Severin, the Emperor, and his agents; any mention of it is suppressed, and its true nature is lost to all but a select few. You look at the Heartstone in your hand, the Queen’s soul silent for now, what so many lives were lost over—in suffering, all products of Faustian bargains. Grateful for the small, warm hand in yours, Ash resolutely sits beside you, his presence comforting. Whatever else is true, you are not alone in this place. For now, that is enough. [[Inside the Mind: The Undoing]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Inside the Mind: The Undoing</h2> Inside the Mind: The Undoing (Atmospheric Psychic Battle) You cross the threshold into the final room of the labyrinth, and the world shudders. The air is thick—almost viscous—heavy with the scent of old incense and the chill of centuries-old regret. Shadows pool in the corners, swirling with the memory of loss. You alone are alive here; every other presence is memory, echo, or spirit. The Emperor sits hunched at the center, his outline flickering between flesh and aether, as if he’s caught between worlds. Azaroth’s presence is a living darkness, putrid and sliding along the walls, casting long, unnatural shadows that seem to whisper and writhe. The Heartstone in your hands shimmers with gentle warmth. A glimmer of silver mist curls from the delicate wood, swirling in the charged air. Then, as if the room itself is holding its breath, the light gathers and lengthens, weaving itself into the suggestion of a figure. A silvery, translucent form unfurls—robed in flowing light, her presence both impossibly delicate and unyielding. Her feet barely touch the ground. It is your mother: ethereal, luminous, more beautiful and sorrowful than any memory or dream. For a heartbeat, you can only stare, knowing this is the first time you have truly seen her. When she speaks, the air shivers with the memory of spring and the scent of roses. Azeroth (soft, insidious; his words chill the air, the shadows lengthening): “She’s come to judge you, you know. She saw everything. She knows the bargain you made, the price you paid. She’ll never forgive you—no one will. Every failure, every betrayal… especially hers. You remember how she looked at you, don’t you? You know you deserve her disappointment.” His voice echoes from every direction—sometimes a whisper behind your ear, sometimes a thunderous resonance that rattles the stone of the room. There’s a note of confidence, but beneath it, a subtle tremor. His grip is absolute, but not unbreakable. The walls drip with spectral ooze, and flickers of the Emperor’s worst memories bleed through the air. Mother (ethereal, voice gentle but sorrowful): “That’s not true. I never wanted to judge you. I loved you, even when I saw the danger in your choices. I warned you because I cared, not because I wished to shame you. I came because you’re more than what he’s made you believe.” Her words float like music, layered with a quiet strength—the sound of distant bells and the soft rush of wind through leaves. The cold recedes, replaced by a golden glow. Memories of laughter and sunlight flicker at the edges of your vision—a forest in bloom, hope almost tangible. Warmth gently pushes back against Azaroth’s chill. You (quiet, steady; your living breath stirs the dust, grounding the space): “He’s always tried to turn us against each other. He made you believe you were alone, that you’d lost her trust. But she loved you—even when she disagreed, even when she was afraid.” Your voice is hesitant at first, but grows firmer as you see the effect your words have. The dust stirs with every breath you take, and the labyrinth’s walls ripple in uncertainty. You sense, for the first time, that your presence matters. Emperor (voice hollow, uncertain; his form flickers, the crystal spreading as his doubt grows): “I… I tried to protect you. I tried to protect her. But everything went wrong. I made a bargain, and after that… I can’t remember when things started to slip away. I thought I was saving them. I thought I was doing what was needed. But nothing turned out as I hoped.” His words come in broken fragments, sometimes clear, sometimes warped and distant, as if spoken from underwater. Frost creeps across the floor, regret weighing the air. Yet there’s a flicker of longing—a yearning for something better. Azeroth (offended, almost hurt; the darkness pulses, pressing in): “You asked for deliverance. You pleaded for protection. I gave you what you wished—your army preserved, your enemies at bay. And yet, not a word of thanks. Not even from her.” The room vibrates with resentment, the air thickening, oppressive. You feel the pressure in your skull, as if the room itself resents the lack of gratitude. Azeroth's tone is sharper, more brittle, as if the lack of gratitude wounds him. His control is still strong, but now tinged with irritation. Mother (quietly firm; her light pushes back the gloom, illuminating the cracks in the crystal): “I saw the trap, even if you could not. I told you there was another way, but you were too desperate to hear me. I never stopped loving you, even when I feared what you were becoming.” Her light pushes back the gloom, illuminating the cracks in the crystal, creating a path of light through the darkness—a memory of what might have been. The Emperor’s form glimmers faintly, as if remembering hope. Azeroth (mocking; his voice multiplies, echoing from every shadow): “See? Even she doubted you. And he admits it. Weakness. Guilt. That’s all he is. That’s all he’ll ever be. It’s why he needs me.” His voice multiplies—a chorus of sneers and whispers, bouncing off the walls, making the shadows press tighter, suffocating. There’s an edge of desperation now, a need to reassert dominance. Emperor (confused, voice thin; his image blurs, almost fading): “I… I don’t know. Maybe I was wrong to ask. Maybe I should have listened. But I was so afraid. So desperate. And you were there, offering answers…” His image blurs, flickering as if he’s being erased. The air grows thin, and the room seems to shrink, as if the world is forgetting him. You (your voice a lifeline, the only thing holding the room together): “He made you desperate. He fed your fear, made you believe there was no other path. He twisted every doubt, every silence between you and Mother, separated you from loyal friends—until you couldn’t see hope anymore.” Your words cut through the echoes. The labyrinth pulses, and the shadows stutter, losing their hold. Mother (softening; her hand reaches out, her touch a gentle breeze): “You weren’t weak, only human. I wish you’d trusted me, but I understand why you didn’t. I forgive you. I always did.” Her forgiveness radiates warmth, the cracks in the crystal glowing with golden light. The air shimmers, and for a moment, you hear the faint sound of her laughter, echoing from a place beyond memory. [[Ash’s Return: The Catalyst]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Ash’s Return: The Catalyst</h2> While Azaroth’s attention is fixed on you and your mother, a golden light flickers at the edge of your vision—a ripple in the psychic haze. You sense, rather than see, a small presence slip into the room: Ash, silent, eyes wide with exhaustion and resolve. Shadows cling to him like mist, but his gaze is fixed not on you, but on the Emperor. Ash closes his eyes, steadying himself. He doesn’t speak; he doesn’t need to. You feel the brush of his hand in yours—real and not real at once, a memory, a promise, a final act of courage. The Emperor sees him. For a moment, neither moves. Then Ash lifts his hand. The Emperor, jaw set, mirrors him. Their palms meet. Where their hands touch, light pulses outward—silver and gold, flickering with memories and lost time. For a heartbeat, you see both faces, child and man, superimposed: innocence and sorrow, hope and regret, fusing into one. The Emperor’s hands, once heavy with age and guilt, now move with the lightness of a child’s. You watch, heart pounding, as something unspoken passes between them. There’s a familiarity in the way the Emperor looks at Ash—a recognition deeper than words. You recall how Ash always seemed to know the palace’s hidden passages, the secret ways only a royal child would ever discover. He’d flinch at the same nightmares that haunted the Emperor, and sometimes he’d whisper old words—private phrases, childhood promises—you once overheard the Emperor mutter in his sleep. Ash never seemed to age, even as the years blurred in the labyrinth. He spoke with a wisdom that belonged to someone much older, yet sometimes shrank from the world like a frightened boy. Sometimes, you’d catch Ash watching the Emperor from afar, his small face shadowed by a sadness far beyond his years. He never tried to approach, never tried to be seen; it was as if he knew the Emperor could not see him, or would not. There was a heaviness in Ash’s gaze, a silent understanding that there was no way to save the Emperor from himself. Whenever you witnessed this, it always felt strange—at odds with everything you thought you knew about the boy. You didn’t know why, but the sight unsettled you, as if you were glimpsing a truth just out of reach. But none of this—none of Ash’s cleverness, his hiding, his hope—would have been enough. Not without you. He was kept safe, yes, but trapped, powerless to reach this place alone. It was you who found the Heartstone, you who braved the catacombs, you who earned Ash’s trust and brought him here. You who refused Azaroth’s bargains, who took the harder path. Only together could you reach this final room, this final moment. A sudden, impossible understanding rises in you—not from nowhere, but from all the pieces finally clicking into place. Ash isn’t just a wandering spirit. He is something the Emperor lost—or hid—long ago. Something precious, uncorrupted, and deeply familiar. Ash glances at you. For the first time, you see not just a boy, but a memory made real—an echo of innocence, courage, and love. He smiles, brave and sad, and in that look you see both gratitude and farewell. And you understand: this is goodbye. Now, as the light between Ash and the Emperor grows, the world seems to hold its breath. Their hands meet—child’s and man’s—and light pulses outward, silver and gold, flickering with memories and lost time. For a single heartbeat, their faces blur and merge: child and man, innocence and sorrow, hope, forgiveness and regret, all fusing into one. Then the light intensifies, and Ash’s form dissolves completely—not vanishing, but becoming indistinguishable from the Emperor, as if the two have always been one being, finally made whole. The light flares, and Ash’s form dissolves into the Emperor, merging in a rush of memory and feeling. The Emperor straightens, shoulders squaring, his presence suddenly commanding. He looks down at his hand, then at the space where Ash stood. His voice, when it comes, is steady, but there’s a quiet tremor beneath the words. “He was what I hid from Azaroth,” he says. “The last of what I was before the darkness took hold. When I knew I was losing myself, I split my mind. I sent him away—my hope, my innocence—so that something good might survive, even if I did not.” He lifts his head, and for the first time, you see a new steadiness in his eyes—a warmth that wasn’t there before. And in that gaze, you recognize something else: a deep, grateful recognition of the journey you both endured, side by side, in the shadowed catacombs. The Emperor’s expression softens, and for a moment, you can still see a glimmer of Ash there—a trace of the friend you never expected to find in your father. “For so long, I thought I was lost. But he waited for me. He kept the best of me safe, all these years. And you—you helped bring me back. You were the friend I never thought I’d have, not as a ruler, not even as a father. Now, at last, I am whole. And I am free.” The chamber is silent, the light gentle and whole. In that hush, you understand: Ash and the Emperor were never truly separate. The child’s courage and the man’s sorrow are one and the same—and now, at last, they are whole again. [[Chapter 46: The Final Confrontation]](set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)The Arranged Marriage The counselors, now controlling the corrupted Tharion, arrange for his daughter to marry a cruel partner They target her because of her mother's bloodline, which is the one connected to the temple The corrupted Tharion, now completely evil, approves of this arrangement This planned marriage becomes the catalyst for the protagonist's escape and the beginning of the main story “I died.., I am sure it is so.” She scans back to her last memories, although clouded... She felt the hopelessness of her sickness and final acceptance of death. In the last days she had welcomed it. A strange blankness and sudden fragility stops her from probing her thoughts further. She mouths to herself. “But it cannot be.” Aelira tries to calm her thoughts. Reaching for the princess, she holds her gently, tucking in the soft woollen blanket. Attempting to rock them both to sleep. Failing, she continues to stare into the night silently, swaying back and forth. And Aelira... something is wrong with Aelira. She moves differently, speaks differently. Sometimes he catches her staring at their daughter with an expression he cannot name but that chills his blood. When he confronts her, she smiles in a way that doesn't reach her eyes and speaks of being "merely tired." [[Rebirth of the moon]]<Notes to self Rebirth of the moon: The queen has a night mare, and realises she had died But doesnt yet realisewhat has happend, Tharion deal etc, but instead worries she may be losing her mind> It is the day of the coronation. The Lord Chancellor’s words ring above all. “Be strong and of good courage, that you may be a king of our age in justice and glory!” Theodoric’s words ring in acceptance of this command with vibrancy, The words echo and fade, distorted against the columns of the mighty cathedral. Looking at the crowd, Aelira is buoyed by the joyful faces she sees, looking at him in tenderness. Luminous and effervescent crowds. The velvety rose petals fall, their fragrance sweet and enduring. A small peasant boy runs smiling at her. In his hands a hidden gift which he imparts to her wordlessly, with solemn innocence. She opens her cupped hands to reveal a small dead bird. In shock she looks up, back to the boy. He studies her face with sadness. His eyes dark and wise, aged with care.., seemingly at congruities with such a young body. He seems to fade back into himself somehow. Leaving the young boy to run off. In revulsion she stares at the dead bird, her hands feel immobile, unable to release the corpse to the ground. The flesh is Rotten and pustulant, pocked with small maggots moving within the thin shell of semitransparent skin. They feast uninterrupted, indifferent to her horror. However, It is the coldness of the body that shocks her, the emptiness so consuming... Almost as if she is being sucked into the blackness. It draws her in... Queen Aelira wakes sharply. “I died.., I am sure it is so.” She scans back to her last memories, although clouded... She felt the hopelessness of her sickness and final acceptance of death. In the last days she had welcomed it. A strange blankness and sudden fragility stops her from probing her thoughts further. She mouths to herself. “But it cannot be.” Aelira tries to calm her thoughts. Reaching for the princess, she holds her gently, tucking in the soft woollen blanket. Attempting to rock them both to sleep. Failing, she continues to stare into the night silently, swaying back and forth. Choice Prompt example format and content CHOICE: TORREN RAMPARTS [[Option A – Reinforce Duty to the Emperor]] [[Option B – Focus on Protecting Siania]] [[Option C – Strive for Neutral Ground]] END CHOICE If Option A - Reinforce Duty to the Emperor: With jaw set, Torren touches the sunburst on his tunic. The oath is everything; feelings must wait. If Option B - Focus on Protecting Siania: A slow breath escapes him. Whatever the cost, the Little Fox will not face the court alone. If Option C - Strive for Neutral Ground: He lets the wind carry his doubts—no hurry, no vows, only watchful patience for the moment to act.<h2>Stay quiet, match the guards’ cold demeanor</h2> At first, Torren, molded by a child’s urge to fit in and bound to House Lucian, sided with the guards. He assumed their silence reflected agreement with the queen’s execution. He kept his distance, mirroring the guards' stoicism. When Siania first arrived, he saw her as a small, defiant figure but remained unmoved, prioritizing his place among the Lucian boys. In those early days, he neither offered a hand nor a word, his indifference a quiet barrier between them. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[''The Comrades They Became''] But time erodes even the hardest barriers. Torren couldn’t ignore Siania’s skill—her sword strikes precise, her sling deadly—or the grudging respect she earned from the fort’s boys and veterans. She was daring where others hesitated, fiercely protective of the ragged outcasts who formed around her. The boys called her Little Fox for her cunning, her fearless raids into the Purged Lands. A compliment, yes—but foxes don’t trust. They survive. Torren’s friends had been skeptical when the exiled girl joined them. Yet through sheer stubbornness and skill, Siania carved her place among them. They became a unit—Torren’s childhood friends and this copper-haired outsider who had grown indispensable. They sparred until their muscles screamed, traded insults with grins, fought side by side in the wastes beyond the walls. The group that was once Torren’s alone now orbited around her, like river stones reshaped by a relentless current. Yet the past lingered. When Siania laughed, it never reached her eyes—the only tell of the rift between them. She joked easily with them but fell silent when talk turned to House matters. A Lucian soldier, yet never truly one of them. The last daughter of Ne’Tiriania knew better than to test where loyalties would fall when politics demanded blood. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[''The Choice That Loomed''] The guards had marked Torren that first day—not for defiance, but for silence. Where they’d once watched the orphan boy for potential, they now saw only another Lucian blade: solid, dependable, //unremarkable.// He would do his duty, nothing more. He could have been the first to step forward. He should have been the one to break the silence. But he hadn’t. And though years had forged them into comrades, though they trusted each other with their lives in battle, one truth remained: Siania had earned respect through skill, not trust. And Torren? He would have to earn it through a choice as bold as the one he’d once failed to make. She was House Ne’Tiriania’s last heir. He was House Lucian’s faithful blade. And one day, that divide would demand an answer. Would he stand with his House? Or would he finally stand for her? <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Days of Innocence]]</span> (set: $fortKezerakApproval to it - 1) (set: $notificationMessage to "-1 Fort Kezerak") (display: "Notification") (display: "Allegiances") (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Defy the guards’ attitude and offer immediate help.</h2> At first, Torren, molded by a child’s urge to fit in and bound to House Lucian, sided with the guards. He assumed their silence meant Siania was somehow to blame for the coldness, a conclusion drawn from his limited understanding of the adult world. He didn’t yet grasp that the guards were caught in a web of fear and political caution, unwilling to risk persecution (theirs and hers) by showing her kindness. He kept his distance, observing as she entered the fort. But something shifted within him. He saw no one offer a hand, saw her small frame tremble not just from exhaustion but from something deeper, perhaps fear or loss. In that moment, a thread of doubt wove in, questioning the obedience and Lucian ties he belonged to. (text-colour:#d0af53)[The First Step of Kinship] Despite the guards’ silence and inaction, Torren felt a surge of protectiveness. Though loyal to these men, he was compelled to stand by her. At eight, he wasn’t political—just a boy following his heart. His courage broke through the fort’s fear; as he stepped forward, the soldiers saw not just a child, but a rare spark of kindness and bravery. The Adjudicator’s narrowed eyes hinted at danger. He couldn’t fault a child openly, but tension lingered—no one knew how he might react. The soldiers admired Torren’s quiet heroism – though his defiance chilled them. They’d seen children flayed by Adjudicator’s reports before. His youth might protect him, if they could smooth it over. But challenging the Order of Severin invited consequences no one could undo. Yet in that stolen moment of rebellion – in that spark of humanity even the Adjudicator couldn’t extinguish – he won both factions’ silent respect. Duty forbade them to show gratitude. But in their eyes, Torren saw it: not a leader yet, but the kindling of something that might survive the coming dark. Torren's defiance that day—an eight-year-old boy shielding a frightened six-year-old exile when no one else would—marked the first crack in the fort's indifference. Back then, he hadn't thought of it as courage. He had just been a child himself, reacting to the raw injustice of her exile. But that instinctive act had become the foundation of something unshakable. To the Order of Severin, they had been nothing - a nameless orphan and the disgraced daughter of a condemned house, already expunged from official records in a remote outpost the world had forgotten. Torren's childish defiance meant nothing against the machinery of Order's justice. Yet as the years hardened them both, the truth had become undeniable. He had been her stubborn protector even when he could barely lift a training sword. She had become the sister of his heart long before either understood what that bond would demand. Now, at twenty-eight, Torren looked back and saw the shape of their loyalty—forged not in grand gestures but in countless quiet acts of defiance against a world that had cast her out. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Days of Innocence]]</span> (set: $torren to it + 3, $jaro to it + 1, $tarek to it + 1, $fortKezerakApproval to it + 3) (display: "Allegiances") (set: $notificationMessage to "Jaro & Tarek approve! +3 Fort Kezerak approval + 3 Loyalist approval + 3") (display: "Notification") (set: $jaro to it + 1) (set: $tarek to it + 1) (set: $fortKezerakApproval to it + 3) (set: $KezerakRevolt to it + 3) (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Days of Innocence</h2> His gaze drifted to the distant dunes beyond the fort’s walls, where the sand shimmered under the harsh sun, and Torren couldn’t help but see them as children again, racing across that same unforgiving terrain toward incoming caravans. Torren remembered her as a child—racing across the dunes with the rest of them to meet Talon’s caravans, all of them half-wild, half-starved, and wholly incorrigible. (text-colour:#d0a853)[How does Torren use his influence during the race?] <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[He runs ahead with the others, she's not part of their circle.]] </span> <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[He slows to run beside Siania]] </span> <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[He calls out sharply to the boys, ordering them to wait for Siania]] </span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <h2>Roots in the Desert</h2> Siania cherished the stories of that ancient strife above all, her voice hushed with reverence as she touched the altered ground, as if her exile and unspoken magic tied her to its wounds. (if: $helpedSiania)[ She always sat at the heart of their circle, red hair wild, green eyes alight, the desert sand sometimes stirring at her feet in ways only the other children noticed.](else:)[she sat a little to the side of their circle, red hair wild, green eyes alight, the desert sand sometimes stirring at her feet in ways only the other children noticed.]For Siania, the desert was more than a backdrop; it was woven into her being, an unstrippable strength and anchor—Kezerak, a home after all that had been lost, connecting her to her lineage's past. Years later, Torren pieced together what he’d missed as a boy. The caravan drivers who brought dates and supplies to the fort weren’t just traders. Some bore the white crane tattoo of the Kren Legion—men with a quiet discipline that set them apart from ordinary merchants. Their visits always coincided with the gatherings in the narrow shade of the fort’s wall, where stories of House Ne’Tiriania’s fall were told. House Kren were still loyalists, Torren realized. These drivers weren’t just hauling goods; they were soldiers, tasked with more than supply runs. They came to remind Siania—and the other children—of who she was. Of who they all might have been, had the war ended differently. They wanted her as their queen. The guards’ complicity made sense now. Some officers turned a blind eye to the meetings, even smoothed the way for the caravans to pass the Order of Severin’s tax collectors. Over time, many of those familiar faces—drivers vanished, their fate unknown, and the cherished visits ceased as if disrupted by some unseen shift beyond the fort’s gaze, leaving a void where hope once flickered. This deepened the ache of Siania’s potential loss: she would lose the home she had made in exile with them, and they would lose her—the one who embodied a hidden hope within their quiet resistance. It was a hope Torren, Jaro, and Tarek had unknowingly guarded, their protection woven into an unspoken allegiance to her as a potential queen. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|A mind adrift]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <h2>A Mind Adrift</h2> Why did this thought seize him now, when duty demanded his attention? He turned his eyes to the arena below, seeking a moment of respite. The trials were a source of quiet pride for Fort Kezerak, a display of skill and honor that steadied Torren’s mood as he looked forward to the efforts of the fort’s warriors and the visiting competitors who joined them for the month. Yet, even this could not fully draw him from his inner conflict. Boots crunched behind him, pulling him from his thoughts. A young guardsman saluted. Torren nodded, masking his unease with a commander’s steadiness. “All’s quiet. Keep an eye on the north parapet—the wind’s turning. A storm brews in the southeast, though not a full khamsin. The roads are still clear, but late arrivals might miss the last event. We expect House Sabine and Vorn by dusk, coming from Talin. What’s your assessment?” he tested. The guardsman hesitated, then spoke with cautious thought. “They might struggle with even small sandstorms, sir, being unused to these lands. It could be wise to send a patrol. We wouldn’t want them delayed or unsettled, and showing our strength might deter scavengers.” “Good thinking,” Torren said. “Have patrols watch for their banners and guide them in. Look out for trouble, but only stragglers, understood?” “Yes, sir,” the guardsman replied. “I’ll see to it and ensure the orders are passed along.” He gave a sharp nod, moved off to relay the instructions, before returning to his post. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|When Duty Was Clear]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>When Duty Was Clear</h2> Torren observed the young sentinel settle in, noting the sharp salute and unclouded eagerness in his eyes. There had been a time when duty felt that straightforward to Torren—before the boundaries of oath and loyalty grew indistinct. The boy’s perspective was still unmarred; Torren’s had become a landscape of shifting sand. A familiar step broke his thoughts. Jaro approached, helmet under arm, a wry grin in place. “Brooding again?” Torren managed a faint smile, eyes still on the distant field. “They’ve come for her. We won’t be at her side after this.” Jaro’s grin eased, a flicker of understanding in his gaze. “True. It’s a hard thing, knowing she’ll face that world alone.” Torren’s eyes narrowed slightly, voice low. “We’ve shielded her here. Out there, it’s a different fight.” Jaro nodded, his tone steady. “She’s faced hard odds with us. Still, I feel the weight of not standing with her.” Torren’s jaw tightened, a rare edge slipping through. “Hard odds, yes. But not like this. No blades or sand—just schemes we can’t counter.” Jaro met his gaze, resolute. “She won’t stand alone if this trial proves her worth. Let’s hope it wins her strong allies.” Torren exhaled, the tension easing a fraction. “We’ll see her through this much, at least.” Jaro’s smirk returned, a quiet determination beneath it. “Our little fox—she’ll outwit them yet.” Torren gave a slight nod, a trace of warmth buried beneath his reserve. “Your optimism is a constant, Jaro.” Jaro’s smirk deepened, though it carried no malice. “A necessary counterweight to your gravity, I’d wager.” He fell into step beside Torren, his easy stride a contrast to Torren’s measured pace, yet both were bound by shared years and the unspoken weight of what lay ahead. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Pride Tinged with Sorrow]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <h2>Pride Tinged with Sorrow</h2> A quiet pride stirred in Torren’s composed exterior. Siania’s strengths would hold—he had no doubt. In her, they recognized resilience and skill. This trial, part of "The Passing" at Fort Kezarak, was more than a challenge. It was a defining moment. Held in the emperor’s remote desert stronghold, it was a private event. Soldiers rose in rank there, while Noble Houses backed fighters and gained prestige. As a rule, the emperor kept his distance, with the Order of Severin dispatching mere Adjudicators to collect taxes, never their Hyrach. But now, the entire court descended upon the fort. Their presence lent weight to the occasion and created tension in the fort. The gathered nobility brought poisonings and political schemes, though most soldiers ignored these intrigues. For Siania, heir to the emperor, the stakes reached far beyond the arena. This moment aligned with the emperor’s decision to reclaim his child to court to strengthen his reign, a rare and significant act, the reason for the court’s attendance. Torren, though sharp and observant, knew little of the deeper reasons—out here in this isolated outpost, under the emperor’s strict control, news was scarce, with only fragments slipping through from supply caravans. He hoped Siania’s performance would earn her the recognition she deserved, proving her worth not just as a warrior but as a figure of strength in this pivotal transition. Yet beneath that pride, a bittersweet undercurrent persisted. Success meant her return to the capital, ending her time among them, and the fort would lose a vital part of itself. Still, Torren wished she would win—not just for her sake, but so her success could protect her and win allies at court, carrying Kezarak’s values to a place that desperately needed them. The clang of steel and the roar of the crowd grew louder as they descended from the ramparts, the sounds rising to meet them like a tide. Torren’s eyes lingered on the arena below. “Come on, she doesn’t waste a move. If she wins, it’ll be quick and clean—we don’t want to miss it. The only ones who should be sweating are House Kren’s tracker and the judges, trying to keep up. So stop worrying.” Tarek joined them, his nod carrying quiet assurance. “She’ll have to end it before he can wear her down—precision over brute force, as always.” He clapped Jaro’s shoulder, tone steady. “Accuracy is her edge.” Jaro tossed him a waterskin. “Tarek’s got three silver on her disarming Kren’s man. I say he’ll make her work for it—he’s not easy to catch off guard.” Torren’s lips quirked into a rare smile. “Either way, it’ll be a match worth watching. She’s always known how to find the smallest opening.” He nodded toward the crowded gates, where the crowd pressed close. “Is Vestergaard here to survey the field?” <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Next|Light Words, Heavy Thoughts]] </span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Light Words, Heavy Thoughts</h2> Jaro gave a low huff, eyes narrowing with dry amusement. “Surveying, indeed. He watches the yard as a hawk eyes open ground—though I reckon it’s not just her blade he’s keen to know, given the betrothal.” Tarek’s eyes sharpened, a protective edge beneath his calm. A brief smirk crossed Torren’s face, fleeting but pointed. “Hard to fault him. A talent like hers? He’s likely never seen a woman rival him in the trial’s sword forms—even if it’s just drills, not real fighting.” Jaro leaned closer, voice low with a conspiratorial tone. “I doubt it’s those particular ‘forms’ that hold his interest.” Torren’s elbow nudged sharply, his look cutting. “Mind yourself, Jaro. That’s Siania. Show some respect.” Jaro lifted a hand in mock surrender, smirk fading under Torren’s firm gaze, the quip carrying more weight than meant, tinged with a shared, quiet envy they all had for the man who’d claim their closest companion. Tarek muttered, “He’s probably just hoping she’ll save him from his mother.” The three diffused snorted almost in unison. Jaro shook his head. “Gods, picture it. Our little fox staring down Lady Vestergaard at breakfast.” He tried to mimic Siania’s glare, earning a crooked smile from Torren. Jaro’s tone grew shadowed. “Lady Vestergaard’s ruthlessness isn’t mere gossip—she’s a mother-in-law you don’t defy. You’ve heard the stories.” He gave a slight shudder, leaving the rest unspoken. (text-colour:#c0975f)[''A Deeper Concern''] Tarek’s grin flashed again, undeterred. “Good that Siania’s training then, useful for a real fight.” Torren shook his head, still chuckling. “Vestergaard’d trade every ancestral sword in his house for that.” Jaro’s fingers drummed on the hilt at his side. “We might yet hold him to that.” “Should he ever need steel—” Tarek began, but Jaro cut him off, voice dropping low. “Vestergaard can swing a sword well enough—both of them can—but his mother rules the court, a far deadlier battlefield than any tourney ground. He may be a capable fighter, but he’s ill-prepared to shield Siania from the games she’ll face there.” The group fell silent. <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Next|A Procession of Power]] </span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>A Procession of Power</h2> They moved steadily down the road, the crowds thickening with every step. Merchants hawked their wares from colorful stalls, their calls weaving through the air alongside the scent of spiced meats and fresh bread. Festive banners in Lucial colours fluttered overhead, and laughter mingled with the clatter of boots on stone. Yet beneath the surface buzz, a tension hummed—an undercurrent of anticipation that tightened as they neared the arena gates. Then it came—a jarring clash of iron bells, joined by the steady thud of sand-worn feet. Their words fell silent, a ripple of stillness spreading outward. Torren, Jaro, and Tarek slowed their pace; the street itself seemed to tense. Eyes turned. From the glare emerged the palanquin. It moved with a somber grandeur, lacquered panels glinting like newly drawn blades, silk drapes in crimson and gold catching the light. Indentured porters, ribs visible beneath tattered livery, bore its weight with faltering steps. Each movement was urged by thin, jeweled lashes in the hands of junior acolytes; every strike left a mark, drew a stifled cry, and—more chillingly—a forced “thank you” from the one struck. Some nobles along the path wore masks of detachment, though unease betrayed them in fleeting glances, while others watched with revulsion they dared not voice. Officers, bound by duty, remained expressionless. Merchants turned their gaze aside, feigning ignorance. Soldiers stood rigid and silent, their faces a mix of anger and shame, held in check by discipline. Sadaarkian nobles observed with stiff approval or barely concealed discomfort, shown in tightened lips or subtle shifts of gaze. Their courtesans, faces partly veiled by painted fans, murmured softly, their expressions unreadable as they navigated the undercurrents of courtly games. Lucian officers from other participating forts, clad in their house’s colors, stood unyielding, their neutrality a shield, though a hint of resentment might flicker in their eyes. Allegiant officers, the emperor's elite, dressed in black, upheld flawless discipline, faces blank, yet brief, almost imperceptible glances passed among them. Envoys, ever observant, cataloged each reaction, their own visages carefully empty to avoid any misstep. At the center sat Morvaine, Thrice-Scarred Hierophant of the Order of Severin. His skin bore the marks of ceremonial brands across his bare scalp, each scar threaded with black opal. He reclined on velvet cushions, one gaunt hand gripping an iron crozier, the other idly tracing a rosary of finger-bones. Around him gathered scarlet-robed hierarchs, laden with rings, reliquaries, and the cloying scent of attar meant to cover traces of old blood. They chanted litanies of self-denial, even as they surrounded themselves with gem-studded opulence. Behind them followed novices in plain cincture and linen—young, earnest, still believing in a sacred purpose. They marched in step, unaware of the records of bribes and tithes swelling Morvaine’s coffers or the dungeons hidden beneath his sanctuaries. The higher one rose in Severin, the more shadowed the paths became; innocence was stripped away layer by layer. The procession pressed forward, a tangible force of sanctioned harshness pushing legionaries to the roadside. A single nod from Morvaine prompted an acolyte to lash a porter with greater force, the whip's crack splitting the air. Dust blended with incense; blood dotted the heated stone. (text-colour:#c0975f)[''How does Torren react?''] <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Silently Endure]] </span> <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Offer a Quiet Support.]]</span> <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Shield Jaro's Expression]]</span>(set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Days of Innocence 2</h2> Once the wagons were empty, they'd huddle in the blue shade by the courtyard wall, the driver weaving stories of pirates, whirlpools, and true khamsin with feigned exasperation and real warmth. Their knack for turning anything into a game was evident in how they jostled for the best listening spot near the unloading area. As the afternoon waned and the shadows grew longer, the mood shifted. The ancient tales quieted them—accounts of mage wars that had shattered what was once an idyllic realm. From where they sat, the children could see the distant silhouette of Fort Kezarak’s southwestern flank, where the walls merged with the Great Cliff. Its sheer face was carved with a deep incision, running straight down to the base, scarring the wall and bursting into the pockmarked, blistered sand below. There, deep obsidian shards still shone from the heat that had turned it into glass—the marks of the sorcery that had created the Mage Sands. Where rivers once cut through green valleys and forests stretched to the horizon, now only fissures, sinkholes, and crystallized sand drifts remained—scars of betrayal and power. Torren remembered the driver’s eyes glinting as he spoke of a Ne’Tiriania mage who had fallen there. He looked at Siania as if seeing her own legacy in the story. The driver called it a final stand—a desperate defense of the land where her ancestors once raised their banners. House Ne’Tiriania later fled to Talin, abandoning their home in the old southern palace and Fort Kezarak, which was eventually claimed by the Emperor under Lucian rule. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Stories Roots in the desert]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <h2>He runs ahead with the others, she's not part of their circle.</h2> The others follow without hesitation, their pace quickening as Torren leads. He's always been the fastest, the one to follow, some think, falling into step. Siania stays behind, the space between her and the group growing. //She's different,// others murmur, watching her. The distance feels natural to some, but to others, the absence weighs heavier than before. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Arrive at carravan]]</span> <!--Stories Roots in the desert--> (set: $torren to it - 1, $jaro to it - 1, $tarek to it - 1, $fortKezerakApproval to it - 1) (set: $notificationMessage to "-1 Fort Kezerak, Jaro and Tarek disapprove") (display: "Notification") (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>He slows to run beside Siania</h2> The painted wagons of the storytellers' caravan beckoned in the distance. Torren, usually the first to race ahead, matched his stride to Siania's. Her small legs worked hard to keep up, her face bright with the effort. He offered no words, no grand gesture, just a steady presence. The other boys, drawn to Torren's quiet strength, eased their pace without being told. A few glanced at Siania, noticing the determination in her face, the way she struggled to keep up. A flicker of understanding passed between them. //Maybe she's not so bad//, one seemed to think. //Torren's looking out for her.// The wagons still promised treats and tales, but the race had subtly transformed into a shared journey, one where Siania now had a place. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Arrive at carravan]]</span> <!--Stories Roots in the desert--> (set: $helpedSiania to true) (set: $torren to it + 1, $jaro to it + 1, $tarek to it + 1, $fortKezerakApproval to it + 1) (set: $notificationMessage to "+1 Fort Kezerak, Jaro and Tarek approve, Ran with the fox") (display: "Notification") (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>He calls out sharply to the boys, ordering them to wait for Siania..</h2> His voice cuts through the air, firm and unyielding. //He's always got to be in charge//, some think, bristling at the command. The group halts abruptly, eyes flicking between one another and Torren. //Why does he always have to make it a thing? //others wonder, resenting the forced situation. The children's own sense of choice is overridden. Siania stands caught in the middle—pulled forward by his command, yet uneasy with the attention it draws. She didn't ask for this, some realize, feeling a mix of pity and resentment. Friendships aren’t something to be commanded, and the weight of his authority leaves a tension that lingers long after the race resumes. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Arrive at carravan]]</span> <!--Stories Roots in the desert--> (set: $torren to it + 1, $jaro to it + 1, $tarek to it + 1, $fortKezerakApproval to it + 2) (set: $notificationMessage to "+2 Fort Kezerak, Jaro and Tarek approve") (display: "Notification") (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)(display: "Header") (link: "Back")[(go-to: (history: 1))]<!--Allegiances--> <!-- CSS styling --> <style> #allegiance-table { width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse; margin: 1em 0; color: #c0975f; } #allegiance-table th, #allegiance-table td { border: 1px solid #c0975f; padding: 8px; text-align: left; } #allegiance-table th { background-color: #2a2a2a; } #allegiance-table tr:nth-child(even) { background-color: #1a1a1a; } .imperial { color: #c0975f; } .loyalist { color: #c0975f; } .neutral { color: #c0975f; } .independent { color: #c0975f; } </style> <!-- Initialize factions if not set --> (if: $factions is not a datamap)[ (set: $factions to (dm: "imperial", (a: "emperor", "ladyVestergaard", "severin", "court", "vestergaard"), "loyalist", (a: "ash", "valerius"), "neutral", (a: "agamar", "kaleth", "jaro", "tarek", "siania", "torren"), "independent", (a: "halak", "arafis", "draethlyn") )) ] <div id="allegiance-table"> <h3 id="allegiance-header">Allegiances</h3> <table> <tr> <th>Faction</th> <th>Character</th> <th>Allegiance Level</th> <th>Allies</th> <!-- New column --> <th>Enemies</th> <!-- New column --> </tr> <!-- Imperial Faction --> <tr class="imperial"> <td rowspan="5">Imperial</td> <td>Emperor Lucius</td> <td>(print: $emperor)</td> <td>(print: $emperorAllies)</td> <td>(print: $emperorEnemies)</td> </tr> <tr class="imperial"> <td>Lady Vestergaard</td> <td>(print: $ladyVestergaard)</td> <td>(print: $severinEnemies)</td> </tr> <tr class="imperial"> <td>The Court</td> <td>(print: $court)</td> <td>(print: $courtAllies)</td> <td>(print: $courtEnemies)</td> </tr> <tr class="imperial">
